Speaker: NA
Text: Monday, 6 March 1989

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: ELECTORAL DIVISION OF GWYDIR

Speaker: NA
Text: Issue of Writ

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-I inform the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have today issued a writ for the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of a member to serve for the electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: division of Gwydir in the State of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales in place of the Hon. Ralph James

Speaker: NA
Text: Dunnet Hunt. The dates in connection with

Speaker: NA
Text: the election are fixed as follows: close of the

Speaker: NA
Text: roll, Monday, 13 March 1989; date of nom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ination, Friday, 17 March 1989; date of poll-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, Saturday, 15 April 1989; date of return

Speaker: NA
Text: of writ, on or before Thursday, 1 June 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Wills-Prime Minister)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House that the Minister for Sci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry

Speaker: NA
Text: Jones, left Australia on 3 March to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: an environmental conference and for associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated discussions in London. He will return

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia on 15 March. In his absence,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Industry, Technology and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce, Senator Button, has assumed Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Jones's portfolio duties and the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, is represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Minister in this chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORT AND

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMUNICATIONS: SALE OF

Speaker: NA
Text: AIRCRAFT

Speaker: Mr BLUNT
Text: My question is directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Transport and Communica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Was an F28 aircraft owned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's Department disposed of without

Speaker: NA
Text: public tender? Was this aircraft acquired by

Speaker: NA
Text: a company of the Ansett group and was it

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately resold overseas for a profit of

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of dollars? Did the procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted by the Department for this sale

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with the finance regulations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Administrative Services? If

Speaker: NA
Text: not, why not?

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Text: I suggest that the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member put the question on notice.

Speaker: NA
Text: WAGE-TAX TRADE-OFF

Speaker: Mr MOUNTFORD
Text: Can the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister advise the House of the principles being

Speaker: NA
Text: used to determine the Government's ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to the wage-tax trade-off in the forth-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming April economic statement?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: The tax cuts that my Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment will provide from 1 July will recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nise that those in receipt of average, or

Speaker: NA
Text: around average, earnings have borne the

Speaker: NA
Text: greater part of the burden of restraint. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the event, our tax cuts will be concentrated

Speaker: NA
Text: on low to moderate income earners because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is the case that they have earned the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts and they will get them. We will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: those tax cuts in the context of an econom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ically responsible wage-tax trade-off. In ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaining that tax cut in the context of our

Speaker: NA
Text: economic responsibility, I say it is well known

Speaker: NA
Text: that that sort of economic responsibility is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a strong suit of those opposite. We see

Speaker: NA
Text: that honourable members opposite are now

Speaker: NA
Text: contemplating trying to slide out of detailing

Speaker: NA
Text: the spending cuts that they would make to

Speaker: NA
Text: fund their tax cuts. One could well ask who

Speaker: NA
Text: said this of the coalition's tax policy:

Speaker: NA
Text: I have said all along that the timetable for policy

Speaker: NA
Text: release is by August 1988 ... is going to be adhered

Speaker: NA
Text: to.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was said by the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. As against what is happening on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's side, it is well known that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has never shirked the responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility of explaining to the Australian com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity just where the money to finance tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts is coming from. In that context, Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, you could well ask who, in a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fidential memo to the preceding Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kooyong, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We will be very vulnerable if Labor can successfully

Speaker: NA
Text: put the tag of 'Where's the money coming from' on

Speaker: NA
Text: our election offerings.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was what the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bennelong said to the then Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition: that they would be vulnerable if

Speaker: NA
Text: they could not say where the money was

Speaker: NA
Text: coming from. I say to the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Banks, and through him and the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to the Australian community: The

Speaker: NA
Text: community will be left in no doubt-as far

Speaker: NA
Text: as we are concerned on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House-as to where the money is coming

Speaker: NA
Text: from to finance the tax cuts of this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. What you will find on the other side,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker, is no indication whatsoever

Speaker: NA
Text: at this stage. Now there is an indication that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition will slide out of that respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility altogether.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I ask this House to contrast what

Speaker: NA
Text: is said in 'Futile Diversions' on this score. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Futile Diversions' on page 3 the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition said:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . politicians . . . have glossed over the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth when it has been too difficult for them to cope

Speaker: NA
Text: with its consequences and made unrealistic promises

Speaker: NA
Text: which have built up false expectations of what can

Speaker: NA
Text: be achieved.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we are witnessing at this stage in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard to the Opposition's so-called tax and

Speaker: NA
Text: fiscal policy is exactly described by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition's own statement on

Speaker: NA
Text: page 3. As we go through this year, Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, you will continue to see this con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trast: absolutely explicit indications by this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House as to where the tax cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: will be coming from; as far as the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: is concerned, no indication whatsoever.

Speaker: NA
Text: INFLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer. I remind him that on 9 Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember last he said in an address to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Planning Advisory Council:

Speaker: NA
Text: The wage/tax trade-off we will implement will

Speaker: NA
Text: secure a further fall in inflation to around three

Speaker: NA
Text: four per cent in 1990.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the Treasurer still stand by this predic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion? If not, what is his revised assumption

Speaker: NA
Text: for inflation for the calculation of the For-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward Estimates for next year?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I addressed all these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters publicly a couple of weeks ago in a

Speaker: NA
Text: press conference-which I have and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member does not have.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: What about the Parliament?

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for O'Connor will not interject.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: We don't want to know what

Speaker: NA
Text: he said out there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for O'Connor will not argue

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Chair.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I refer the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman to the transcript.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOVIET DIPLOMAT

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BILNEYI direct my question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. I refer to the rather feverish

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations by the shadow Minister for for-

Speaker: NA
Text: eign affairs about our policy towards· the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union. Is it the case, as alleged by

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow Minister, that our policies to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards the Soviet Union have been influenced

Speaker: NA
Text: in any way by the alleged clandestine activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of Mr Valery Zemskov?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I am indebted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for this question. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: well established practice, not only under this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government but under all preceding govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, that the Government does not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on security and intelligence matters,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I do not intend to depart from that

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. Within that constraint there are,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, some aspects of the allegations

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the shadow Minister for foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs on which I am able to comment and

Speaker: NA
Text: which should not be allowed to pass without

Speaker: NA
Text: comment. The allegations made in the media

Speaker: NA
Text: release of 3 March by the shadow Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: are amongst the most shabby, despicable and

Speaker: NA
Text: unsubstantiated to have come from the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position in recent memory. In particular, they

Speaker: NA
Text: represent a grossly unfair attack upon a par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular Australian official who has served and

Speaker: NA
Text: continued to serve his country with diligence

Speaker: NA
Text: and with dedication. The unambiguous pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: to port of the shadow Minister's media release

Speaker: NA
Text: is that there was a sinister relationship be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween Mr Hayden's former principal private

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary, who is now an acting deputy sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retary in the Department of Foreign Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: and Trade, Mr Michael Costello, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet official.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: Do I have to sit here and

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to this man misrepresent me? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister is misrepresenting what I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-If the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter is misrepresenting anyone the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will have a chance by way of per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal explanation to reply.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: I rise on a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker. Under our Standing Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not in order for one member, be he the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister or anyone else, to make· any

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of an inference against another member

Speaker: NA
Text: unless on a substantive motion. The sugges-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion just made by the Prime Minister that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was something sinister in a press

Speaker: NA
Text: lease suggests that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: for North Sydney had entirely improper mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives. I would put it to you, Madam Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the nature of that response by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is entirely out of the bounds of our

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Orders and I suggest he either withDepartment

Speaker: NA
Text: draw the remark or rephrase his answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The Prime Minister that

Speaker: NA
Text: will take note of the standing order which

Speaker: NA
Text: states one should not impute improper

Speaker: NA
Text: tives to any member of this House.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I repeat that the unambigreasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: uous purport of the shadow Minister's media

Speaker: NA
Text: release is that there was a sinister relationthat

Speaker: NA
Text: ship between Mr Hayden's former principal

Speaker: NA
Text: private secretary--

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker. To be more specific on the It

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier point of order, I would suggest that Zemskov

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister's use of the word 'sinisSoviet

Speaker: NA
Text: ter' to describe motives of any member of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House is entirely improper and I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that the remark be withdrawn.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: I rise to speak to that point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order, Madam Speaker. We have all

Speaker: NA
Text: in Question Time here over many years now.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the cut and thrust of Question Time, story

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously both in questions that are asked of anything

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government and in answers that

Speaker: NA
Text: given, there is a reasonable degree of lati-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude. There is no suggestion in anything

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister has said that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: some way impugning the propriety of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member opposite. The suggestion

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is something particularly sinister

Speaker: NA
Text: about a relationship does not go to any beconclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: haviour of the honourable gentleman oppoa

Speaker: NA
Text: site. It is a perfectly reasonable statement

Speaker: NA
Text: the context of an answer to a parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The Chair accepts

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement but again tells the Prime Minments

Speaker: NA
Text: ister to ensure that he does not in any way

Speaker: NA
Text: impugn the motives of any member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Madam Speaker, there was and

Speaker: NA
Text: not the slightest foundation given in

Speaker: NA
Text: statement by the shadow Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: serious attack that has been made on a senHouse

Speaker: NA
Text: ior Australian career diplomat. In making

Speaker: NA
Text: the allegation the shadow Minister refers

Speaker: NA
Text: reto a Canberra Times report on 5 February.

Speaker: NA
Text: member His press release says:

Speaker: NA
Text: It may also be a cause for particularly grave

Speaker: NA
Text: concern that according to the Canberra Times of 5

Speaker: NA
Text: February, 1989, Zemskov developed a close relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship with Mr Hayden's former Principal Private Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retary who is now a Deputy Secretary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: of Foreign Affairs and Trade . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the only support he has in making

Speaker: NA
Text: allegation. He suggests that the relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship between the Australian official and

Speaker: NA
Text: moZemskov is a cause for particularly grave

Speaker: NA
Text: concern. I ask you, Madam Speaker, and all

Speaker: NA
Text: members of this House to note

Speaker: NA
Text: that the shadow Minister neglected to say

Speaker: NA
Text: the very same report in the Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: Times from which he was quoting says:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... there was never any suggestion of impropriety.

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order, The report says:

Speaker: NA
Text: was natural enough that Mr Costello should know

Speaker: NA
Text: in view of his professional responsibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Department for Australia's relations with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is from the report of the Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: Times. But it becomes worse when we con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider the fact that on the following day the

Speaker: NA
Text: same paper printed a piece headed 'Zem-

Speaker: NA
Text: been skov: Clarification', which said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Canberra Times reiterates that its original

Speaker: NA
Text: did not suggest Mr Costello's conduct was

Speaker: NA
Text: but appropriate, professional and necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: are to the execution of his duties.

Speaker: NA
Text: that The honourable member having based his

Speaker: NA
Text: in allegations on the newspaper's report but

Speaker: NA
Text: neglecting, obviously deliberately, even to

Speaker: NA
Text: mention these clear and unequivocal state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments by the Canberra Times, I believe the

Speaker: NA
Text: is unavoidable that there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: malicious and unfounded attack upon an

Speaker: NA
Text: in individual. It is an exercise in MCCarthyism

Speaker: NA
Text: which is to the immense discredit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Minister and the entire Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow Minister compounds his mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: take by going on to suggest that develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia's relations with the Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Union, in particular the conclusion of a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sular agreement, can be traced to the alleg-

Speaker: NA
Text: edly sinister relationship between Zemskov

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian official. That is preposter-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ous. Moreover, the shadow Minister mayor

Speaker: NA
Text: may not be interested, but I am sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: will, to know that the Australian Se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity Intelligence Organisation had no diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: only culties from its perspective with the

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion of that agreement and was thor-

Speaker: NA
Text: oughly involved in the interdepartmental

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me say in conclusion that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment totally rejects the allegations which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made. I say here on the floor of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that we affirm without qualifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion our complete confidence in the loyalty

Speaker: NA
Text: and integrity of Mr Costello. Mr Costello

Speaker: NA
Text: emerges with his very substantial standing

Speaker: NA
Text: and reputation for competence and integrity

Speaker: NA
Text: untarnished, and, if it is possible-and

Speaker: NA
Text: it-the shadow Minister emerges from this

Speaker: NA
Text: disgraceful episode even more an object of

Speaker: NA
Text: contempt than he was before.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOVIET DIPLOMAT

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: My question is addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. In view of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Prime Minister has now gone behind

Speaker: NA
Text: the screen to tell us what the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Intelligence Organisation thinks, will

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister tell us why, after ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: had advised his Government and his Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister on the day before Mr Zemskov left

Speaker: NA
Text: Moscow that he had been identified by MI5

Speaker: NA
Text: as a Soviet agent and a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: special reserve, that same individual was al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowed to come to this country and remain in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country for three years when it was

Speaker: NA
Text: known that he was a Soviet spy?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I am certainly aware of

Speaker: NA
Text: the media reports and the reports to which

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable gentleman refers. I will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: peat what I said at the outset of my previous

Speaker: NA
Text: answer, that, in accordance with practice-

Speaker: NA
Text: not merely the practice of this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: but a longstanding practice of successive

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments-the Government will not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in detail on reports relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: intelligence and security matters. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: intend to breach that principle that was fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowed by the coalition Government when it

Speaker: NA
Text: was in office and by successive governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can assure honourable members that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government obviously takes very seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed its responsibilities in the area

Speaker: NA
Text: tional security and will continue to do so.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: I seek leave to table a doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ument marked 'Cabinet in Confidence' and

Speaker: NA
Text: , 'Secret', two pages, directed to Mr Hayden

Speaker: NA
Text: from . Mr A. D. Campbell, Deputy Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Department, dated II March 1986. It

Speaker: NA
Text: sets out in detail the matters to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: referred. That will allow the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to refresh his memory.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave not granted.

Speaker: NA
Text: PUBLIC SECTOR BORROWING

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Text: My question is addressed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the

Speaker: NA
Text: House what role reduced public sector bor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rowing is playing in combating Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: balance of payments difficulties? Further-

Speaker: NA
Text: more, what evidence is there of support for

Speaker: NA
Text: I doubt this approach?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The reduction in the

Speaker: NA
Text: public sector borrowing requirement from

Speaker: NA
Text: the 7 per cent of gross domestic product

Speaker: NA
Text: which existed when this Government came

Speaker: NA
Text: to office to this year's zero figure in prospect

Speaker: NA
Text: is a central part of the economic policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government arrayed against Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: economic problems, particularly the current

Speaker: NA
Text: account deficit-that is, to free up savings

Speaker: NA
Text: within Australia by a program of public sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor dis-saving to allow those funds to go

Speaker: NA
Text: where Australia needs them most, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is investment in the import-competing and

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting sectors. As I have said in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: before, we are now presiding over the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: investment phase since records were first

Speaker: NA
Text: kept, which was 1948.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other part of the question asks

Speaker: NA
Text: whether there is political support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's policy approach. We have bi-

Speaker: NA
Text: partisan support because today we discov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered that the shadow Treasurer has endorsed

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's fiscal policy. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: promised that a Federal coalition govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: gov- ment would aim to have a sufficient Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus after tax cuts to offset all Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth and State borrowings; that is, he is

Speaker: NA
Text: arguing for, and promising, under a coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government, a zero public sector borrowing

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement. That is what we will have in

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect this financial year-a zero one for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time in 35 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me contrast that statement with the

Speaker: NA
Text: of na- high drama of a week ago. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to come into the House and give

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government a torrid time. There was a

Speaker: NA
Text: censure motion moved against the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. The essence of the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: argument was that this Government had not

Speaker: NA
Text: adjusted policy sufficiently to meet Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia's balance of payments problem. On page

Speaker: NA
Text: 24 of Hansard of 28 February the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer said in the debate:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has given up on fiscal policy-

Speaker: NA
Text: so that is out of the way. It will not act on that,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will.

Speaker: NA
Text: I emphasise the words 'but we will'. The

Speaker: NA
Text: next day he asked a question of me. He

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to an address I gave to the Eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic Planning Advisory Council in which I

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We will not hesitate to adjust policy

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: In view of that undertaking, why has the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer failed to adjust economic policy?

Speaker: NA
Text: On Tuesday he said that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would adjust policy; he then by inference

Speaker: NA
Text: asked me why we had not adjusted policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: After all of that he comes out and says that

Speaker: NA
Text: basically it is all bets off; the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: endorses the Government's fiscal policy. He

Speaker: NA
Text: endorses the Government's fiscal policy. In

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, we find out a week later, after

Speaker: NA
Text: all this hubbub, that the Opposition's fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: policy objective will be exactly the same as

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the Government. All the high drama

Speaker: NA
Text: and contrived urgency have evaporated and

Speaker: NA
Text: we have the shadow Treasurer endorsing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's fiscal policy. He is laughing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does he deny it? He goes on to say this--

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of order. Regrettably, the Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Orders do not permit a response at this point,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the Treasurer has asked a question. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will simply say that I am foreshadowing,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Standing Orders, that--

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member does not have a point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: He will resume his seat. He does not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the call; he does not have a standing order.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. In circumstances in which a

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is basing an answer on an edited

Speaker: NA
Text: transcript, it is possible, at the end of Ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Time, to set him correct, is it not?

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-I will put the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member on my list for personal

Speaker: NA
Text: explanations.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I will be interested to see

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member deny Mr Hadler's

Speaker: NA
Text: story, if that is what he proposes to do. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact of the matter is that the Opposition, in

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of the most important policy, is

Speaker: NA
Text: advocating no alternative policy strategy to

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the Government. That is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: interview means. That is what the claim

Speaker: NA
Text: but means. The Opposition says it will tighten

Speaker: NA
Text: fiscal policy, cut outlays, do all of these

Speaker: NA
Text: things, but when pressed it endorses Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment policy. HonQurable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: have such a great policy plank that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: actually endorsing the Government's basic

Speaker: NA
Text: economic strategy. They are hoping to pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent themselves as an alternative at the next

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign but their shadow Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer has committed them to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's economic policy. Apparently, by

Speaker: NA
Text: implication from the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party of Australia, we will have the device

Speaker: NA
Text: often employed by the coalition of denying

Speaker: NA
Text: its words and denying journalists' stories. We

Speaker: NA
Text: will see where it stands.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said last week and I will say it again: it

Speaker: NA
Text: is time that the shadow Treasurer appeared

Speaker: NA
Text: at a press conference to be questioned on

Speaker: NA
Text: these issues. It is not simply for the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, my colleagues and me to appear-

Speaker: NA
Text: good news or bad-at press conferences. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition should appear at press confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences. Despite all the huffing and puffing, we

Speaker: NA
Text: find now that the shadow Treasurer in the

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative government endorses as his policy

Speaker: NA
Text: the policies of the existing government.

Speaker: NA
Text: HEALTH FUNDS

Speaker: Mr SHACK
Text: My question to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Community Services and Health is based

Speaker: NA
Text: on a page 1 story appearing in today's Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne Herald headed 'Health Funds Facing

Speaker: NA
Text: Giant Losses'. I quote briefly a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraphs. The article states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health Dr Blewett has called an emer-

Speaker: NA
Text: gency meeting with HBA Health Insurance to discuss

Speaker: NA
Text: the company's ability to meet its financial

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further on, it states:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Tomorrow we'll be asking HBA for a detailed game

Speaker: NA
Text: plan on how they're going to improve their situation'

Speaker: NA
Text: a spokesman for Dr Blewett said today. 'The Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter has been watching HBA and several other com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies closely because they've dropped below the

Speaker: NA
Text: two months of reserves required by law'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the Minister stand by the comments

Speaker: NA
Text: attributed to his spokesman? Why did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister not answer the question I put to

Speaker: NA
Text: him last Thursday when I asked, in part,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he would advise the House whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not all health funds are currently meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: the statutory reserve requirement? Finally,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the light of the story, I now ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister again: how many funds are operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing below the two-month reserve provision;

Speaker: NA
Text: how many are continuing to operate under

Speaker: NA
Text: the exemptions from this provision; and for

Speaker: NA
Text: how long have they been doing so?

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: I would have hoped that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the interests of the private health funds

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves, this issue would not have been

Speaker: NA
Text: canvassed in the rather irresponsible way it

Speaker: NA
Text: has been both in the press and in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: First of all, let me explain to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Tangney the operation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: two-month rule which he has referred to.

Speaker: NA
Text: My Department is responsible under the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Health Act to monitor the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of these funds. The Act requires

Speaker: NA
Text: that health funds maintain reserves equal to

Speaker: NA
Text: two months of break-even contribution in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come., Where a fund cannot comply with

Speaker: NA
Text: this requirement at any time, there is provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion for an exemption to be granted, and

Speaker: NA
Text: such an exemption is granted under con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trolled conditions and where demonstrable

Speaker: NA
Text: corrective action is being taken. Let me point

Speaker: NA
Text: out that the two-month period is simply a

Speaker: NA
Text: guideline and is used as a guideline to mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: itor funds where there may be some prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem. Indeed, large funds can vary aro!lnd

Speaker: NA
Text: that guideline without any serious financial

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties, as they do not face the same

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of concern about sudden heavy draw-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing as do the small funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been, as I say, some irrespons-­

Speaker: NA
Text: ble speculation about one particular fund,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we have been having discussions with

Speaker: NA
Text: that fund. However, I am advised that that

Speaker: NA
Text: fund certainly has sufficient reserves to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: any claims on it by contributors. So contrib-

Speaker: NA
Text: utors need not be alarmed by some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sensationalist reporting that has taken place.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I say, this issue has been sensationalised

Speaker: NA
Text: in a, way that is not in the interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: private health funds themselves. Let me say

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is no emergency meeting, as was

Speaker: NA
Text: claimed today,in the Melbourne Herald. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is part of ongoing discussions that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been having with this fund. All I say at this

Speaker: NA
Text: stage is what I said the other day in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House: I give the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Tangney the assurance that this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will ensure that the contributors of any fund

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be put at risk.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL POLICY DEVELOPMENT

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Is the Minister for So-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial Security aware of the Australian Insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute of Family Studies report entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: Families and Tax in 1989? Can the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House of the relevance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: report to social policy development?

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: The report is a theoretical

Speaker: NA
Text: study of the effects of the tax transfer sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem; that is, the interaction of tax on the

Speaker: NA
Text: social security system. I think it is important

Speaker: NA
Text: to make the point that the analysis is no

Speaker: NA
Text: more than that. The report makes it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is referring to hypothetical couples

Speaker: NA
Text: earning around average weekly earnings

Speaker: NA
Text: (AWE). It is important, when one is discuss-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing income distribution and income transfers,

Speaker: NA
Text: to take account of social wage measures that

Speaker: NA
Text: are not taken into account in the Institute's

Speaker: NA
Text: document, for example, the impact of Med-

Speaker: NA
Text: icare. If a family has children, clearly it

Speaker: NA
Text: needs health insurance. Medicare is worth

Speaker: NA
Text: about $21 a week for a family earning around

Speaker: NA
Text: AWE. In relation to superannuation, this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, with the Australian Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Unions, has made superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: widely available to ordinary families. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: the 3 per cent arrangements that is worth

Speaker: NA
Text: $14.40 a week for an AWE family. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: area of education, we do not need to refer

Speaker: NA
Text: only to the increase in the retention rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: from 35 to 65 per cent, under this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-nea-ly 30 per cent more are staying

Speaker: NA
Text: to year 12-but more precisely, an AWE

Speaker: NA
Text: family with one year 11 student and two

Speaker: NA
Text: younger children will receive about $32 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week from Austudy.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, taking just those three social wage

Speaker: NA
Text: measures together and comparing them with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Institute of Family Studies alleged tax

Speaker: NA
Text: loss, we are talking about a gain of $67 or

Speaker: NA
Text: its equivalent, compared with the alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: AIFS tax loss of $27 to $34 a week. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: it is important to say that social policy is not

Speaker: NA
Text: built, and will never be constructed, on hy-

Speaker: NA
Text: pothetical examples. One of the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Opposition's preoccupation with

Speaker: NA
Text: what it calls the typical family-that is, a

Speaker: NA
Text: single income couple with two children-is

Speaker: NA
Text: that that so-called typical family represents

Speaker: NA
Text: something like 7 per cent of all income units.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, rather than being typical

Speaker: NA
Text: over the whole distribution, it is in fact quite

Speaker: NA
Text: atypical. The Institute of Family Studies sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports and indeed indicates the quite signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant gains that have been made with respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to low income families. For example, it talks

Speaker: NA
Text: about a couple with two children aged less

Speaker: NA
Text: than 13 years on half AWE, which is in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: $18 a week, being better off in tax terms

Speaker: NA
Text: than it would have been under the 1976-77

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we see the announcement of policy

Speaker: NA
Text: by an important group such as the Institute

Speaker: NA
Text: of Family Studies-it is an important study-

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not long before the Opposition jumps

Speaker: NA
Text: on to the bandwagon. Mr Howard, who has

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently been quite sceptical about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Institute, said he thought its work was valu-

Speaker: NA
Text: able and he was not sceptical any more. That

Speaker: NA
Text: reminded me that there was some scepticism

Speaker: NA
Text: on the part of the Government at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: of the last election, when a policy was re-

Speaker: NA
Text: leased by the Opposition which purported to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver massive gains to middle income fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ilies. I think it would not be untrue to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that those gains were described as massive.

Speaker: NA
Text: But as the debate unfolded, as the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment gave consideration to the detail of that

Speaker: NA
Text: policy and took it away from being a hypo-

Speaker: NA
Text: thetical policy, into a policy which would

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be costed and presented to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people as real, there was found to be

Speaker: NA
Text: some double counting of the order of $1 t

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. Before the Opposition jumps on to

Speaker: NA
Text: the bandwagon with this document and

Speaker: NA
Text: adopts it as policy and says, 'That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: we are going to throw up at the next elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion--

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Madam Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. I refer you to your own point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order which you raised on 9 September

Speaker: NA
Text: 1981, when you said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I draw your

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the Hansard of 27 August. You ruled,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'The Minister will answer the question and not en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gage in irrelevancies, such as contrasting the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the Labor Party'.

Speaker: NA
Text: If this Minister were as generous with his

Speaker: NA
Text: money as he is with his words, no-one would

Speaker: NA
Text: be living in poverty. He has been going for

Speaker: NA
Text: five minutes and he should cease.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member has raised his point of order. I

Speaker: NA
Text: call the Minister for Social Security in

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: Let me come very much to

Speaker: NA
Text: the point. No doubt the proposal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Institute of Family Studies is very attractive

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Opposition, a concept so attractive

Speaker: NA
Text: that no longer is the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion sceptical. In fact the AIFS was out in

Speaker: NA
Text: its costing by more than $1 billion, so that

Speaker: NA
Text: what was presented as a $5.6 billion proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: was in fact a $6.6 -illion proposal.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude by saying that it may occur to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition-there was some reference to

Speaker: NA
Text: this in the Australian Financial Review this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning-that perhaps we can go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: election without all the agony of costing,

Speaker: NA
Text: without the calculations of the replacement

Speaker: NA
Text: for the honourable member for Mackellar;

Speaker: NA
Text: that we could go on attitudes. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment does not operate on the basis of atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tudes. We operate on the basis of producing

Speaker: NA
Text: policies which are fair for families. I refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole cross-section of families. Secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: we operate on the basis of policies which

Speaker: NA
Text: give greater opportunities, particularly to low

Speaker: NA
Text: income families and--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Rocher-I take a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker. The terms of your ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: were that the Minister should conclude. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: taking him an inordinately long time to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so. I think you will agree that it is unreason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able and that he should be asked to sit down.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: been asked to conclude his remarks. I now

Speaker: NA
Text: draw his attention to the request from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chair.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: I conclude by saying that,

Speaker: NA
Text: secondly, our policies are about giving to low

Speaker: NA
Text: income families-who were excluded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: failed policies of the Opposition-a leg-up

Speaker: NA
Text: and an opportunity to get back into the

Speaker: NA
Text: mainstream. Finally, unlike the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: family reforms of 1976-which, despite what

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Chaney says, proved to be unsus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainable-the reforms that we bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: for families will prove to be sustainable and

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible fiscally, and, frankly, we cost

Speaker: NA
Text: them accurately.

Speaker: NA
Text: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT

Speaker: NA
Text: ISLANDER COMMISSION

Speaker: Mr MILES
Text: I direct my question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and refer him

Speaker: NA
Text: to his statement to the House of 21 Decem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber 1988 in relation to his meeting with State

Speaker: NA
Text: and Territory Aboriginal affairs Ministers the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous month that:

Speaker: NA
Text: . for the first time at any of these meetings,

Speaker: NA
Text: we had unanimous decisions between the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth and the States on every issue raised there.

Speaker: NA
Text: How does the Minister reconcile his state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the Parliament with the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the minutes of the meeting of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Affairs Council to which he re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred clearly showed that the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Community Services, Mr Bob

Speaker: NA
Text: Katter, made clear the Queensland Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's implacable opposition to the Aborig-

Speaker: NA
Text: inal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill? Furthermore, is it not a fact that a

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal to hold a summit on the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: was opposed by the majority of the Council

Speaker: NA
Text: members from the States and Northern Ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ritory? In light of these facts, how does the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister explain misleading the House on 21

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1988?

Speaker: Mr HAND
Text: Firstly, the minutes referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to, and which have been agreed to by all

Speaker: NA
Text: State Ministers present at the most recent

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting, are draft minutes. Secondly, there

Speaker: NA
Text: was a decision taken in terms of the Aborig-

Speaker: NA
Text: inal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: (ATSIC) which was a unanimous decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition has already been asked

Speaker: NA
Text: twice to cease interjecting.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Text: That decision on ATSIC was

Speaker: NA
Text: that I would agree to communicate with all

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers of the various States to make ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements for a briefing on ATSIC by de-

Speaker: NA
Text: partmental officers and I would agree to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet with the Ministers prior to the intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of the legislation. Interestingly

Speaker: NA
Text: enough, from memory, only one Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: responded .to that- Mr Katter certainly did-

Speaker: NA
Text: and he sought a day long meeting with me

Speaker: NA
Text: to discuss his concerns about ATSIC. Fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing that, a further meeting was held here

Speaker: NA
Text: in Canberra to discuss the findings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Deaths in Custody, at which a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: the States requested that a meeting be held

Speaker: NA
Text: of State Ministers and me prior to the intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of the legislation into the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was agreed to by me and arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: for that meeting are currently being made.

Speaker: NA
Text: The difficulty we are having is in getting all

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ministers available on the one day. But

Speaker: NA
Text: the meeting certainly will be held. I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: recall the second part of the question, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: will take it on notice and provide a response.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Miles-The second part of the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion related to the tied vote.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Text: There was a tied vote.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore the vote lapsed. There was a

Speaker: NA
Text: unanimous decision that I would write to

Speaker: NA
Text: them and I would communicate with them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore it was unanimous.

Speaker: NA
Text: WHEAT MARKETING

Speaker: NA
Text: ARRANGEMENTS

Speaker: Mr COURTICE
Text: My question is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Primary Industries and

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy. Can the Minister advise the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of the reasons ,for the Government's pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed changes to wheat marketing arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and whether the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: change its proposals in response to the ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: guments being raised by the Opposition?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member, particularly for asking for the rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons for the Government's policy. It may be

Speaker: NA
Text: instructive to the Opposition. Let us just go

Speaker: NA
Text: through them. The first reason is to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Wheat Board to have enough

Speaker: NA
Text: power to catalyse changes in storage, trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port and handling, to give farmers cost sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings off-farm on an ongoing basis. The second

Speaker: NA
Text: reason is to allow the Australian Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Board to be more effectively involved com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercially in domestic trading, thus allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: it to compete with private firms and traders

Speaker: NA
Text: under the permit system. Since the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has announced this policy a lot of good

Speaker: NA
Text: things have been happening and there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of change under way in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: grain sector. For example, the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has come out with a Green

Speaker: NA
Text: Paper that virtually duplicates what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth is trying to do, but of course

Speaker: NA
Text: it wants to lock up Queensland as a State as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as wheat is concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The New South Wales Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: been doing the right thing in respect of its

Speaker: NA
Text: Grain Handling Authority. The Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been able to negotiate a

Speaker: NA
Text: lower freight rate for the Australian Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Board this year. The cotton industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland is moving to a private approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to the marketing of cotton, away from boards.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Queensland Barley Board is moving to

Speaker: NA
Text: a permit system. There is a court case under

Speaker: NA
Text: way on section 92 with respect to State grain

Speaker: NA
Text: boards. A lot is happening, but the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion cannot see that. It fought the status quo

Speaker: NA
Text: last time at the behest of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheatgrowers Federation; now it wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: fight the status quo this time, five years on.

Speaker: NA
Text: All that we are proposing is a little bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Wool Corporation has been doing

Speaker: NA
Text: very successfully since 1974.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at some of the other reasons.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also want to place the Australian Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Board in a position to trade in other grains

Speaker: NA
Text: so that it can assist some of the smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: industries and get away from the nonsense

Speaker: NA
Text: of many of the small State grain marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: boards when it is sensible to do so. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the growers of grain legumes can

Speaker: NA
Text: assemble small cargoes but not large cargoes,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we are producing more grain legumes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another reason is to prepare the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheat Board to be more pro-active in inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national grain marketing. The fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: because of restrictions on the Wheat Board

Speaker: NA
Text: we have missed many opportunities in inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national markets over the years. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: reason is that we want to prepare the grains

Speaker: NA
Text: industry for the mental leap from the wheat-

Speaker: NA
Text: sheep belt to a growing livestock-grain sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor, and that is happening. Another reason

Speaker: NA
Text: is that we want to allow the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: additional export industries, such as starch

Speaker: NA
Text: export and food manufacturing, thereby ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: panding wheat production in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also want to institute general effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency gains for the cropping sector by not

Speaker: NA
Text: overencouraging one grain at the expense of

Speaker: NA
Text: others. There are other reasons, and of course

Speaker: NA
Text: all this is opposed by many honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers opposite-mainly because the Grains

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Australia is opposed and that

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation is split, Liberal versus National.

Speaker: NA
Text: To do these things, because of the reasons I

Speaker: NA
Text: have just set out to the House, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to retain the Board's export monop-

Speaker: NA
Text: oly on milling and industrial wheat, to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: move the sunset clause so that any future

Speaker: NA
Text: John Elliott Liberal government-Roger

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipton should resign in about 2016-or any

Speaker: NA
Text: future government will need an Act of Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament to remove that monopoly; to make

Speaker: NA
Text: the Board more commercial, particularly al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing it to trade in cash on the domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: market, including in competition with pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate traders; and to align the underwriting

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement more closely with market sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nals while maintaining high first advances to

Speaker: NA
Text: growers.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result of these changes growers will,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the first time, have an effective choice in

Speaker: NA
Text: who they sell their wheat to. They can sell

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Board's pools, they can sell to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Board's cash trading arm or they can sell to

Speaker: NA
Text: private traders. At present the Board has

Speaker: NA
Text: been effectively restricted from doing that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear a lot about competition, deregula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and choice from honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: on the other side, but in this new competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: environment all market participants-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Board, the transport and handling authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: and the private traders-will need to max-

Speaker: NA
Text: imise their efficiency. They will need to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: charges to growers as low as possible or they

Speaker: NA
Text: will simply not get any grain.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why these changes will benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: growers. Their costs will be lower. This sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing will more than outweigh the small effect

Speaker: NA
Text: on domestic prices as domestic prices more

Speaker: NA
Text: accurately reflect market developments and

Speaker: NA
Text: market realities. But none of this impresses

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party members. They have no pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy formation machinery; they just wander

Speaker: NA
Text: around the landscape, agreeing to whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: case is put to them by the farmers. Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: MCGauran has lied not only about the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's intentions but also about the po-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition of those in the Liberal Party who

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise--

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The Minister will

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw that comment.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: I withdraw. Senator Mc-

Speaker: NA
Text: Gauran has misrepresented the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's intentions and also the position of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party, which recognises the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: what we are doing. Of course, he has re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived no reprimand from his leader.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition has grandly

Speaker: NA
Text: announced that the coalition will vote the

Speaker: NA
Text: same way on the issue. But which way will

Speaker: NA
Text: that be? Will the National Party once again

Speaker: NA
Text: kick the Liberal Party off its favoured turf

Speaker: NA
Text: of protecting the agricultural status quo?

Speaker: NA
Text: Every time that the Liberals-who, I might

Speaker: NA
Text: add, have as many members in this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment representing rural seats as the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, although not as many as the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party-try to influence rural policy, they

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the most vehement reaction from the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party. It goes back decades. Mc-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ewen blackballed MCMahon because he ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually had the gall to face up to what was

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong with National Party policies. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken the Liberals 20 years even to begin to

Speaker: NA
Text: contemplate shrugging off the legacy of that

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of blackmail at that time. Once again

Speaker: NA
Text: we are facing the political blackmail of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party. The National Party is cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rupt and undemocratic in Queensland; it

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot help itself in northern New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales; it is brawling in Victoria and Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; but there is hope for it, as it

Speaker: NA
Text: received 1.6 per cent of the vote in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory election and Joh

Speaker: NA
Text: is to lead Grey Power. That is the record of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Nationals. Let me spell it out clearly to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition: the Government's proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: will benefit wheat growers. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to make up its mind during the

Speaker: NA
Text: first half of this year. We will not give it an

Speaker: NA
Text: extra 12 months to sort out its own splits,

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresentations and nonsense.

Text: Swan-Leader of the

Text: House)-Papers are tabled as listed in the

Text: schedule circulated to honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: port 1987-88-including the Auditor-General's Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port-section 38 of the National Museum of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1980 and section 63M of the Audit Act 1901.

Speaker: NA
Text: The working of the protection of movable cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Heritage Act 1986 and the administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Cultural Heritage fund-Annual Report

Speaker: NA
Text: 1987-88-including the Auditor-General's Report-

Speaker: NA
Text: section 47 of the Protection of Movable Cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Heritage Act 1986.

Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: North Sydney)-Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member may proceed.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: This afternoon the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Hawke), in answer to a pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared question, made an attack on me. I

Speaker: NA
Text: could not hear everything that he said but,

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst other things, he said that I had

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in a serious attack-I believe those

Speaker: NA
Text: were his words-on Mr Costello; that I had

Speaker: NA
Text: been grossly unfair; that I had imputed a

Speaker: NA
Text: sinister relationship. Quite simply, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense. I have not questioned the personal

Speaker: NA
Text: propriety, motives or general professionalism

Speaker: NA
Text: of that gentleman. I have questioned, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: question most profoundly, any kind of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: official relationship between any senior offi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial in the Department of Foreign Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: and Trade or, indeed, any other department,

Speaker: NA
Text: and a known KGB spy who, due to the

Speaker: NA
Text: lunatic policies of this Government, is al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowed to come here and stay here for three

Speaker: NA
Text: years--

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: I raise a point of order. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member has gone outside the

Speaker: NA
Text: framework of personal explanations. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: debating the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member has shown the House where he has

Speaker: NA
Text: been misrepresented. He will not move out-

Speaker: NA
Text: side the ambit.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member may proceed.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) during Ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Time today in which he alluded to a

Speaker: NA
Text: very interesting article written in today's

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian by Mr Robert Hadler, a gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man for whom I have great respect and who,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the interview, kindly provided me

Speaker: NA
Text: with a copy of his reporter's transcript. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the nature of many reporters' transcripts, the

Speaker: NA
Text: transcript, which I have in my office, is not

Text: held out to be full and detailed. Mr Hadler's

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: A. That would be our aim, as it is the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's aim. But in fact the Government on the very

Text: figures I've given you . . . will not be able to

Text: achieve their aim, they won't be able to do it.

Speaker: NA
Text: There the answer in the reporter's edited

Speaker: NA
Text: transcript ends. The full transcript goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: I mean, just to take into account the figures I've

Speaker: NA
Text: given you, puts them in position where their aim,

Speaker: NA
Text: that Keating constantly talks about and practice can

Speaker: NA
Text: point to will be destroyed and .we will. be in a -etter

Speaker: NA
Text: position because we are addressIng pubhc expendIture.

Speaker: NA
Text: So much for bipartisanship on fiscal policy

Speaker: NA
Text: because there are as you would know,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker, different components in

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving any form of public sector borrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing requirements, taxes, borrowing and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure. I addressed public expenditure and

Speaker: NA
Text: have indicated clearly that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: could not.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Blaxland-Treasurer)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Does the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Yes, I do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I would never have at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempted to misrepresent the Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: portant matter. Let me refer to the quote he

Speaker: NA
Text: refers to. The question is:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . would you still aim to have a sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus to produce a net, a zero net PSBR?

Speaker: NA
Text: Answer:

Speaker: NA
Text: That would be our aim.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is, it would be the Opposition's aim to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a zero net public sector borrowing re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirement. He goes on to say--

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: On a point of order, Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. The Treasurer is now arguing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member will resume his seat. The Chair

Speaker: NA
Text: is hearing a personal explanation from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: That is right and I am on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Go ahead.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: My point of order is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer is now commencing to debate his

Speaker: NA
Text: personal explanation, and he should be told

Speaker: NA
Text: to stop.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The Chair has given

Speaker: NA
Text: a certain latitude to both sides of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: on this matter. It is sometimes very difficult,

Speaker: NA
Text: as I have pointed out before, when honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members are quoting from a newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: or when they are rebutting a point, to be as

Speaker: NA
Text: succinct as the Chair would like.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: On a further point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker. Just before you took the

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order from the Leader of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: and before our spokesman on foreign affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately ceased his particular remarks,

Speaker: NA
Text: the remarks that the Treasurer was making

Speaker: NA
Text: as I got to my feet had nothing to do with

Speaker: NA
Text: the press release. He then started to argue

Speaker: NA
Text: the case, and it is a pretty poor one.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will resume his seat. The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for North Sydney had indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Chair that he had completed his per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal explanation.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The transcript goes on to

Speaker: NA
Text: ." say:

Speaker: NA
Text: That would be our aim .

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Where have you been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: is suggesting that I have misrepresented the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He is sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gesting it. The transcript states:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . as it is the Government's aim. But in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government on the very figures I've given

Speaker: NA
Text: you . . . will not be able to achieve their

Speaker: NA
Text: aim . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether there is any argument about

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Government achieves it is im-

Speaker: NA
Text: material. He said, 'It is the Opposition's aim

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a zero net PSBR', which is existing

Speaker: NA
Text: Government policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: NAMIBIA

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Wills-Prime Minister)-

Speaker: NA
Text: by leave-I report to the House on recent

Speaker: NA
Text: events in Namibia and Australia's role in

Speaker: NA
Text: assisting the implementation of United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Security Council Resolution 435 of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978, providing for the withdrawal of South

Speaker: NA
Text: African military forces from Namibia and

Speaker: NA
Text: the holding of elections under United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions (UN) supervision and control. As an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced by the Minister for Defence ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 March 1989, a contingent of 300 Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian engineers will leave shortly for Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will form part of a United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping force in Namibia that will help

Speaker: NA
Text: bring independence to Namibia after more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 100 years of rule by foreign powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The settlement of the long and complex

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of Namibian independence is an impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant international event. It is an event in

Speaker: NA
Text: which Australia has played, and will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to play, a substantial part. During my

Speaker: NA
Text: recent visit to India, I noted that there had

Speaker: NA
Text: been much talk during the 1970s and early

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980s about an arc of instability stretching

Speaker: NA
Text: from southern Africa, through the Persian

Speaker: NA
Text: Gulf, through Afghanistan and South Asia

Speaker: NA
Text: and on to Indo-China. We see now, if not

Speaker: NA
Text: an arc of peace, then at least an arc of

Speaker: NA
Text: peace-making. It is a process, facilitated by

Speaker: NA
Text: an improvement in superpower relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: aided by the constructive role of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations, that is finally bringing the treasured

Speaker: NA
Text: goal of independence within sight of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: My Government recognises that the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems in southern Africa constitute one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: major challenges facing the international

Speaker: NA
Text: community. We have sought, through the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations, the Commonwealth and our

Speaker: NA
Text: own diplomatic links with countries in the

Speaker: NA
Text: region, to find peaceful solutions to the

Speaker: NA
Text: plex set of problems that trouble that region.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent times, there has been little cause

Speaker: NA
Text: for optimism in southern Africa. The offen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive doctrine of apartheid remains en-

Speaker: NA
Text: trenched in South Africa's social, political

Speaker: NA
Text: and economic life. Civil wars with drastic

Speaker: NA
Text: human consequences continue in Mozam-

Speaker: NA
Text: bique and Angola. The front line states of

Speaker: NA
Text: southern Africa-including fellow Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth members such as Botswana, Tanza-

Speaker: NA
Text: nia, Zambia and Zimbabwe-continue to be

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable to economic and military desta-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilisation. The question of Namibia, in many

Speaker: NA
Text: ways, encapsulated a number of these

Speaker: NA
Text: problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact that Namibia is now on the way

Speaker: NA
Text: to independence demonstrates that concerted

Speaker: NA
Text: international action, the determination of the

Speaker: NA
Text: region, and the goodwill of individual players

Speaker: NA
Text: can combine to bring solutions to longstand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing problems in the region. For a southern

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa torn by attrition, deprivation and

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy, recent moves on Namibia offer a

Speaker: NA
Text: glimmer of hope. The problem of Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: has been with the international community

Speaker: NA
Text: for close on 70 years. South Africa was ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed mandatory over the former German

Speaker: NA
Text: colony of South West Africa by the Treaty

Speaker: NA
Text: of Versailles in 1919, in circumstances simi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar to Australia's own mandate over Papua

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea. This mandate was confirmed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the League of Nations. After the Second

Speaker: NA
Text: World War, the League of Nations was

Speaker: NA
Text: superseded by the United Nations, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: mandate system by the trusteeship system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Alone of the former mandatory powers,

Speaker: NA
Text: South Africa refused to submit a trusteeship

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement for South West Africa, or Nami-

Speaker: NA
Text: bia, as it is now known. In 1966, the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: General Assembly resolved that South Afri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ca's role in Namibia should be terminated,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the responsibility for the territory

Speaker: NA
Text: should be assumed by a UN-appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: Council for Namibia. Despite these deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions, South Africa continued to govern Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: mibia against the wishes of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations, and claimed sovereignty over it in

Speaker: NA
Text: the face of widespread international

Speaker: NA
Text: condemnation.

Speaker: NA
Text: South African rule has been opposed from

Speaker: NA
Text: within Namibia since 1957 by the South West

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa People's Organisation, SWAPO.

Speaker: NA
Text: SWAPO commenced an armed struggle in

Speaker: NA
Text: com- 1966, and was supported in this by Nami-

Speaker: NA
Text: bia's neighboijr to the north, Angola, when

Speaker: NA
Text: it achieved independence in 1975. South Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: rica responded by supporting an insurgency

Speaker: NA
Text: against the Government of Angola, and by

Speaker: NA
Text: direct attacks against Angolan Government

Speaker: NA
Text: forces inside Angola. Angola sought Cuban

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement and as many as 50,000 Cuban

Speaker: NA
Text: troops have been deployed there at· anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: time. This involvement, with substantial So-

Speaker: NA
Text: viet backing, became a significant source of

Speaker: NA
Text: East-West tension.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has taken years to begin to untangle this

Speaker: NA
Text: mess. In 1978 the UN agreed on a plan for

Speaker: NA
Text: a settlement contained in UN Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Council Resolution 435, but intransigence on

Speaker: NA
Text: all sides prevented that plan from being im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plemented. Then last year, in the context of

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced East-West tensions, the log-jam

Speaker: NA
Text: started to break up. South Africa agreed to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw its forces and to allow Namibia its

Speaker: NA
Text: independence, while Angola agreed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal of Cuban forces and the removal

Speaker: NA
Text: of African National Congress camps from its

Speaker: NA
Text: territory. The signing of the Brazzaville

Speaker: NA
Text: tocol on 22 December last year by South

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa, Cuba and Angola has at last formal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised the acceptance by South Africa of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978 UN settlement plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last month the UN Security Council

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed that the transition to independence

Speaker: NA
Text: for Namibia would begin on 1 April 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the 12 months from that date the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: will monitor the withdrawal of foreign forces,

Speaker: NA
Text: oversee the drafting and adoption of a Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitution, and supervise the installation of a

Speaker: NA
Text: new government after general elections. A

Speaker: NA
Text: vital element in this plan is the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations Transitional Assistance Group (UN-

Speaker: NA
Text: TAG). It will monitor the ceasefire and troop

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawals, supervise elections, and support

Speaker: NA
Text: the maintenance of law and order in Nami-

Speaker: NA
Text: bia until the new government of independent

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia is ready to take over. The scale of

Speaker: NA
Text: these tasks is reflected in the size of the

Speaker: NA
Text: force. UNTAG will have civilian, police and

Speaker: NA
Text: military elements. The military element, will

Speaker: NA
Text: consist initially of 4,650 personnel, including

Speaker: NA
Text: three infantry battalions, with scope for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pansion to 7,500 should the circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: demand.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is providing the engineering

Speaker: NA
Text: component of UNTAG. Our contingent of

Speaker: NA
Text: 23 officers and 277 other ranks will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: engineering and construction support to the

Speaker: NA
Text: UN effort. Such support will be sorely

Speaker: NA
Text: needed. Namibia is a large, arid, sparsely

Speaker: NA
Text: populated and underdeveloped country which

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a war zone for many years. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: engineers will build roads, bridges, airstrips

Speaker: NA
Text: and camps for UNT AG. They will have the

Speaker: NA
Text: very serious task of clearing mines which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been laid by the various contending

Speaker: NA
Text: forces along the border between Angola and

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia. This is, of course, not the first time

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian personnel have been involved with

Speaker: NA
Text: a peacekeeping force in Africa; we partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pated in the Commonwealth force that mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: itored Zimbabwe's transition to independence

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1980. In that process, as in others before

Speaker: NA
Text: and since, Australian defence forces played

Speaker: NA
Text: a constructive role in what can be a difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: and sometimes dangerous process. Members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian contingent will serve in

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia for tours of six months, after which

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be replaced by a fresh contingent

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australia. The UN plans to complete

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia's transition to independence within

Speaker: NA
Text: Pro- a year, but delays in this complex process

Speaker: NA
Text: are possible, and we may be called upon to

Speaker: NA
Text: stay longer than a year. The bulk of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian contingent will be based at

Speaker: NA
Text: Grootfontein in the north of Namibia, near

Speaker: NA
Text: the border with Angola. Elements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent could be required to deploy into

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbouring countries to support UNT AG

Speaker: NA
Text: operations there.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very large and important com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment for Australia, comprising almost half

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Army's construction engineering ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: pability. Careful planning, including the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of reservists, has been required to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: high priority engineering tasks closer to home

Speaker: NA
Text: can still be performed. I am pleased to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has been possible to minimise the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the deployment on support to the

Speaker: NA
Text: operational deployment force, exercise Kan-

Speaker: NA
Text: garoo 89, and the defence cooperation pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram in the South Pacific, where our

Speaker: NA
Text: engineers build wharves, airstrips and other

Speaker: NA
Text: essential infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has to be understood that the political

Speaker: NA
Text: and military situation in the border region

Speaker: NA
Text: where the bulk of our men will be deployed

Speaker: NA
Text: will remain uncertain and outbreaks of fight-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing cannot be ruled out. Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian contingent will travel often on

Speaker: NA
Text: minor and remote roads. They will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for the dangerous work of clearing

Speaker: NA
Text: mines throughout the country. Threats are

Speaker: NA
Text: also posed by disease and the harsh environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Against these dangers should be set

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that our service personnel are ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perts in their profession; they are well trained

Speaker: NA
Text: and will be armed for self-defence. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: assure honourable members that the safety

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian contingent is uppermost in

Speaker: NA
Text: my mind. To ensure that we are kept fully

Speaker: NA
Text: informed of developments that may affect

Speaker: NA
Text: the well-being of the Australian contingerit,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has decided to establish a

Speaker: NA
