Text: temporary Australian Liaison Office in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibian capital of Windhoek for the du-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration of the 12-month independence pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess. The office will provide the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: with first-hand reporting on political and

Speaker: NA
Text: military developments in the territory, during

Speaker: NA
Text: what at times is likely to be a difficult pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess. The office will be headed by an expe-

Speaker: NA
Text: rienced diplomat with many years'

Speaker: NA
Text: background in African affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has also ensured that

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Australian contingent be ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: equately compensated for the hardships and

Speaker: NA
Text: dangers they will face through a comprehen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive and generous set of conditions of service,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the payment of special allowances.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) will

Speaker: NA
Text: be seeking an amendment to the Income Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Assessment Act to exempt the pay and al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowances earned by Defence Force personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: while they are on tour with UNTAG. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: patriation benefits appropriate to the tasks

Speaker: NA
Text: and hazards encountered will also be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our contribution to UNTAG and our in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volvement in the Namibian settlement makes

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia party to what may be one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations' most substantial achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for many years. We have been in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in this process from the start.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been a member of the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: Council for Namibia since 1974. We pledged

Speaker: NA
Text: our support for UNT AG at the inception of

Speaker: NA
Text: the UN plan for Namibia in 1978. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: also made an important contribution to UN

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberations about Namibia during our re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent term on the UN Security Council in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1985-86. Our participation in UNTAG also

Speaker: NA
Text: builds on the constructive role successive

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian governments have played on

Speaker: NA
Text: southern African issues. I pay particular trib-

Speaker: NA
Text: ute to the achievements of my predecessor

Speaker: NA
Text: Malcolm Fraser in this regard. Our decisive

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to the attainment of independ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence by Zimbabwe, Australia's leading role

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Commonwealth on southern Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs, and our bilaterial aid support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: member countries of the Southern African

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Coordination Conference, all

Speaker: NA
Text: speak of a firm commitment to peace and

Speaker: NA
Text: stability in that region. Our involvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Eminent Persons Group was only one

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration of our longstanding determi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation to work constructively to bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: an end to the repugnant policies of apartheid.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the Namibian settlement,

Speaker: NA
Text: together with the resolution of the Iran-Iraq

Speaker: NA
Text: war and the end of Soviet military interven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in Afghanistan, marks a renewal of faith

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United Nations as an effective partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ipant in international affairs after many years

Speaker: NA
Text: of cynicism and apathy about its role. The

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations belongs on the centre stage

Speaker: NA
Text: of world affairs, not in the wings, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: very encouraging that more and more coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries are recognising this. I take this oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to pay tribute to the efforts of Martti

Speaker: NA
Text: Ahtisaari, the United Nations Secretary-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Special Representative on Nami-

Speaker: NA
Text: bia, for his important role, and those of the

Speaker: NA
Text: late Bernt Carlsson, the UN Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: for Namibia, who was tragically killed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Lockerbie air disaster.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to think that Namibia's tTlin-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition to independence will proceed to plan

Speaker: NA
Text: and that there will be no major setbacks.·

Speaker: NA
Text: But such things are never certain. Our effort

Speaker: NA
Text: in Namibia will be the largest peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment in which this country has ever

Speaker: NA
Text: participated. It may also be the most diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cult. I am sure that all honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: of this House and the people of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: join me in wishing our troops well in their

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavours. We do so in the knowledge that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will make an outstanding contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: to the future peace and prosperity of an

Speaker: NA
Text: independent Namibian people and a more

Speaker: NA
Text: stable region. I present the following paper:

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia-Ministerial statement, 6 March 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr West) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the paper.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Bennelong-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (3.08)-The statement just made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) is, ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cording to any measure of parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: statements, a very important one because it

Speaker: NA
Text: confirms the rare event of the dispatch of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian forces overseas to undertake, on

Speaker: NA
Text: this occasion, a very difficult and a very

Speaker: NA
Text: important peacekeeping role. I say at the

Speaker: NA
Text: outset on behalf of the Opposition that we

Speaker: NA
Text: fully support the action of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: in dispatching Australian forces to be part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United Nations (UN) peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: force in Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Prime Minister properly acknowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edged, the original decision to commit Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian forces, to the number of some 300

Speaker: NA
Text: mainly engineering personnel, was taken in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978 by the former coalition Government. I

Speaker: NA
Text: join the Prime Minister in extending to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian forces that are to go overseas the

Speaker: NA
Text: very best wishes for their safety and success

Speaker: NA
Text: from all members of the Opposition. When

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian forces go overseas in the name of,

Speaker: NA
Text: and on behalf of, the Australian people, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that they know they have the

Speaker: NA
Text: total support of both sides of politics. On

Speaker: NA
Text: this occasion 1 can say unreservedly

Speaker: NA
Text: will. The Prime Minister is right to draw

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the tortured process of achieving

Speaker: NA
Text: the peace arrangement in Namibia. It is 11

Speaker: NA
Text: years since the provisional settlement was

Speaker: NA
Text: concluded. At times during that process it

Speaker: NA
Text: must have appeared to all participants that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was unlikely that that original agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: would ever be fully consummated. Undoubtplace

Speaker: NA
Text: edly the general easing of East-West tension

Speaker: NA
Text: and a greater sense of pragmatism about

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the affairs of southern Africa, from

Speaker: NA
Text: both Pretoria and the front line states,

Speaker: NA
Text: played a role in bringing about a very sensibution

Speaker: NA
Text: ble arrangement.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 share the hope of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian forces will be there only

Speaker: NA
Text: for the designated period of 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be an easy task. It has to be recogaware

Speaker: NA
Text: nised frankly on both sides of the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: that our forces can and will be exposed

Speaker: NA
Text: physical danger. 1 would say to the Governin

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that any measures introduced into this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament by the Treasurer ( Mr Keating)

Speaker: NA
Text: to exempt the pay and allowances of Austrapowers

Speaker: NA
Text: lian forces from income tax will be fully

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by the Opposition. We will also

Speaker: NA
Text: be looking for the repatriation benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: provided appropriate to the task and the

Speaker: NA
Text: hazards encountered. There is no doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: this very large and important commitment,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Prime Minister said, comprises almost

Speaker: NA
Text: half of the Army's construction engineering

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity, and careful planning has been reMinister

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to ensure that high priority engineerthose

Speaker: NA
Text: ing tasks closer to home can still be who

Speaker: NA
Text: performed.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 hope that the Prime Minister's assurof

Speaker: NA
Text: ances about the impact of the dispatch of

Speaker: NA
Text: this contingent on the Kangaroo 89 exercise world.

Speaker: NA
Text: are fulfilled. If they are not, that will inev-

Speaker: NA
Text: itably raise serious questions about the

Speaker: NA
Text: of defence preparedness in Australia. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: second to none in giving total support to

Speaker: NA
Text: Government for the dispatch of these forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not and will not in any way criticise

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's decision in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: But that does not prevent, in the proper

Speaker: NA
Text: arena of political debate and conflict in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, the Opposition pointing out any

Speaker: NA
Text: deleterious consequences on the capacity of

Speaker: NA
Text: the remainder of the Australian defence

Speaker: NA
Text: forces to play an effective role in other areas

Speaker: NA
Text: that they of our responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: This announcement today and the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: patch of the 300 Australian servicemen to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia for this peacekeeping role continues

Speaker: NA
Text: a long and very honourable tradition of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian service personnel serving overseas in

Speaker: NA
Text: a variety of peacekeeping and other capaci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties; and 1 welcome the fact that this takes

Speaker: NA
Text: under the auspices of the United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. 1 would have to confess to being some-

Speaker: NA
Text: what of a sceptic about many of the roles

Speaker: NA
Text: and activities of the United Nations, but 1

Speaker: NA
Text: have have never demeaned the enormous contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: that the voluntary agencies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations have made to the relief of

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering. Anybody who has visited the ref-

Speaker: NA
Text: ugee camps in the Gaza and on the border

Speaker: NA
Text: It between Thailand and Cambodia will be well

Speaker: NA
Text: of the very fine work of those agen-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies. There have been, as the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to properly points out, a number of examples

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years of which this is one, where

Speaker: NA
Text: the persistent work of the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: has brought about a rational solution. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: true that changes in attitude by the great

Speaker: NA
Text: I;lnd other participants have played a

Speaker: NA
Text: part, but 1 do not wish on this occasion to

Speaker: NA
Text: be churlish in denying the role that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: to be played by the United Nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me say again that this decision by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government fulfils the original commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: made 11 years ago by the Fraser Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It has our support and 1 join the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: in extending, in the fullest possible

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of the word, bipartisan good wishes for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian service men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: will be making a very significant contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to bringing about a greater measure

Speaker: NA
Text: security, peace and stability in what has

Speaker: NA
Text: been and remains a very troubled part of the

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Swan-Minister for Def-

Speaker: NA
Text: level ence) (3.15)-1 would like to make a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of remarks on the statement of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister ( Mr Hawke). First, 1 express our

Speaker: NA
Text: gratitude to the Opposition for its support.

Speaker: NA
Text: We did rather expect that it would be forth-

Speaker: NA
Text: that. coming and there was no surprise in that

Speaker: NA
Text: regard. Nevertheless, it is gratifying to have

Speaker: NA
Text: it. 1 want to make two general points on the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the commitment outlined by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister on the operations of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Defence Force (ADF) and some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the salient features of the tasks that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be performing.

Speaker: NA
Text: A substantial commitment has been made

Speaker: NA
Text: in terms of the impact of the operations on

Speaker: NA
Text: the section of the Army from which this

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent is drawn. A very substantial com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponent of our engineering capability is in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved. We will be able to perform this task

Speaker: NA
Text: to some degree because of the changes we

Speaker: NA
Text: placed in our policy on reservists, and I will

Speaker: NA
Text: talk a bit more about that later. But, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fullness of time, there will be a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement of some of our Army Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: people in this commitment, and that is only

Speaker: NA
Text: proper. One of the reasons that we intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced the call-out legislation relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: servists was to give the Army Reserve an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to playa role in the total Army.

Speaker: NA
Text: A second feature I draw attention to is

Speaker: NA
Text: the status that is going to be accorded the

Speaker: NA
Text: participants in relation to benefits and more

Speaker: NA
Text: will be said about that by the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Science and Personnel ( Mrs Kelly).

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to say something about the

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for that. This is a different peace-

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping operation from those with which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been associated in the past. It is on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of that difference that determinations

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made. Unlike the situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Zimbabwe, the current situation associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with the separation of forces from the Iran-

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraq war or the personnel involved in Leba-

Speaker: NA
Text: non, this will be an armed force. It will be

Speaker: NA
Text: deployed in anticipation that it may from

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time experience trouble. This is not

Speaker: NA
Text: expected, but there is that possibility and,

Speaker: NA
Text: hence, it will be a force that carries arms.

Speaker: NA
Text: will, of course, also directly confront prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems which will endanger the lives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel concerned. For example, it has as

Speaker: NA
Text: one of its tasks the clearance of minefields.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian servicemen have been serving

Speaker: NA
Text: as observers and peacekeepers continuously

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1947 in Indonesia, the Middle East,

Speaker: NA
Text: Kashmir and Zimbabwe. Today we have 28

Speaker: NA
Text: Army officers in the Middle East serving

Speaker: NA
Text: with the United Nations truce supervision

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation and with the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: largest peacekeeping commitment until now

Speaker: NA
Text: was in Zimbabwe, where about 150 Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian servicemen monitored the disengagement

Speaker: NA
Text: of opposition forces in Zimbabwe's civil war.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 303 members of our United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Transitional Assistance Group (UNTAG)

Speaker: NA
Text: deployment are, therefore, by a large margin

Speaker: NA
Text: our biggest peacekeeping effort yet, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: probably our most difficult. We certainly had

Speaker: NA
Text: plenty of notice. The Army has had engi-

Speaker: NA
Text: neers on stand-by to join UNTAG since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1979. Nonetheless, the scale of the deploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the tough conditions in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: will operate and the importance of the task

Speaker: NA
Text: all make this a challenging undertaking.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our contingent of 303 men will be made

Speaker: NA
Text: up of two main elements. The headquarters

Speaker: NA
Text: element of about 50 men-the Headquarters

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief Engineer UNT AG-will be part of

Speaker: NA
Text: UNTAG headquarters in Windhoek, the

Speaker: NA
Text: re- capital of Namibia. The main body of our

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent comes from 17 Construction

Speaker: NA
Text: Squadron, based at Holsworthy in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales. The squadron consists of two con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction troops, a resources troop, a plant

Speaker: NA
Text: troop and afield troop. As well, the squad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ron will have a full workshop unit and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications and medical support. The 17

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction Squadron and its workshop will

Speaker: NA
Text: be based at Grootfontein in northern Nami-

Speaker: NA
Text: bia, close to the Angolan border, but it may

Speaker: NA
Text: be called on to operate anywhere in Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: and perhaps in neighbouring countries. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian contingent will be commanded by

Speaker: NA
Text: Colonel Richard Warren, a highly trained

Speaker: NA
Text: and widely experienced engineer officer who

Speaker: NA
Text: had served throughout Australia and in

Speaker: NA
Text: Papua New Guinea. In Namibia he will serve

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Chief Engineer, UNT AG, as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: Commander of the Australian contingent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second in command of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent is Lieutenant-Colonel Kevin

Speaker: NA
Text: It Pippard who will serve as senior operations

Speaker: NA
Text: staff officer to Colonel Warren at UNTAG

Speaker: NA
Text: headquarters. The 17th Construction Squad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ron at Grootfontein will be commanded by

Speaker: NA
Text: a Major David Crago, whose previous post-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings have included service with the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth monitoring force in Zimbabwe in

Speaker: NA
Text: The contingent will deploy with its own

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy equipment. The main items' of equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to be shipped include 24 Land Rovers,

Speaker: NA
Text: 19 Unimog all-terrain vehicles, 26 heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: trucks, 43 trailers, 8 bulldozers and a range

Speaker: NA
Text: of other road making plant such as graders,

Speaker: NA
Text: scrapers and rollers. The supporting work-

Speaker: NA
Text: shop will require a further 40 vehicles, and

Speaker: NA
Text: over 1,800 tonnes of stores will be shipped

Speaker: NA
Text: with the contingent's equipment. The ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vance party of the contingent will leave Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia this week. The heavy equipment and

Speaker: NA
Text: stores will be loaded for transport by sea

Speaker: NA
Text: about the middle of March. The main body

Speaker: NA
Text: of the contingent is scheduled to leave on

Speaker: NA
Text: 17 March. Those members will fly to NamiIt

Speaker: NA
Text: bia by United States transport aircraft.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister has already indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that our troops will find in Namibia an un-

Speaker: NA
Text: certain political and military situation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: harsh and unforgiving terrain. In recent years,

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia has been subject to a very complex

Speaker: NA
Text: series of interconnecting conflicts. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, the South West Africa People's

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation (SWAPO) has been fighting the

Speaker: NA
Text: South African armed forces, both in Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: and from bases in neighbouring Angola and

Speaker: NA
Text: Zambia. In recent years, South Africans

Speaker: NA
Text: recruited Namibians into the South-West Afof

Speaker: NA
Text: rican Territorial (SWAT) Force to support

Speaker: NA
Text: them in fighting SWAPO.

Speaker: NA
Text: Meanwhile, events in Namibia have been

Speaker: NA
Text: heavily influenced from across the border

Speaker: NA
Text: Angola. The Angolan Government, sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported by up to 50,000 Cuban troops, have

Speaker: NA
Text: been fighting an insurgency based in the

Speaker: NA
Text: south-east of the country by the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Union for the Total Independence of Angola

Speaker: NA
Text: (UNITA). UNITA has been aided by the

Speaker: NA
Text: South African Government, while SWAPO

Speaker: NA
Text: has been aided by the Angolan Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: As an additional complication, Angola has

Speaker: NA
Text: been providing refuge and support to the

Speaker: NA
Text: African National Congress in its fight against

Speaker: NA
Text: the regime in South Africa. UNT AG has

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult and complex task in helping to

Speaker: NA
Text: tangle this complex situation. It will mdnitor

Speaker: NA
Text: the cessation of hostilities by' all parties

Speaker: NA
Text: the implementation of the transition to

Speaker: NA
Text: dependence for Namibia. UNT AG's military

Speaker: NA
Text: component will play a vital role in this

Speaker: NA
Text: process.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the UN plan a cease-fire is already

Speaker: NA
Text: in place before UNTAG's arrival. During

Speaker: NA
Text: the 12 weeks following the arrival of UNcould

Speaker: NA
Text: TAG, all but 1,500 South African troops

Speaker: NA
Text: will be withdrawn from Namibia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: remainder will be confined to camps. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time SW APO forces inside Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: will be confined to their camps, and those

Speaker: NA
Text: Angola and Zambia will be restricted to

Speaker: NA
Text: bases there. Unarmed SWAPO personnel and

Speaker: NA
Text: other Namibians outside the territory will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to return to participate in the election.

Speaker: NA
Text: The military component of UNT AG will

Speaker: NA
Text: be required to monitor, and if necessary en-

Speaker: NA
Text: in force, this complex cease-fire and disengage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It will need to keep borders under

Speaker: NA
Text: surveillance to prevent infiltration of forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: will be responsible for disarming and dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: banding citizen forces such as SWAT Force,

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that all military installations along

Speaker: NA
Text: .the northern border are deactivated or placed

Speaker: NA
Text: a under UN supervision and providing security

Speaker: NA
Text: for vital installations in the northern border

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. As well, it will be required to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: first and support the civilian component of UN-

Speaker: NA
Text: OrTAG in managing the constitutional and

Speaker: NA
Text: electoral processes, and respond to any spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial requests from the UN special represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ative to help to maintain law and order.

Speaker: NA
Text: have UNT AG's military component will consist

Speaker: NA
Text: three infantry battalions of 850 men each,

Speaker: NA
Text: 300 military observers, 1,700 logistic troops

Speaker: NA
Text: and a headquarters staff of 100, making a

Speaker: NA
Text: total of 4,650 men. Should it become appar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent that this is insufficient for the task, the

Speaker: NA
Text: in force can be expanded to 7,500.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, mobility will be fundamental to

Speaker: NA
Text: the effectiveness of UNT AG. Our contin-

Speaker: NA
Text: gent's key task will be to maintain that mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility in what will often be very difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances. Hence, the tasks envisaged

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Australian engineers in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: this force include mine clearing, maintaining

Speaker: NA
Text: roads and tracks and building and maintain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing light aircraft strips and helipads. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will also be .called upon to help with water

Speaker: NA
Text: a supplies, to construct rough camp accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: unmodation and to build field defences. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister has said, these are clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: and tasks which carry some risks. We all hope

Speaker: NA
Text: inand expect that all parties to the complex

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict in south-west Africa will abide by

Speaker: NA
Text: the terms of the Namibia settlement. With

Speaker: NA
Text: . such a large number of competing forces and

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicting interests, it is possible that trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: could break out and that UNTAG members

Speaker: NA
Text: become involved. Apart from the risk

Speaker: NA
Text: of combat, Australian forces will face danger

Speaker: NA
Text: from mine clearing and disease and from the

Speaker: NA
Text: harsh and arid climate of south-west Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: Against these dangers need to be set the

Speaker: NA
Text: in skill and professionalism of our defence

Speaker: NA
Text: their forces. UNT AG members, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian contingent, will be armed for self-

Speaker: NA
Text: defence. Our engineers are specialists in mine

Speaker: NA
Text: clearance. They have been carefully trained

Speaker: NA
Text: and equipped for this work. Every care is

Speaker: NA
Text: being taken to ensure the safety, health and

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare of our soldiers. Nonetheless, the ADF

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Government accept that there may

Speaker: NA
Text: be casualties among our contingent. We re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cognise the dedication of our contingent

Speaker: NA
Text: members, who accept these risks as part of

Speaker: NA
Text: their duties and a concomitant of a profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of arms. The Government has decided

Speaker: NA
Text: that because the potential risks of service in

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia may be higher than for previous

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping operations, a more generous

Speaker: NA
Text: level of compensation should be paid to our

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers serving with UNTAG. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has decided that because of the signif-

Speaker: NA
Text: icant risks involved, the members of our

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia contingent will receive appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: recompense, including a substantial allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance, and that their full pay and allowances

Speaker: NA
Text: will be tax-free while they are in Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is in fact the most generous package

Speaker: NA
Text: of allowances and conditions offered to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian servicemen abroad since the Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: War. My colleague the Minister for Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Personnel, who has been respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for putting this package together, will

Speaker: NA
Text: be giving fuller details later in this debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: am confident that all honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: will agree that these conditions are a fitting

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition of the service to be undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: by our soldiers in Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian soldiers will serve in Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: for tours of six months. The UN plans to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring Namibia to independence within one

Speaker: NA
Text: year. We are committed to maintain our

Speaker: NA
Text: UNTAG contingent for that period. At least

Speaker: NA
Text: one rotation will therefore be necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, it may be that delays in the imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation of the transition plan for Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: could occur, which might require UNT AG

Speaker: NA
Text: to stay in place longer than a year. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government would, of course, then have to

Speaker: NA
Text: review our commitment in the light of all

Speaker: NA
Text: the circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our UNTAG contingent accounts for

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly half of our construction engineer ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: pability and their deployment to Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: will affect the engineering resources closer to

Speaker: NA
Text: home. Our engineers perform a lot of impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant work in Australia and in our region.

Speaker: NA
Text: Among the activities which had been planned

Speaker: NA
Text: for our engineers are a number of high prior-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity defence cooperation program (DCP)

Speaker: NA
Text: projects in the south-west Pacific and Papua

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea, including a new police head-

Speaker: NA
Text: quarters in Vanuatu, a new wharf on Manus

Speaker: NA
Text: Island in Papua New Guinea, and studies for

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishment of a new base for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Papua New Guinea defence forces air ele-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in Port Moresby. All of these projects

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to go ahead unaffected by the

Speaker: NA
Text: UNTAG deployment. Another major task

Speaker: NA
Text: for our engineers is participation in Kanga-

Speaker: NA
Text: roo 89. Here the departure of 17 Construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Squadron will have some impact, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army is planning to use reserves more

Speaker: NA
Text: fully to make up the gap. I might say that I

Speaker: NA
Text: am very pleased, as I said before, that two

Speaker: NA
Text: reservists are among our first deployment to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia and that others will follow. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve this demonstrates in a concrete fashion

Speaker: NA
Text: our determination to integrate the reserves

Speaker: NA
Text: fully into the Army and treat them as the

Speaker: NA
Text: serious soldiers that they are. I conclude by

Speaker: NA
Text: joining the Prime Minister and the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) in wishing

Speaker: NA
Text: the men of our first Namibia contingent well

Speaker: NA
Text: in their important work.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England-Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the National Party of Australia) (3.28)-

Speaker: NA
Text: II share the good wishes extended to those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are about to serve in the United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Transitional Assistance Group, the

Speaker: NA
Text: UNTAG Corps, by the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke), the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard) and the Minister for Defence ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley). I do not think there is any more

Speaker: NA
Text: significant decision by this Parliament than

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision to send armed forces abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a significant decision and, albeit that

Speaker: NA
Text: it comes 11 years after the original decision,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is one which now has a prime bearing on

Speaker: NA
Text: those personnel about to serve in Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are three aspects of the service that I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to address: the role of peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: forces and their role in southern Africa; the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect on the Australian Defence Force

Speaker: NA
Text: (ADF); and the protection of the rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: serving personnel and their dependants.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, with respect to peacekeeping forces,

Speaker: NA
Text: I was very critical, and remain critical, of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's decision to withdraw the

Speaker: NA
Text: multinational force from the Sinai. I well

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the reason for the return of the

Speaker: NA
Text: rotary wing element and comprehend the

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage to the mobility of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force, in particular the Operational

Speaker: NA
Text: Deployment Force (ODF), of that helicop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter facility. Nonetheless, I believe there

Speaker: NA
Text: other roles that could have been played there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has served and is serving in a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of other joint forces around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. I think it is commendable that yet

Speaker: NA
Text: again the United Nations (UN) in this in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance has been prepared to act and it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: more commendable because it seems the So-

Speaker: NA
Text: viet veto has not been applied as it has on a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of occasions. We recall that, because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Soviet veto, it was necessary to form

Speaker: NA
Text: a multinational force and observers (MFO)

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than a UN force when the Sinai com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment was entered into. There is, without

Speaker: NA
Text: any doubt, for Australia a very real respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility to act as a neutral country where we

Speaker: NA
Text: can to assist in trying to ensure peace be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween other nations. The Opposition parties

Speaker: NA
Text: see this as an entirely appropriate part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the role of the ADF. It is in that respect

Speaker: NA
Text: that we made this initial commitment and

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the Government for pursuing it.

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to the role in southern Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: rica, the situation there is difficult. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the elements that I noticed absent

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Prime Minister's statement-and it

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been adverted to by the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence-is the very large number of Cuban

Speaker: NA
Text: troops that have been serving in the area.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a requirement that, by 1 August, all

Speaker: NA
Text: 47,000 Cuban troops must be north of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fifteenth parallel. That is a large number of

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel. We need to understand that the

Speaker: NA
Text: UNTAG group is a very small element and

Speaker: NA
Text: much will depend on the goodwill of those

Speaker: NA
Text: other personnel-not just the Cuban troops

Speaker: NA
Text: but also the group that has been referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister within the South West Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: rica People's Organisation. We know that

Speaker: NA
Text: SWAPO has been guilty of continued insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: gency activities, in violation of the New York

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements, along the border of Angola and

Speaker: NA
Text: south-west Africa. There has been, appar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ently, a building up of about 4,800 SWAPO

Speaker: NA
Text: members in various camps.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an extraordinarily sensitive part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility of UNTAG to try to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol a large number of forces whose acts in

Speaker: NA
Text: the past have not suggested that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to meet the general obligations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the peace accords, although I believe that at

Speaker: NA
Text: least to date the Cuban troops are acting in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with their obligations. One can

Speaker: NA
Text: only hope that within the responsibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: were the UNTAG group, which is to monitor the

Speaker: NA
Text: peace process, there will be an ability for it

Speaker: NA
Text: to act as one would wish, given its size and

Speaker: NA
Text: the inevitable limitations of any peacekeep-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing force. Indeed, one commends those in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations who have been respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for putting together this element.

Speaker: NA
Text: For Australia, however, it is a risky oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation. One would be foolish to think there is

Speaker: NA
Text: not an element of risk in our service in

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia. This has been acknowledged by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and now by the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence. It is in that respect that we all

Speaker: NA
Text: need to understand the nature of service in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Defence Force. It is in that

Speaker: NA
Text: area that my own concern is paramount. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know from the Prime Minister's statement

Speaker: NA
Text: that about half of the engineering capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Defence Force will go to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia. We have been told by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Defence that two reservists will be in this

Speaker: NA
Text: first detachment. While we entirely endorse

Speaker: NA
Text: the integration of reservists with the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Defence Force, and hence their dispatch

Speaker: NA
Text: and participation, through the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: to the call-out legislation, I believe there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: problem be.::ause of the nature of demands

Speaker: NA
Text: that could be brought to bear on the ADF

Speaker: NA
Text: and other areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister's statement refers to

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence cooperation program in the Pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: cific. It is not only that obligation overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: which might require a commitment from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force; from media re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports it seems that the Government has made

Speaker: NA
Text: an initial suggestion that up to 1,000 Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Defence Force personnel might partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pate in any cooperative peace force involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in Cambodia. We also know of an approach

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government of Papua New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australian Defence Force personnel to

Speaker: NA
Text: be posted there. In other words, quite apart

Speaker: NA
Text: from this obligation, there are at least two

Speaker: NA
Text: possible commitments which will draw fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther on the ADF. When that is measured

Speaker: NA
Text: against the record rate of resignations and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party's attitude to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards the Defence Force, which has not

Speaker: NA
Text: shown care for and attention to the person-

Speaker: NA
Text: nel of the Australian Defence Force, one

Speaker: NA
Text: can only be apprehensive about the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: this will have on the Australian Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Force's ability not only to meet those exter-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal obligations but also to maintain the train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing program and the high standards expected

Speaker: NA
Text: in its preparedness and ability to service the

Speaker: NA
Text: new equipment acquired by it within Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and within the ADF's other broader

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course this is particularly significant

Speaker: NA
Text: far as the Army is concerned. Over the 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months to which the Prime Minister's state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment refers, every member of the engineer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing corps will be serving in Namibia. As half

Speaker: NA
Text: will go in the first element and half in the

Speaker: NA
Text: second-even though there might be some

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing on reservists, and one needs to un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstand that inevitably there is some turn-

Speaker: NA
Text: over-every member of the engineering corps

Speaker: NA
Text: will serve in Namibia. While that is excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: in experience terms, the reality is that num-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers in the Australian Army are inadequate

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet the sorts of obligations that this

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas commitment places on them. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been 11 years notice. Over that time one

Speaker: NA
Text: would have hoped that there could have

Speaker: NA
Text: been a recognition that there might well

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be, therefore, some build-up of the

Speaker: NA
Text: engineering force so that it is not stretched

Speaker: NA
Text: to the limit, as I suggest it might be. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has said that there will be no effect

Speaker: NA
Text: on Kangaroo 89, nor on domestic ability. I

Speaker: NA
Text: put it to him that in the circumstances of

Speaker: NA
Text: such an extraordinarily large commitment it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be very hard for the Army to meet its

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic commitments not only in Kangaroo

Speaker: NA
Text: 89 but in the defence cooperation program

Speaker: NA
Text: and certainly, if additional commitments are

Speaker: NA
Text: required, in either Cambodia or Papua New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps the most significant element, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, of Opposition concern is our worry

Speaker: NA
Text: about the extent to which the protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of serving personnel and their depen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dants, if any injury should occur, is covered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government. I understand that the

Speaker: NA
Text: area is to be declared a war zone. I remain

Speaker: NA
Text: to be advised whether the service will be

Speaker: NA
Text: declared operational. I also heard no refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence in the comments of either the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Prime Minister to the present terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth Employees Compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation Act which largely, in many instances,

Speaker: NA
Text: has replaced the overall embrace of cover

Speaker: NA
Text: for veterans. One needs to understand, if

Speaker: NA
Text: there should be death-sadly, we know that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was one in the United Nations forces

Speaker: NA
Text: in Lebanon a little while ago-that those

Speaker: NA
Text: who serve abroad in the Australian uniform

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of this country need to be offered

Speaker: NA
Text: a more secure and better package than that

Speaker: NA
Text: which is available to anybody who serves

Speaker: NA
Text: within Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, for those who are serving in the

Speaker: NA
Text: as UNT AG group, there should be a require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the part of this Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide at least as generous a package of

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements on their return-or for their

Speaker: NA
Text: dependants, should anything tragic happen

Speaker: NA
Text: to them-that ensures that they and their

Speaker: NA
Text: dependants are protected. I trust that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mrs Kelly) will cover this aspect in her

Speaker: NA
Text: statement. We need to know whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will declare the zone opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional; the impact on dependants of the pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent package within the Commonwralth

Speaker: NA
Text: Employees Compensation Act; and whether

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans' entitlements will be available to the

Speaker: NA
Text: full degree that they were available in

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole of the character of what I have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen and heard suggests-as does the reser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation in the comments of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence-that the Government is not being

Speaker: NA
Text: as forthcoming as it should be. In the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position's mind that is totally unacceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: because there is, without any doubt, a neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity for those who are serving in these cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances to be fully covered and fully

Speaker: NA
Text: protected, as should be their dependants. I

Speaker: NA
Text: say to those who are serving and who wiIl

Speaker: NA
Text: serve that members of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: join other members who have spoken in

Speaker: NA
Text: wishing them well and commend them for

Speaker: NA
Text: their professionalism and the high standards

Speaker: NA
Text: which we know they will achieve, and trust

Speaker: NA
Text: that they all return to this country in a 100

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent healthy state.

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: Canberra-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Science arid Personnel) (3.38)-1

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the House for the cooperative spirit in

Speaker: NA
Text: which this issue has been debated. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) and the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Defence ( Mr Beazley) have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: uniformed Australians have an outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: record in United Nations (UN) peacekeep-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing forces. From Korea to Cyprus, to Leba-

Speaker: NA
Text: non and Iran, Australian police and military

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel have been keeping the peace. Often

Speaker: NA
Text: that peace has been uneasy and fragile, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the battles of long time enemies have flared

Speaker: NA
Text: up again along disputed borders or between

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional rivals. Keeping the peace in

Speaker: NA
Text: bled lands, trying to implement on the ground

Speaker: NA
Text: the complex strategies of mediators and endetails

Speaker: NA
Text: voys, is no sinecure: it is tough, difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: enormously valuable work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The peace plan for Namibia has been long

Speaker: NA
Text: in the making, as the Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence have said, and much

Speaker: NA
Text: delayed in its implementation. Now, after lO

Speaker: NA
Text: years, it is time for the plan to be tested;

Speaker: NA
Text: is time for the Australian Defence Force

Speaker: NA
Text: (ADF) to make its contribution; and it will.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a contribution from all Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: tangible evidence of our commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: peace in the world. For the 300 men who contingent.

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to Namibia, it is a very personal

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment. I have visited the Namibian has

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent twice, accompanied on my most

Speaker: NA
Text: recent visit by my colleague the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: was most impressed with the calibre of the

Speaker: NA
Text: troops we are sending, the quality of their

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership and equipment, and their good

Speaker: NA
Text: spirits and high morale. Colonel Richard

Speaker: NA
Text: Warren and his second-in-command, Lieuthe

Speaker: NA
Text: tenant-Colonel Kevin Pippard, were in New

Speaker: NA
Text: York attending the United Nations Transipayable

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Assistance Group (UNTAG) contintransfer

Speaker: NA
Text: gent commanders brief, but Colonel Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Rose, the Commandant of the Land Comin

Speaker: NA
Text: mand engineers, took me around, along with

Speaker: NA
Text: Major David Crago, who is leading the 238

Speaker: NA
Text: men of the 17th Construction Squadron,

Speaker: NA
Text: UNT AG, to Namibia. I must say that I was

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly impressed with the leadership

Speaker: NA
Text: the officers who wi11lead this contingent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was invited to a lunch at

Speaker: NA
Text: where I had a chance to meet members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the contingent and talk with them about

Speaker: NA
Text: their concerns and feelings on the eve of

Speaker: NA
Text: their deployment. They all knew that they

Speaker: NA
Text: were going into danger. No doubt for many

Speaker: NA
Text: of them there was regret at the thought

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving their families behind. But all were

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clear about one thing above all: that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were going to Namibia for a good

Speaker: NA
Text: son, for a really worthwhile purpose. They

Speaker: NA
Text: take with them all our best wishes and our

Speaker: NA
Text: unanimous support. Along with our goodbe

Speaker: NA
Text: will, they deserve tangible evidence that we

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate what they are doing for us and

Speaker: NA
Text: for the cause of peace in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: A package of conditions has been agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: on that recognises the unique and special

Speaker: NA
Text: troucharacter of the circumstances that these

Speaker: NA
Text: men will face in Africa. I will go into the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the allowances in a moment, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: and begin by expressing my pleasure at the ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: forts that will go into providing for the fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ilies of the men who are going to Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Members of the contingent will be eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for up to seven days of pre-embarkation

Speaker: NA
Text: leave to finalise their personal affairs and to

Speaker: NA
Text: it make their farewells before they go. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to keep in touch with their

Speaker: NA
Text: families and loved ones while they are in

Speaker: NA
Text: and Namibia and Defence will meet the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: to postage to and from members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: A support network, known as network 17,

Speaker: NA
Text: been established to assist families. Based

Speaker: NA
Text: at No. 1 Construction Regiment at Holswor-

Speaker: NA
Text: for thy, the network includes a 008 information

Speaker: NA
Text: I service which families can ring for advice

Speaker: NA
Text: and support. The families already have been

Speaker: NA
Text: called in. They have met with the officers

Speaker: NA
Text: and have had a full brief in regard to contact

Speaker: NA
Text: and the sort of support they will have. So

Speaker: NA
Text: support network is already well in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Normal Defence Force allowances will be

Speaker: NA
Text: to members of the contingent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance of between $335 and $4lO

Speaker: NA
Text: per member, depending on whether he lived

Speaker: NA
Text: barracks or outside prior to departure,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be paid. Separation allowance for those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are separated from their families will be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid. Members of the contingent also will be

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible for an outlay allowance and an inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: of est-free loan of $1,500 to assist in meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: costs associated with establishing themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: Holsworthy, in an overseas country.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Namibia the contingent will be divided

Speaker: NA
Text: into two groups: the headquarters staff in

Speaker: NA
Text: barracks in the capital and those who will

Speaker: NA
Text: be out in the field, mainly along the northern

Speaker: NA
Text: . border. The headquarters staff will receive a

Speaker: NA
Text: of special Namibia allowance of $22 a day. On

Speaker: NA
Text: top of this, the United Nations allowance of

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.52 is payable. Headquarters staff will pay

Speaker: NA
Text: rearations and quarters charges at the Win-

Speaker: NA
Text: dhoek barracks through the commanding of-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficer, although the commanding officer will

Speaker: NA
Text: empowered to waive these charges if he

Speaker: NA
Text: finds the conditions there to be substandard.

Speaker: NA
Text: No rations and quarters charges will be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: by members of the contingent out in the

Speaker: NA
Text: field and their special allowance for Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: will be paid at the rate of $35 a day as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as the UN allowance. These rates will be

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewed, but not diminished, soon after the

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent deploys to Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowances payable to members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent will vary from $335 plus $23.52

Speaker: NA
Text: a day for single members serving at head-

Speaker: NA
Text: quarters to $410 plus $39.96 a day for a

Speaker: NA
Text: married member posted to the forward areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer ( Mr Keating) has agreed that

Speaker: NA
Text: all pay and allowances for members of UN-

Speaker: NA
Text: TAG will be free of tax. The decision dates

Speaker: NA
Text: from 18 February and the Treasurer will be

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking an amendment to section 23A (c) of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Income Tax Assessment Act to give ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fect to it. I would like to thank members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House for their support of that initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Particularly, I would like to pay tribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer for his support. The Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: has proved by this decision that this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is committed to the UN peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: force. This is no empty gesture; it is a real

Speaker: NA
Text: and determined decision, which I welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: most warmly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members opposite raised the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of repatriation benefits. These benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: will be appropriate to the task and hazards

Speaker: NA
Text: that the contingent will meet. Currently we

Speaker: NA
Text: are examining the various options. Ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously, there are two categories: operational

Speaker: NA
Text: and peacekeeping. Basically, I am looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to provide the best conditions possible

Speaker: NA
Text: for these people. Some people argue that

Speaker: NA
Text: better conditions are offered under the

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping category. Others argue that

Speaker: NA
Text: better conditions exist under the operational

Speaker: NA
Text: category. Much will depend on the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances, As a minimum, these conditions will

Speaker: NA
Text: include: normal benefits under part 4 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Entitlements Act; 24-hour any oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: currence cover for death or· invalidity bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits while outside Australia; coverage under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilita-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Compensation Act for 28 days after

Speaker: NA
Text: return; favourable standards of proof for

Speaker: NA
Text: cases; and limited rights to sue at common

Speaker: NA
Text: law. These are just the basic conditions and,

Speaker: NA
Text: as I said, we are looking in detail at the

Speaker: NA
Text: categories that they should fall into. The best

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the troops are being taken into

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration, bearing in mind the threat

Speaker: NA
Text: scenario that they are going to be facing. No

Speaker: NA
Text: package of conditions can fully compensate

Speaker: NA
Text: for the hazards that Australia's contingent of

Speaker: NA
Text: UNTAG will be walking into, but conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: like the ones I have outlined are designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: take account of the difficulties that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: predicted and the separation from families

Speaker: NA
Text: and loved ones that necessarily accompany

Speaker: NA
Text: deployment such as this.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian contingent to UNTAG will

Speaker: NA
Text: soon be deployed. To the 300 men directly

Speaker: NA
Text: involved, I extend my best wishes and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal thanks. They are joining a proud group

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australians, including my father, who,

Speaker: NA
Text: many years ago, was a member of the peace-

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping force in Cyprus. These men over the

Speaker: NA
Text: years have genuinely fought for peace. I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: them all the best of luck in their role of

Speaker: NA
Text: mediating in an area that has known the

Speaker: NA
Text: ravages of war for so many years. I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: them a safe return. I hope that their families

Speaker: NA
Text: feel compensated in some way by the pack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages we have allowed. I hope that the serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: icemen feel that at least this Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: looking after them and their families. They

Speaker: NA
Text: go in the hope, though not in the certain

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge, of succeeding in their mission.

Speaker: NA
Text: The heartfelt good wishes of all peaceloving

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians and of everyone dedicated to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ideals of the UN everywhere go with the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADF contingent to be deployed to Namibia.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: North Sydney) (3.48)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall be brief. I welcome, as other speakers

Speaker: NA
Text: have, the decision to give effect to a decision

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in principle many years ago by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser Government, of which the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition ( Mr Howard) and the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of National Party of Australia ( Mr Sinclair)

Speaker: NA
Text: were both members, to support, effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: through Australian troops, the peace process

Speaker: NA
Text: in Namibia. Namibia is large in size, small

Speaker: NA
Text: in population and impoverished. Like so

Speaker: NA
Text: many other African countries, it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: afflicted not simply by poverty but by man-

Speaker: NA
Text: made disasters of one kind or another. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, it has been bedevilled by

Speaker: NA
Text: insurgency.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am glad that we are going to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: removal of foreign troops. I am also glad

Speaker: NA
Text: that the South African Government appears

Speaker: NA
Text: to be taking a more realistic approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the foreign policy issues on its bor-

Speaker: NA
Text: der. We on this side of the House look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward in particular to the eventual with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawal from Africa of all Cuban troops who,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the arm of the Soviets, have been so

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for so much of the armed devas-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation that has bedevilled sub-Saharan Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's role is an important one, as has

Speaker: NA
Text: been pointed out by all speakers. I join the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the National Party in hoping that

Speaker: NA
Text: our involvement in Namibia will not over-

Speaker: NA
Text: stretch our forces. I notice that in his state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the House, in reference to the 300

Speaker: NA
Text: men that we are sending to Namibia, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) said:

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very large and important commitment for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, comprising almost half of the Army's con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction engineering capabilities. Careful planning,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the use of Reservists, has been required to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that high-priority engineering tasks closer to

Speaker: NA
Text: home can still be performed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I emphasise that in this case careful plan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning, including the use of reservists, was nec-

Speaker: NA
Text: essary for the purposes of leaving available

Speaker: NA
Text: the capability of high priority engineering

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks closer to home. It is a pity that our

Speaker: NA
Text: forces are in that state.

Speaker: NA
Text: I acknowledge, as other members have,

Speaker: NA
Text: the difficulties that this process is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: face. The timetable looks for independence

Speaker: NA
Text: in a year's time and the establishment of

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic government. I am sorry to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the record of democratic government in

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa has been a sad one. I hope that on

Speaker: NA
Text: this occasion a democratic government will

Speaker: NA
Text: be established and will be able to flourish.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me say one other thing about some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the disasters that have bedevilled Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we speak about Africa-indeed, when

Speaker: NA
Text: we speak about any other part of the world-

Speaker: NA
Text: in terms of rights and abuses, we need per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps to take a broader view and not be as

Speaker: NA
Text: selective as this Government has been in its

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to southern African affairs. We

Speaker: NA
Text: join the Government unequivocally in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: demning apartheid. The reasons for that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: demnation are well known and have been

Speaker: NA
Text: stated again and again by speakers from this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: We think that more attention should be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to some of the other manmade disasters

Speaker: NA
Text: in the sub-Saharan area of southern Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will give one example. In August of last

Speaker: NA
Text: year in Burundi the majority Tutsis slaugh-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered some 25,000 minority Hutus. In con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trast to the language of denunciation on

Speaker: NA
Text: South African affairs-and I am not quar-

Speaker: NA
Text: relling about the language of denunciation

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to apartheid but I do quarrel

Speaker: NA
Text: about selectivity in weight, however-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ator Gareth Evans) answered a total of one

Speaker: NA
Text: question on this dreadful outrage. Twenty-

Speaker: NA
Text: five thousand people were slaughtered. It

Speaker: NA
Text: passed almost unnoticed by this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. When asked a question on notice by

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Chaney-a question put down on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Notice Paper-about whether Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: would look into what concerted international

Speaker: NA
Text: action might be possible over Burundi the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's response was nothing, zero. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was no answer after many months. One

Speaker: NA
Text: would think that if this deep concern for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Burundi is felt, as it should be, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister could bother to get around to an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swering a question on that subject. I ask him

Speaker: NA
Text: and other members of the Government, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the spirit of the bipartisan and sensible ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to these important foreign policy is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sues, to look to the other issues as well in

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-Saharan Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister has welcomed the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volvement of the work of the United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in this case. We certainly welcome more

Speaker: NA
Text: effective work from the United Nations. But

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to understand that effective work

Speaker: NA
Text: from the United Nations depends on con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structive diplomacy from the Soviet Union,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially at the Security Council level. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: good to see that in some respects changes

Speaker: NA
Text: have been noted in the way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union is approaching a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign policy issues as it reassesses its own

Speaker: NA
Text: position in the world and its own internal

Speaker: NA
Text: position. But we need to remember that the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations is a meeting ground of na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and that its success is not dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: on some kind of mystical quality that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: attributed to the United Nations but is de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent crucially on the constructive in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volvement and cooperation of the major

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. It was the Soviet Union, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Council level, which for decades

Speaker: NA
Text: was the major preponderant bloc to success-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful work in the Security Council.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we are seeing is a first step. We

Speaker: NA
Text: hope it will be a successful step towards

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic government. We welcome again

Speaker: NA
Text: the involvement of Australian troops. We

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that if Namibia proves to be successful

Speaker: NA
Text: it may help wean the South African Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment away from the policies of apartheid

Speaker: NA
Text: which are so universally condemned. It is in

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of all South Africans that that

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy be put to one side. But it is in our

Speaker: NA
Text: general interests to look to African affairs as

Speaker: NA
Text: we look to the affairs of any other part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world and to apply a measured, balanced

Speaker: NA
Text: and objective judgment on events.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mrs Darling)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: ECONOMY: LIVING STANDARDS

Speaker: NA
Text: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Leo der

Speaker: NA
Text: MCLeay)-Madam Speaker has received a start

Speaker: NA
Text: letter from the Deputy leader of the Oppoyears.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: nite matter of public importance

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House for discussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The impact of six years of economic mismanage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment under the Hawke Government on the living

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of low to middle income earners.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members

Speaker: NA
Text: quired by the Standing Orders having risen

Speaker: NA
Text: in their places-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: is an interesting matter of public importance

Speaker: NA
Text: that I bring before the House today-even

Speaker: NA
Text: I say so myself-not only because it provides

Speaker: NA
Text: one with the opportunity to range over

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of the economic mismanagestart

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Hawke Labor Government but

Speaker: NA
Text: also because it provides an opportunity,

Speaker: NA
Text: it not, for the Treasurer ( Mr Keating)

Speaker: NA
Text: whoever else may respond, to pick up the

Speaker: NA
Text: much vaunted, in recent days, publicity

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising campaign projected forward by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. The Government has told

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian people that it is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: a comparison of its seven years in governber

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, that is seven years of the Hawke Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment-it has had only six so far and the

Speaker: NA
Text: way it calls early elections it probably will

Speaker: NA
Text: not make seven-with the record of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser Government. I find that fascinating,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite apart from the reality that Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: are suffering under record high interest rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: a huge foreign debt, higher rates of inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: and hopeless positions for so many on

Speaker: NA
Text: housing.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Government pauses at the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mencement of this comparison and says,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Let's have a comparison', it is so retrospec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive and rear vision mirror driven to be going

Speaker: NA
Text: TRADE to the people and saying, 'Look at the past

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of looking to the future'. If we do a

Speaker: NA
Text: there were 7t years of the Fraser.

Speaker: NA
Text: apGovernment and six years of the Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: Government which takes us back 13t years.

Speaker: NA
Text: It takes us back to the commencement of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fraser Government which was the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Whitlam Government. If we wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: to go back ourselves what a time we would

Speaker: NA
Text: have comparing the record of Labor under

Speaker: NA
Text: Whitlam with the record for this nation un-

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser. I will put that to one side and

Speaker: NA
Text: to examine the record of the last six

Speaker: NA
Text: We have the implied contrast that it

Speaker: NA
Text: going to make so explicit with the record

Speaker: NA
Text: be submitted of the Fraser Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I pause before going on to say that on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of politics we have formulated pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams, schedules and policies that not only

Speaker: NA
Text: call forth the aspirations of Australians now

Speaker: NA
Text: but are predicated on the sort of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: we want for the future. We look towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: reyear 2000, which is only lOt years off,

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas the Government comes in with some

Speaker: NA
Text: . propaganda exercise going back 13t years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even the cognisance that the year 2000,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a shorter comparative period of

Speaker: NA
Text: if time than it wants to make, will be not only

Speaker: NA
Text: just to capture the sort of thing we are on

Speaker: NA
Text: the about, for not only is I January 2000 the

Speaker: NA
Text: of a new year but it is the start of a

Speaker: NA
Text: new century, and indeed the start of a new

Speaker: NA
Text: does millenium. It drives home the need to have

Speaker: NA
Text: or in mind the sort of Australia we want. But

Speaker: NA
Text: no, the grubby little exercises, which the

Speaker: NA
Text: and Government thinks will bring it some frui-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, are to go back. The issues that strike

Speaker: NA
Text: at Australians today that have been caused

Speaker: NA
Text: do by this Government-I can think of a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: of them-include tax, interest rates, for-

Speaker: NA
Text: eign debt, unemployment, public housing

Speaker: NA
Text: listings and household disposable income. The

Speaker: NA
Text: question for the immediate future is: What

Speaker: NA
Text: is the Government's fiscal policy? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer will come in here and say, 'Where

Speaker: NA
Text: is your policy here and where is your policy

Speaker: NA
Text: there?'. What is the Government's fiscal pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy for 1989-90? What is the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: tax gross domestic product ratio going to be?

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the Government's target Budget sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: plus? What is the Government's target for

Speaker: NA
Text: the net public sector borrowing requirement?

Speaker: NA
Text: How will the Government finance the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts and spending commitments or inflation?

Speaker: NA
Text: By the way, quite apart from the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: revealing himself today as a textual deviate

Speaker: NA
Text: in misinterpreting my transcript, I also asked

Speaker: NA
Text: him a question about the projected rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation. He got up and said: 'Oh come on,

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm not going to answer that. It's all up here;

Speaker: NA
Text: I know it all. I gave all that out a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks ago at a press conference'-he has to

Speaker: NA
Text: do all these press conferences-'I went along

Speaker: NA
Text: to a press conference and I gave the answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the press. Go and look it up'. So I went

Speaker: NA
Text: along and had a look at it. He was asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: So as of now there is no forecast for inflation?

Speaker: NA
Text: This was the answer:

Speaker: NA
Text: No. But you are not entitled to get off the top of

Speaker: NA
Text: my head CPI forecast.

Speaker: NA
Text: What a terrific answer! Some answer. The

Speaker: NA
Text: harsh reality is that there is no forecast for

Speaker: NA
Text: the projected rate of inflation. The Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that. He could not give it at the press

Speaker: NA
Text: conference and he could not give it today.

Speaker: NA
Text: We come to this comparative exercise, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: will go through a few of the examples. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite are going to do the old seven-seven

Speaker: NA
Text: calculation-Fraser and Hawke. Let us have

Speaker: NA
Text: a look at tax. Starting point: this Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: is the highest taxing Treasurer in Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: history. Bracket creep, tax creep, has taken

Speaker: NA
Text: a huge toll on Australian living standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us have a look at them. In 1982-83, 24.7

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of Australians faced a marginal tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of 40 per cent or more. Today that

Speaker: NA
Text: figure is 51.3 per cent. Some contrast. Do

Speaker: NA
Text: not tell it to the marines if the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks it is going to sell this successfully. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know interest rates are at a record high.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Labor Government average an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nual interest rates are significantly higher

Speaker: NA
Text: than under the Fraser Government. I· make

Speaker: NA
Text: the comparison here: average home loan re-

Speaker: NA
Text: payments as a share of household income

Speaker: NA
Text: have increased from 19 per cent in 1983 to

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 31 per cent. Some contrast. Because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the brevity of this debate I will not go

Speaker: NA
Text: into detail on foreign debt but, as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently said, under Labor our net for-

Text: Let us consider public housing. We know

Text: cent under the Fraser Government to 8.5

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: While I am on the subject of comparisons,

Speaker: NA

Text: the occasion, mark the occasion. He refused.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister was asked to participate

Speaker: NA
Text: in a variety of functions yesterday. He could

Speaker: NA
Text: not because he had a previous engagement.

Speaker: NA
Text: He had to go to the track. He was at the

Speaker: NA
Text: race track. At least it was a change that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was gambling with his own money-I trust-

Text: rather than the money of most Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members crept through this cel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ebratory exercise almost as if they were going

Speaker: NA
Text: through the ventilators and under the carpet

Speaker: NA
Text: to avoid being seen yesterday.

Speaker: NA
Text: So much for the comparisons between the

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us consider past rec;ords and foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us consider the record in relation to

Text: It is very important to look at a compari-

Text: per cent in the USA. In Japan, one of our

Text: Australians have been worse off in that
