Text: period.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Howard) asked the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) about disposable income. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister did not cite the source of his infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation, but he said that this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has increased real household disposable in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come by 5 per cent. He also mentioned that

Speaker: NA
Text: 1t million people had gained employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact the booklet put out by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Institute of Family Studies on the income

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer proje,ct, entitled Families and Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1989, released just last week, indicates:

Speaker: NA
Text: The three components of prices, taxes and wages

Speaker: NA
Text: are contained in the three words, real, disposable

Speaker: NA
Text: and income. 'Real' means adjusted for inflation; 'dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: posable income' means income after taxes have been

Speaker: NA
Text: deducted and family allowances, pensions and bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits and supplements added in.

Speaker: NA
Text: I seek leave to table a document taken from

Speaker: NA
Text: the report which shows what the facts are

Speaker: NA
Text: and what the Prime Minister did not disclose

Speaker: NA
Text: the other day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr BRAITHWAITEAITE
Text: The table indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cates that from 1976-77 to 1984-85 everyone,

Speaker: NA
Text: from single income people to couples and

Speaker: NA
Text: sole parents, benefited by as little as $26.79

Speaker: NA
Text: a week to as much as $38.42 a week. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween 1984-85 and 1988-89 a single person's

Speaker: NA
Text: disposable income dropped by $30.61; that

Speaker: NA
Text: of a couple with two children dropped by

Speaker: NA
Text: $4l.71; and that of a couple with four chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren dropped by $47.85. Where does the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister get his figure of a 5 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement in disposable income when

Speaker: NA
Text: these figures come from a quite neutral plan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning authority, the Institute of Family Stud-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies? Its figures, which agree with ours, show

Speaker: NA
Text: quite conclusively that a family with two

Speaker: NA
Text: children has suffered a deterioration of $58

Speaker: NA
Text: a week. This fact was supported recently by

Speaker: NA
Text: Eric Risstrom, who said that Australian fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ilies in that category are $56 a week worse

Speaker: NA
Text: off now than they were those many years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would now like to deal with what dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: posable income is supposed to buy in 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week we had a major housing summit,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was a talkfest. The quality of housing

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of the things by which we measure

Speaker: NA
Text: our standard of living. That meeting was

Speaker: NA
Text: really a diversion by the Treasurer and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister so that we could not see the

Speaker: NA
Text: real situation in the housing industry today.

Speaker: NA
Text: A report of only this morning, following a

Speaker: NA
Text: poll by Saulwick, indicates that far from

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Treasurer and the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: are saying-that the problem is a shortage

Speaker: NA
Text: of land-only one person in 10 believes that

Speaker: NA
Text: but four out of 10 people believe the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem can be blamed fairly and squarely on

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last Friday the Treasurer gave away land

Speaker: NA
Text: that I understand had already been under

Speaker: NA
Text: option to a Singaporean agency. Some other

Speaker: NA
Text: land is subject to flooding. So not only is he

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to push his economics uphill but also

Speaker: NA
Text: he will be pushing water uphill to prove that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no flooding in that area. A third

Speaker: NA
Text: problem is that some of the land is used as

Speaker: NA
Text: an airport, and that will always remain an

Speaker: NA
Text: airport. That is the Treasurer's response to

Speaker: NA
Text: the major problems of housing in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly for those low to middle income

Speaker: NA
Text: earners.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1983 the average monthly repayment

Speaker: NA
Text: on a housing loan was $350. Today it is

Speaker: NA
Text: $778. In 1983 it was 19.2 per cent of a

Speaker: NA
Text: person's income and in September 1988 it

Speaker: NA
Text: was 30.7 per cent. There are record interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates now applying, particularly in the home

Speaker: NA
Text: loan area. In March 1983 the interest rate

Speaker: NA
Text: on home loans was 12.5 per cent and today

Speaker: NA
Text: it is 15.5 per cent. The prime rate of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: has gone from 14 per cent to 17.5 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the small overdraft rate has gone from

Speaker: NA
Text: 14 per cent to 17.5 per cent. The small

Speaker: NA
Text: overdraft rate is very important to those

Speaker: NA
Text: people trying to get a housing loan but not

Speaker: NA
Text: being able to get a deposit together.

Speaker: NA
Text: I heard as recently as today that the banks

Speaker: NA
Text: are asking those people to get a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: loan, in addition to their mortgage, which

Speaker: NA
Text: carries an extra rate of interest of 2 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Treasurer or the Prime Minister wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: to get to the base of the problem, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: find that in the last six years people have

Speaker: NA
Text: had to walk out of their houses because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the increased loan repayments due to high

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates. We cannot blame this on any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing but the Treasurer's determination to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that interest rates remain high.

Speaker: NA
Text: He is not taking any interest in the living

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of the people we are concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: for, the low and middle income earners. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are not talking about the Treasurer's living

Speaker: NA
Text: standards, but those of people on low and

Speaker: NA
Text: middle incomes who have suffered from those

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates,. high taxation and now this

Speaker: NA
Text: latest scandal of the Treasurer not being

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to support his own policies in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr MiI-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren)-Order! The honourable member's time

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Text: Stirling)

Speaker: NA
Text: (4.35)-Today's matter of public importance

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Opposition challenges the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to talk about the living standards of

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary people. It also mentions economic

Speaker: NA
Text: management and how that economic man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement affects living standards. The Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition has argued that there has been a decline

Speaker: NA
Text: in living standards under the Labor Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. At the outset we say that that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: the case, and we can talk about statistics in

Speaker: NA
Text: a minute to show that. But what we also

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to say is that I and others on my side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House are quite happy to oblige the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition with a debate about economic

Speaker: NA
Text: management. When we reflect back over the

Speaker: NA
Text: seven sorry years that preceded us, we realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was a record of economic misman-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement. We have only to reflect back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the time when we took office in 1983 to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that high inflation was common in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia-for example, 11 per cent-coupled

Speaker: NA
Text: with what is really a very sorry record in

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, which was rising. In fact we

Speaker: NA
Text: had a condition known as stagflation. People

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the Minister at the table, the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Land Transport and Shipping Sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port ( Mr Robert Brown), are familiar with

Speaker: NA
Text: it. It takes an extraordinary economic inabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity to get into that combined condition of

Speaker: NA
Text: high unemployment and high inflation, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition managed to do that. It even

Speaker: NA
Text: reinforced it by ensuring that in its last year

Speaker: NA
Text: in office it put an extra quarter of a million

Speaker: NA
Text: people on the unemployment list. That was

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinary achievement. In the context

Speaker: NA
Text: of an expanding Budget deficit, in Keynesian

Speaker: NA
Text: terms, it ought to have been soaking up

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment-but it was not. So we had a

Speaker: NA
Text: prospective Budget deficit of $9.6 billion un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der the present Opposition-it was already

Speaker: NA
Text: running a high deficit anyway-and it was

Speaker: NA
Text: not eating into unemployment, but those high

Speaker: NA
Text: rates of unemployment were not eating into

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation either. So. we had this paradoxical

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in terms of the tests of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: management: high inflation, high unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and a high deficit. ,

Speaker: NA
Text: But the story went on. We thought that

Speaker: NA
Text: as they messed it up in terms of unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment policy and fiscal policy, they might get

Speaker: NA
Text: it right in terms of monetary policy. But they

Speaker: NA
Text: did not. Despite their best efforts, the infla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion rate and interest rates, which at one

Speaker: NA
Text: stage reached 22 per cent, ran away from

Speaker: NA
Text: them. We have to remember that these were

Speaker: NA
Text: the four major achievements that they could

Speaker: NA
Text: go out on. As the lights went out on Mal-

Speaker: NA
Text: colm Fraser and .John Howard, they also

Speaker: NA
Text: took out with them some extraordinary eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic statistics-high inflation, high unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment, a very high deficit and high interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. We might have thought that the tale

Speaker: NA
Text: would have ended there, but it did not, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they also took out with them high tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. They managed at the same time to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave in place the 60 per cent marginal tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rate. So one can count their five extraordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nary achievements--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-And negative growth.

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Text: I was going

Speaker: NA
Text: to turn to negative economic growth. For

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time in 20 years we had negative

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth. It was an extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement. I find it unusual for the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position to come in here on an anniversary,

Speaker: NA
Text: if we can call it that, and say, 'Let us look

Speaker: NA
Text: back at what has been achieved'. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to do that, but when we do, the first

Speaker: NA
Text: thing we are forced to do is reflect upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic mismanagement that preceded us.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are happy to oblige the Opposition on

Speaker: NA
Text: this, but it is fair to say that we should look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the tax policies and the policy options

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been explored by us and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said that the 60c in the dollar rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: tax was still in place when the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: was in power, and we brought it down to

Speaker: NA
Text: 49c. But we also did a number of other

Speaker: NA
Text: things in terms of tax reform, most of which

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members did not like. They did

Speaker: NA
Text: not like them because they affected people

Speaker: NA
Text: whom they were happy to protect, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly those engaged in tax avoidance and

Speaker: NA
Text: evasion practices. More than that, they were

Speaker: NA
Text: not happy to tackle the issue of the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax; they did not want to. They were

Speaker: NA
Text: also happy to keep the free lunches in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it extraordinary that Opposition mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers have backed off addressing the many

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities that we have put in front of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian public in the past six years.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are still the defenders of the free lunch.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have learnt in the last couple of days

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have finally managed to renege on

Speaker: NA
Text: the assets test in terms of a social welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish that at some stage members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party of Australia would challenge

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Liberal Party of Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know the Nationals are challenging the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: erals on the Kerin wheat marketing plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the previous Government-and mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Opposition should reflect upon

Speaker: NA
Text: this because it has had very serious long term

Speaker: NA
Text: implications-overvalued the Australian dol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar over a long period and thereby gave no

Speaker: NA
Text: help to our export industries. It was the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision of this Government to float the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian dollar that corrected those prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems. It is all very well for members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition to talk about market outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: But they were not willing to let market out-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes prevail. They wanted to disguise those

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes with what amounted to a managed

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange rate. People in the export market

Speaker: NA
Text: will tell members of the Opposition that that

Speaker: NA
Text: is not the way to conduct an economy that

Speaker: NA
Text: is growing and vibrant. We have had to

Speaker: NA
Text: change one of those fundamentals and allow

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian dollar to float. The previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Government never met that challenge. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public knew that it would not

Speaker: NA
Text: meet that challenge. The interesting thing is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian public know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, even though it has had six years

Speaker: NA
Text: cooling down on the opposition benches, will

Speaker: NA
Text: still not meet the challenge. Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: members still react to the sectional interest

Speaker: NA
Text: groups, as they always have.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have found it very interesting-as I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure my colleague the Minister for Land

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport and Shipping Support has-to

Speaker: NA
Text: watch Opposition members over the last six

Speaker: NA
Text: years. We realise that it is a bit difficult being

Speaker: NA
Text: in opposition because a lot of the time one

Speaker: NA
Text: has to counterpunch, react to Government

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives and try to put a reasonable posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive gloss on what otherwise is a difficult job.

Speaker: NA
Text: We accept that, and the Australian public

Speaker: NA
Text: accepts that. But one would have thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that, having done that counterpunching ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ercise, members of the Opposition would have

Speaker: NA
Text: sat back and said, 'Let us put together a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy framework that is designed to project

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia into the future'. We thought that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, after six years, would have

Speaker: NA
Text: produced such a framework. We thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that Future Directions would be it; but it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not. It is a look back into the past. No one

Speaker: NA
Text: is rejecting the past; what we are asking is,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'What is the promise for tomorrow? What

Speaker: NA
Text: chances and opportunities can you put in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way of the Australian public?'. The sad thing

Speaker: NA
Text: about Future Directions is that it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: do that. It is a 'look back over your shoulder'

Speaker: NA
Text: approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of us have been quiet over the past

Speaker: NA
Text: six years and have been willing to listen very

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully to try to see what policy prescrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions might be presented by the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: But none have been presented. One can un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstand that because being in opposition is

Speaker: NA
Text: often very difficult. But the other side of

Speaker: NA
Text: that is that the Opposition has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to do the hard work of putting the

Speaker: NA
Text: policies together. Where is the wages policy?

Speaker: NA
Text: Where is the industry policy? Where is the

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange rate policy? Where is the tax pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy? Where is the employment policy? They

Speaker: NA
Text: are important questions; 1 think they are fair

Speaker: NA
Text: questions. They certainly get asked in here

Speaker: NA
Text: and they are also asked in the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition would do itself and those

Speaker: NA
Text: who seek to vote for it a lot of good if it

Speaker: NA
Text: had alternative policies that were thought

Speaker: NA
Text: through in terms of projections down the

Speaker: NA
Text: track. 1 accept that Opposition members want

Speaker: NA
Text: to look back to the past because the past

Speaker: NA
Text: was successful. But the problem is that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: not learnt enough from the past. All the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has done is focus on knee-jerk

Speaker: NA
Text: prejudices that make it feel comfortable. But

Speaker: NA
Text: that approach does not equip it for dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with what is down the track tomorrow. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a bit like having a football team. The other

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister at the table, the Minister for Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Negotiations ( Mr Duffy), knows that Essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: don has to recruit new players if it wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: be competitive. The problem is that those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite have not followed that line. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have not recruited new players. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: simply said, 'We have a couple of premier-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship trophies on the shelf from a few years

Speaker: NA
Text: back'. They may have the premiership tro-

Speaker: NA
Text: phies from a few years back, but the public

Speaker: NA
Text: is asking, 'What are you offering us this

Speaker: NA
Text: season? What is the new coaching strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: and who are the new players?'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sadly, 1 have to say that 1 never come

Speaker: NA
Text: here with any sense of excitement in that

Speaker: NA
Text: sense. 1 never wonder what the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: policies will be because all we ever hear is

Speaker: NA
Text: the short term fix or a quick comment. Again;

Speaker: NA
Text: to be fair, that is reasonable because there

Speaker: NA
Text: are people in the press gallery who want a

Speaker: NA
Text: daily feed. But. the larger Australian com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity wants a more substantial meal. They

Speaker: NA
Text: want to know what is the Opposition's strat-

Speaker: NA
Text: egy. The Opposition has to address some

Speaker: NA
Text: taxing and very serious questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a joint responsibility to inspire

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community with a belief that

Speaker: NA
Text: this country has policies and projections for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future. It is my view that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has done a lot of that work. We can

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about the public sector borrowing re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirement and the reduction of a deficit into

Speaker: NA
Text: a surplus. We have done all those things and

Speaker: NA
Text: met those challenges. But the challenge is

Speaker: NA
Text: not over. We have to do a lot more on

Speaker: NA
Text: restructuring. We have to do a lot more for

Speaker: NA
Text: our export industries and import competing

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. Those challenges are still before

Speaker: NA
Text: us. We on this side of the House would be

Speaker: NA
Text: crazy to say that those challenges do not

Speaker: NA
Text: exist; they do. But, in facing those chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges, one has to make sure that one has

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed the other things. We will not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the support of the Australian public if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are not doing something about job creation,

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes and attitudes towards the training and

Speaker: NA
Text: education of young people. If we fail those

Speaker: NA
Text: tests, the public will say, 'It is no good your

Speaker: NA
Text: going out into the wider world until you

Speaker: NA
Text: have met our requirements at home'. 1 say

Speaker: NA
Text: to those opposite that over the past six years

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been done. But there is a lot more

Speaker: NA
Text: to be done. 1 am confident that, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: policies we have put in place so far, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: in a position to do that. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: faces the challenge of getting that hard work

Speaker: NA
Text: done. The evidence so far is that it has not

Speaker: NA
Text: done it. 1 am happy to reject the matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: public importance put forward by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: TARIFF PROPOSALS

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Text: Holt-Minister for Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Negotiations) (4.46)-1 move:

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 1 to 9 (1989); and

Speaker: NA
Text: Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1989)

Speaker: NA
Text: The tariff proposals 1 have just tabled relate

Speaker: NA
Text: to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1987. Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 1-

Speaker: NA
Text: 7 (1989) formally place before Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: as required by law, tariff alterations made by

Speaker: NA
Text: notices published in the Commonwealth of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Gazette during the recent recess.

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 8 and 9

Speaker: NA
Text: (1989) introduce further changes in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: text of the post-1988 assistance arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: for the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF)

Speaker: NA
Text: industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1989),

Speaker: NA
Text: operative on and from 1 January 1988, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tains an alteration to additional note 1 to

Speaker: NA
Text: chapter 72 to raise the minimum copper

Speaker: NA
Text: content specification of high alloy steel. This

Speaker: NA
Text: note was prepared some years ago and has

Speaker: NA
Text: been overtaken. by changes in the steelmak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing industry. The Steel Industry Authority

Speaker: NA
Text: has confirmed that changes in technology

Speaker: NA
Text: have made the restrictions imposed by this

Speaker: NA
Text: note irrelevant to current assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 2 (1989),

Speaker: NA
Text: operative on and from 1 January 1989, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain the following alterations:

Speaker: NA
Text: The removal of Forum island rates and

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustment of developing country margins

Speaker: NA
Text: of preferences to five percentage points

Speaker: NA
Text: below the general tariff rate in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: certain tariff classifications. These rates are

Speaker: NA
Text: in accordance with the Forum island

Speaker: NA
Text: countries and revised developing country

Speaker: NA
Text: preference schemes introduced on 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: the acceleration of the phasing-out of cus-

Speaker: NA
Text: toms duty rates applicable to passenger

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicles and components thereof of

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand origin in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: the mid-term review of the passenger mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor vehicle plan; and

Speaker: NA
Text: removal of redundant item 41D from part

Speaker: NA
Text: III of schedule 4 which was in place until

Speaker: NA
Text: 31 December to accord concessional treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to certain parts and accessories for

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy commercial vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 3, 7, 8 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 9 (1989), contain a series of alterations made

Speaker: NA
Text: in the context of the post-1988 assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements for the textiles, clothing and

Speaker: NA
Text: footwear industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 3 and 7

Speaker: NA
Text: (1989), operative on and from 1 March 1989

Speaker: NA
Text: and Customs Tariff Proposals No.9, opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive on and from 1 July 1988, contain the

Speaker: NA
Text: following alterations:

Speaker: NA
Text: Changes to reflect recent decisions made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government on the TCF plan,

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the plan announced in last

Speaker: NA
Text: year's May economic statement, the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: come of a review by the TCF Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Authority on velvet duty rates, a

Speaker: NA
Text: liberalisation of Australia-New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: Closer Economic Relations Trade Agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (ANZCERTA) arrangements, and

Speaker: NA
Text: new entry arrangements for handicraft

Speaker: NA
Text: textiles and clothing and handmade

Speaker: NA
Text: footwear;

Speaker: NA
Text: alterations to the rates of duty of certain

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff classifications which prior to the TCF

Speaker: NA
Text: review fell within the ambit of the TCF

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. This action now allows the duties

Speaker: NA
Text: applicable to these tariff classifications to

Speaker: NA
Text: be phased in accordance with the rates

Speaker: NA
Text: alterations reductions;

Speaker: NA
Text: the insertion of new item 40F in part III

Speaker: NA
Text: of schedule 4 to allow duty free entry of

Speaker: NA
Text: carpets and floor coverings of heading 5703

Speaker: NA
Text: which are made by non-powered tufting

Speaker: NA
Text: machines held in the hand. These provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions were previously contained in item

Speaker: NA
Text: 40D which had validity until 30 June 1988.

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 9 ensures

Speaker: NA
Text: that the provisions continue in the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: vening period; and

Speaker: NA
Text: an amendment to note 1 to schedule 5 to

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitate entry of industrial crafts without

Speaker: NA
Text: a certificate from the supplying country

Speaker: NA
Text: until 31 August 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 8 (1989),

Speaker: NA
Text: operative on and from 1 January 1988, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tains an alteration in relation, to embroidery

Speaker: NA
Text: kits. The customs duty on embroidery kits of

Speaker: NA
Text: subheading 6308.00.90 is being reduced to 15

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 4

Speaker: NA
Text: (1989), operative on and from 4 February

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989, contains alterations to section 26 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Customs Tariff Act 1987. These altera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions complement the changes to the customs

Speaker: NA
Text: and excise tariffs which were announced in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1988 Budget relating to the method of

Speaker: NA
Text: duty collection on beer. Customs Tariff Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals No.5 (1989), operative on and from

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 January 1989, contains an alteration re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sulting from the Government's decision on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Industries Assistance Commission's re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port on transport contain-rs. The customs

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of duty has been reduced to free. Cus-

Speaker: NA
Text: toms Tariff Proposals No.6 (1989) and Ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: cise Tariff Proposals No.1 (1989), operative

Speaker: NA
Text: on and from 15 February 1989, contain al-

Speaker: NA
Text: terations to the customs and excise rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: duty applying to topped crude oil. These

Speaker: NA
Text: alterations clarify Government policy that

Speaker: NA
Text: topped crude oil for use as refinery feedstock

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to be duty free. Topped crude

Speaker: NA
Text: oil used otherwise will be subject to duty at

Speaker: NA
Text: a rate equivalent to that applying to fuel oil.

Speaker: NA
Text: Summaries of alterations contained in these

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals have been prepared and are being

Speaker: NA
Text: circulated for the information of honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members. I commend the proposals to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Moore)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: or held Morris) that we do not oppose the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that he has put to the Committee. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have pressed for the amendments in the Sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: Comate, as the Minister either mentioned or im-

Speaker: NA
Text: a plied. The record of the Government in this

Speaker: NA
Text: "fresh arena of taxation is not good. It has contin-

Speaker: NA
Text: land ually ridden roughshod over the taxpayer in

Speaker: NA
Text: an the pursuit of ever-increasing tax revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Added to that, the legislation has often been

Speaker: NA
Text: fresh needlessly complex and convoluted, thus

Speaker: NA
Text: to breaking one of the fundamental tenets of a

Speaker: NA
Text: origgood taxation system, that is, the need for

Text: simplicity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments before the Committee,

Speaker: NA
Text: the as I understand them, will at least bring back

Speaker: NA
Text: not be a little equity to the tax system. I had in-

Speaker: NA
Text: retended to refer to some of the details of the

Speaker: NA
Text: as a matters involved; I will not do so. I trust

Speaker: NA
Text: the that the Government, from the words used

Speaker: NA
Text: of the by the Minister, is picking up the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to clause 46, which will add to existing

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation affording automatic roll-over re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lief to asset transfers between spouses upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the breakdown of their marriage where the

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer is effected pursuant to an order of a

Speaker: NA
Text: court under the Family Law Act. The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Democrats and the Opposition have

Speaker: NA
Text: been arguing strongly for this amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Walsh, on behalf of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, claimed that the new amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: would have an adverse retrospective effect

Speaker: NA
Text: on some people, but he has produced noth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing but esoteric examples to show this. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has not displayed a case in which some would

Speaker: NA
Text: be hurt. Indeed, the Democrats' amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: was introduced on 8 November last year. If

Speaker: NA
Text: it does have a vague retrospective impact, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is incumbent on the Government, backed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the vast resources of the bureaucracy, to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: word the clause.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are pleased to support the other

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to clauses which have a retro-

Speaker: NA
Text: spective and other effect on capital gains. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is only because of the quick action of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition in most of these amendments-I

Speaker: NA
Text: give the Democrats credit for the one which

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned in a little more detail-that the

Speaker: NA
Text: inequities will be forestalled. I note that not

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone is so lucky. A recent Administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive Appeals Tribunal case on the original

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains tax legislation, which is being

Speaker: NA
Text: amended by Taxation Laws Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.3), found a gross case of retrospectiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity; that is, retrospectivity caused by Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment press release, about which I have talked

Speaker: NA
Text: in this Parliament on many occasions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me draw the Minister's attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: case No. 4825, in which the taxpayers en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered into a leasing arrangement with a pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol company on 13 March 1986. At that

Speaker: NA
Text: date the capital gains tax was operative fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing the announcement of the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Keating) on 19 September 1985, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the actual details of the imposition of capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax were unknown, and remained un-

Speaker: NA
Text: known until such time as the Bill was intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced into Parliament on 22 May. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want to take up the time of the Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having drawn the Government's attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to this matter, I ask it to look at it. Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: President Bannon, when delivering the rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons for his decision, stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The taxpayer and his wife appeared to me to be

Speaker: NA
Text: hard working Australian citizens who were in finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial difficulties . . . There is no element of tax

Speaker: NA
Text: avoidance in this case, only conflict with the new

Speaker: NA
Text: law. It is with regret that I reach the conclusion ...

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that some injustice has been done.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later legislation has not mirrored what was

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the press release, causing, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: words of the Deputy President, h-rdship.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are sure to be other examples, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: think his words speak for themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude by asking the Minister to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vey to the Treasurer the request that he

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an undertaking that the appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation will be amended so that other

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers will not be similarly subject to the

Speaker: NA
Text: retrospective impact of the capital gains tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regard this Government as a rapacious

Speaker: NA
Text: government. It hounds people for tax at all

Speaker: NA
Text: times. But generally, I think it would wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so only under the law. Where there

Speaker: NA
Text: are circumstances of a conflict in the law,

Speaker: NA
Text: even this heartless Government ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: moved to make amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Industrial Relations) (5.05)-1 think

Speaker: NA
Text: it is the ultimate hypocrisy to hear the Dep-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: speak about hounding people for tax. Yes,

Speaker: NA
Text: we hound tax cheats and the tax rogues that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition fostered and promoted--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale-Hey, come on!

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: record and read it, my friend. Yes, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: hounding those tax cheats, but within the

Speaker: NA
Text: limits of the law so that they pay their fair

Speaker: NA
Text: share of what they are properly required to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay just as all other honest wage and salary

Speaker: NA
Text: earners pay their share. We know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the Opposition, in government, was

Speaker: NA
Text: to foster the only growth industry it had-

Speaker: NA
Text: the growth of tax avoidance and tax evasion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to belabour the Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition any longer. The point made

Speaker: NA
Text: by Senator Walsh still stands. There may

Speaker: NA
Text: well be unintended consequences in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the amendment to clause 46-the moving

Speaker: NA
Text: of the date back from 28 January 1988, in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the exemption from capital gains

Speaker: NA
Text: tax for property settlements arising out of a

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage breakdown, to 20 September 1985.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems to me the amendment is based upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the expectation that, on the one hand, there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a surplus arising from the disposal of

Speaker: NA
Text: assets which could be the subject a property

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement. On the other hand, there could

Speaker: NA
Text: be losses involved. The property or busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses c.ould have been acquired post 20 Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember 1985, and a capital loss, arising out

Speaker: NA
Text: of a settlement, could have been incurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale-The lights are dimming on your

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, my friend.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member a long time ago. The

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of this amendment will be to preclude

Speaker: NA
Text: any capital loss, for the purposes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains tax, being taken into account

Speaker: NA
Text: for the benefit of one of the spouses, by

Speaker: NA
Text: backdating it to 20 September 1985. So it

Speaker: NA
Text: covers a period between September 1985 and

Speaker: NA
Text: January 1988. Be that as it may, the respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility for that lies at the feet of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sition. Given that the legislation has been

Speaker: NA
Text: amended by the Senate against our will, we

Speaker: NA
Text: in this place have no alternative but to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cept it. But let responsibility rest where it

Speaker: NA
Text: belongs: any consequences that flow out of

Speaker: NA
Text: this that are detrimental to the spouse con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned will be the responsibility of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: inequities.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: those remarks by the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition to the Treasurer as requested. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will ask the Treasurer to respond to him in

Speaker: NA
Text: writing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Resolution reported; report adopted.

Speaker: NA
Text: NAMIBIA

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: Mrs DARLING
Text: Lilley) (5.09)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) and his able

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting Ministers outlined earlier today

Speaker: NA
Text: the terms of Australian participation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping forces in Namibia. They said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Holsworthy based 17 Construction

Speaker: NA
Text: Squadron, and the Chief Engineer, Head-

Speaker: NA
Text: quarters, comprising 300 engineers and sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port staff, will leave for Namibia in March,

Speaker: NA
Text: with vehicles and equipment expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave by sea later this month.

Speaker: NA
Text: UNTAG, the United Nations Transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance Group, will monitor the imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation of the transition to independence

Speaker: NA
Text: for Namibia. It is appropriate, given Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's record in peacekeeping activities in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternationally, that our forces will be

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking non-combative duties. The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians will be involved mainly in road,

Speaker: NA
Text: bridge, airfield and accommodation construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and in the maintenance of power and

Speaker: NA
Text: water supplies for a 4,600 strong UN force.

Speaker: NA
Text: A field engineer element of the contingent

Speaker: NA
Text: will carry out min-field clearance. The troops

Speaker: NA
Text: will be in Namibia initially for 12 months,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a six-month tour of duty for contingent

Speaker: NA
Text: members.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is appropriate to note the bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the statement of the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister on this action and to say that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Oppofirst offered engineers for UNTAG in 1979.

Speaker: NA
Text: The offer was confirmed by the present Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in 1983 and again in September last

Speaker: NA
Text: year. I am one of two members of this House

Speaker: NA
Text: who were privileged to participate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian delegation to the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1988. I acknowledge the cooperation and

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution of my partner, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Moreton ( Mr Donald Cameron).

Speaker: NA
Text: . I wish to comment on the background to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's involvement in UN peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: forces and in particular the matter under

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion, Namibia, from a United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective. In doing this I would like to put

Speaker: NA
Text: on record the excellent performance of offi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cers of the Australian permanent mission to

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations in New York. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoys a high reputation in the United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and internationally owing to the integ-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity and the dynamism of the contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: of Ministers for Foreign Affairs and of our

Speaker: NA
Text: diplomats at the United Nations and mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions across the globe. It is important for us

Speaker: NA
Text: to remember this factor when we comment

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Prime Minister's statement today. It

Speaker: NA
Text: nas been a long, drawn out process in which

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibians have striven to gain their. inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence with the support of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations. It is important for us to recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is no sudden movement; it is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: long movement. The diplomats at the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent mission in New York have played a

Speaker: NA
Text: very strong part in our reaching this point.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is because of their contribution within the

Speaker: NA
Text: forum of the United Nations that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: reached this point. I particularly commend

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kevin Boreham, who is the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner of our mission and who takes

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for our contribution to peace-

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping forces generally, and Ms Mary

Speaker: NA
Text: Wickes, who is responsible for Namibia which

Speaker: NA
Text: is of one of the last vestiges of colonialism

Speaker: NA
Text: globally. Both of these people have been

Speaker: NA
Text: working with officers in the Department in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and with Ministers and have been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to put forward very strong points of

Speaker: NA
Text: view. They have fulfilled a bridging role be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween United Nations (UN) delegates rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resenting the superpowers. Australia, despite

Speaker: NA
Text: its smaller population, has most certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: been up front in this operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is a significant contributor to

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping operations. Apart from the as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessed contribution to UNIMOG, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations Military Observer Group, UNIFIL,

Speaker: NA
Text: the UN Interim Force in Lebanon, UNDOF,

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations Disengagement Observer

Speaker: NA
Text: Force, UNEF, the UN Emergency Force,

Speaker: NA
Text: and our voluntary annual contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: UNICEF, the UN International Children's

Speaker: NA
Text: Emergency Fund, Australia provides 20 po-

Speaker: NA
Text: lice to serve the UNFICYP, the United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 observers to the United Nations truce

Speaker: NA
Text: supervisory organisation and most recently

Speaker: NA
Text: we have joined other contributors in provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing 15 observers to UNIMOG. Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: reaffirmed our commitment to providing the

Speaker: NA
Text: engineering unit to UNT AG and we fully

Speaker: NA
Text: share the concern that burdens on contrib-

Speaker: NA
Text: uting countries should be minimised, partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ularly given the number of developing

Speaker: NA
Text: countries on which this burden is very heavy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's view is that UN members should

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in peacekeeping forces only for, a

Speaker: NA
Text: specified period of one term plus a possible

Speaker: NA
Text: second term. Australia will be guided by this

Speaker: NA
Text: principle in its participation in future peace-

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping forces, including UNTAG. UNTAG

Speaker: NA
Text: will monitor the cessation of hostilities by

Speaker: NA
Text: parties and the implementation of the tran- .

Speaker: NA
Text: sition to independence for Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the major points put forward by

Speaker: NA
Text: our delegation in New York was the annual

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of current and envisaged peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: operations, which is well above the annual

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of running the UN itself. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation takes a leading role in promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: greater cost effectiveness in UN bodies, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding the operation of the peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: forces. We believe that peacekeeping opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions should not be used to palliate regional

Speaker: NA
Text: problems or to delay their resolution. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is no substitute for the peaceful settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: of disputes. A member State should adhere

Speaker: NA
Text: strictly to the provisions of the UN charter

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the non-use of force. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: charter itself recognises, in providing for

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping operations, that these princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ples will sometimes break down. We must

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that the UN peacekeeping forces

Speaker: NA
Text: are one of the success stories of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations, as was recognised when that body

Speaker: NA
Text: was awarded the Nobel peace prize in 1988.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has had a particular interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of Namibia, which has been on

Speaker: NA
Text: the UN agenda since the very first session of

Speaker: NA
Text: the General Assembly in 1946. Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently supported the people of Nami-

Speaker: NA
Text: bia in their struggle for self-determination

Speaker: NA
Text: and independence, and we continue to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also persistently adhered to our

Speaker: NA
Text: belief that the implementation of proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in Security Council resolution 435

Speaker: NA
Text: of 1978 offers the best possible process and

Speaker: NA
Text: path to independence for Namibia. Today

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister has confirmed that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are ready to back our statements, made in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternationally and in the United Nations, with

Speaker: NA
Text: practical action. The history of Namibia's

Speaker: NA
Text: struggle for independence is long-far too

Speaker: NA
Text: long. After World War II, the UN requested

Speaker: NA
Text: that South Africa place the territory under

Speaker: NA
Text: UN trusteeship. South Africa refused and

Speaker: NA
Text: until recently the territory has been the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject of continuing dispute between South

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa and the United Nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The South West Africa People's Organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation (SW APO) has been fighting South

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa for the liberation of Namibia since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1972, from bases mainly in Angola. For over

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 years after South Africa agreed to take

Speaker: NA
Text: part in the UN package, aimed at easing

Speaker: NA
Text: all Namibia's peaceful transition to independ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence from the South African Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: that Government refused, for a variety of

Speaker: NA
Text: stated reasons, to come to the discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: table. At this stage I am presenting a major-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity view to the House: an opinion that was

Speaker: NA
Text: transmitted by a large number of people

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting in the General Assembly of the UN.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the UN agreed that the different par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties should discuss the problem to devise a

Speaker: NA
Text: practical means of withdrawing troops and

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring a peaceful transition to independ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence in Namibia, South Africa, whilst main-

Speaker: NA
Text: taining membership of the United Nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: ceased taking its place in the Assembly. It

Speaker: NA
Text: had taken its marbles and gone home. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was no delegate from South Africa in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations whereas there were delegates

Speaker: NA
Text: from all of the other parties, involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for a peaceful transition. Although Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position members have brought up other

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns, South Africa had to come to t-e

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion table if it was to demonstrate Its

Speaker: NA
Text: credibility and show that it wanted to find a

Speaker: NA
Text: peaceful solution. South Africa did not come

Speaker: NA
Text: to the table. However, I welcome the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that South Africa has now decided to coop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erate with the UN in the implementation of

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals for the independence of Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The signing of the Brazzaville protocol in

Speaker: NA
Text: late 1988 by South Africa, Cuba and Angola

Speaker: NA
Text: has formalised the acceptance by South Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: rica of resolution UNSCR 435 1978, which

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined a blueprint for the realisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: independence for. Namibia. The dat- set. for

Speaker: NA
Text: the implementation of the resolutIOn IS 1

Speaker: NA
Text: April 1989. Over the period of transition t?

Speaker: NA
Text: independence it is intended that South Afn-

Speaker: NA
Text: can troops will withdraw from Namibia, .Cu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ban troops will begin leaving Angola, Afncan

Speaker: NA
Text: National Congress camps will leave Angola

Speaker: NA
Text: and SWAPO will be allowed to participate

Speaker: NA
Text: in the elections for an independent govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Namibia to be held in November

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989. The UNTAG, along with civilian rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives will be deployed to Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: during the transitional period to assist in the

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of UNSCR 435.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been a committed member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the UN Council for Namibia since 1974.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have been an active participant in coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil and committee activities during that time

Speaker: NA
Text: and will continue to i be so. Australia will

Speaker: NA
Text: also continue its voluntary contributions to

Speaker: NA
Text: the UN Fund for Namibia. The time may

Speaker: NA
Text: be approaching when it will be necessary t?

Speaker: NA
Text: look more closely at the role of the Counctl

Speaker: NA
Text: for. Namibia, particularly if the ongoing ne-

Speaker: NA
Text: gotiations move to a successful conclusion. It

Speaker: NA
Text: may then become necessary to define in more

Speaker: NA
Text: detail the Council's role in the transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: period. The Bureau of the Council and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Office of the UN Commissioner for Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: have already turned their attention to these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. I grieve with other people the loss

Speaker: NA
Text: of the UN Commissioner who died in tragic

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances in the Lockerbie disaster. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian delegation is looking closely at th-

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in Namibia, the role of the Counctl

Speaker: NA
Text: and the office of the UN Commissioner and

Speaker: NA
Text: is ready to play a constructive and active

Speaker: NA
Text: role in any discussions.

Speaker: NA
Text: In September last year Australia had the

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure of welcoming a mission of consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation led by Council President Ambassador

Speaker: NA
Text: Peter Zuze, the first such mission to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia since 1984. That mission briefed the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government on the situation in Namibia,

Speaker: NA
Text: met with the parliamentary Joint Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: held talks with senior officials of a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of major government dep-rtments. I woul-

Speaker: NA
Text: like to take this opportumty to express thIS

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's gratitude for the demonstrated en-

Speaker: NA
Text: ergy and sense of purpose displayed by Am-

Speaker: NA
Text: bassador Zuze in leading the Council. We

Speaker: NA
Text: would certainly be looking to his continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: that leadership in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has played a key role in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area. I wish to bring to the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House the role played by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation to the UN in the matters which

Speaker: NA
Text: we are discussing today. I am sure the ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciation and best wishes of all -arliamen­

Speaker: NA
Text: tarians go with Colonel Warren, Lleutenant-

Speaker: NA
Text: Colonel Pippard, Major -rago and the ?-O

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians whom they WIll lead to NamIbIa

Speaker: NA
Text: in the interests of a peaceful transition to

Speaker: NA
Text: independence for the war-torn people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: MCPherson)(5.24)-As has

Speaker: NA
Text: already been indicated by the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition ( Mr Howard) and other spe-k.ers

Speaker: NA
Text: from this side of the House, the OppOSItion

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the deployment of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent to Namibia. M-mbers of .the c-n­

Speaker: NA
Text: tingent go with the best WIshes of thiS Parha-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the Australian people. While the

Speaker: NA
Text: position taken by the Opposition of agreeing

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Government, is somewhat unusual,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is pleasant and good to see. The Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment of 1978, which was formalised

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1979 has been reaffirmed by this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It is very much in Australia's inter-sts

Speaker: NA
Text: that we participate in these pe-cekeeplI-g

Speaker: NA
Text: operations around the world, particularly m

Speaker: NA
Text: the region in which we live.

Speaker: NA
Text: This deployment of troops will be difficult,

Speaker: NA
Text: as other speakers have said, and there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be occasions when it will be dangerous. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about an uncontrolled situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in which there may be a requirement for -ur

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers to defend themselves. We are talkmg

Speaker: NA
Text: about the clearance of mines in a climate of

Speaker: NA
Text: largely uncontrolled warfare that has gone

Speaker: NA
Text: on in Namibia for some years. Indeed, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about a dangerous operation. But

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian engineers are well trained and

Speaker: NA
Text: their expertise in these sorts of operations-

Speaker: NA
Text: for instance, in Vietnam-has been well

Speaker: NA
Text: noted. Some of the bravest men I have ever

Speaker: NA
Text: met were Australian engineers in Vietnam.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I have no doubts about their capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: do the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: From what has been said today by Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment spokesmen, the conditions of service

Speaker: NA
Text: under which our troops will be operating

Speaker: NA
Text: appear to be adequate. But we have to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: why it has been left to the last minute for

Speaker: NA
Text: these conditions of service· to be put on re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cord. The advance party goes next week and

Speaker: NA
Text: the troops a week or so after that. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have been carrying out training for all this

Speaker: NA
Text: time not knowing under which conditions of

Speaker: NA
Text: service they will be operating and what their

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits will be. It is not as though this

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment has been sprung on us by sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: prise. We have had this commitment since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978. The Government has eventually got

Speaker: NA
Text: around to deciding on the conditions of serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ice a week before the servicemen leave for

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia. As I understand it, the observers

Speaker: NA
Text: that we recently sent to the Persian Gulf in

Speaker: NA
Text: another form of peacekeeping operation did

Speaker: NA
Text: not even know until after they got there

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what their conditions of service were

Speaker: NA
Text: to be.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the general benefits and cOl!ditions

Speaker: NA
Text: of service may be. acceptable-and we will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to have a look at them in more detail-

Speaker: NA
Text: there is one matter which my colleague, the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Farrer ( Mr Tim

Speaker: NA
Text: Fischer), will take up in more detail, namely,

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of repatriation benefits. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: glad to see the Minister for Veterans' Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Humphreys) at, the table. Once again I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the Minister: how is it that a force that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been warned about overseas service for

Speaker: NA
Text: something like 10 years will be leaving this

Speaker: NA
Text: country presumably not knowing what its

Speaker: NA
Text: repatriation benefits will be when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: back? It is an absolute' disgrace that we

Speaker: NA
Text: expect our servicemen to go overseas not

Speaker: NA
Text: knowing under what conditions they are

Speaker: NA
Text: serving. I ask the Minister to use all his

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts to get this matter resolved before

Speaker: NA
Text: those men go. After 10 years, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has still not made up its mind. I really

Speaker: NA
Text: do not understand that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Department of Industrial Relations is

Speaker: NA
Text: interfering in regard to the general conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: that apply to this force. Apparently it is

Speaker: NA
Text: being given carte blanche to decide what

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions should apply to the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Defence. That in itself is something I find

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary. That is the reason, no doubt,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the long delays in getting this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: resolved. That is what happens when the

Speaker: NA
Text: government directs that the employment

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions of the Department of Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Australian Defence Force be decided

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Department of Industrial Relations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government can find the effort and the

Speaker: NA
Text: energy to make conditions and benefits rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonably attractive when soldiers, sailors and

Speaker: NA
Text: airmen actually have to go and do a job, but

Speaker: NA
Text: in times of peace, when it is thought they

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be required, the Government re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duces those benefits; it reduces the status of

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Defence Force to that of

Speaker: NA
Text: second class citizens. The Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: to wake up to itself. If it wants engineers, or

Speaker: NA
Text: anybody else, to go and do a job it has to

Speaker: NA
Text: look after them in times of peace as well. If

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not, at the end of the day, as is

Speaker: NA
Text: gradually happening now, it will not have

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone to do the job that the country ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pects of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian troops overseas, in war and in

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping operations, have a reputation

Speaker: NA
Text: second to none. I am quite sure that this

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent will maintain that record. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks ago I sought permission to visit the

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent at Holsworthy before it went. I

Speaker: NA
Text: got a most extraordinary letter from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister saying he did not think it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: convenient. I indicated that there was going

Speaker: NA
Text: to be one hell of a row about it, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister changed his mind. '

Speaker: NA
Text: The point I make is that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and Ministers do not own the Defence Force;

Speaker: NA
Text: the force is part and parcel of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community. The Government might be in

Speaker: NA
Text: temporary control, but if the shadow Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for defence, or anybody else, asks to go

Speaker: NA
Text: and farewell them, to wish them well and to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they know they have the support

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, it is certainly not up to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Defence to deny that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: > quest. I am pleased that the Minister's deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion has been changed. In fact, the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition and I and the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for defence personnel, Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Newman, will be visiting the contingent this

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday.

Speaker: NA
Text: The implications of this deployment to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia are quite widespread. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: some beneficial implications. It shows that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is playing its part in seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the peace around the world. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: be invaluable experience for our engineers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is a pity, certainly initially, that only

Speaker: NA
Text: engineers are going. I would have preferred

Speaker: NA
Text: to see a more balanced force where people

Speaker: NA
Text: from other corps got experience in these

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of operations and brought that experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence back into the different corps of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army. That is not to be. I understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem. The United Nations force has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be balanced and Australia agreed to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the engineer contingent, but I am disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed that the Government did not seek

Speaker: NA
Text: to change that commitment so that we could

Speaker: NA
Text: have provided a commitment of all arms.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other good thing about this is that we

Speaker: NA
Text: will see, perhaps not initially but eventually,

Speaker: NA
Text: reservists used as part of this contingent. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is very important at a time when the Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers are declining-when those that come

Speaker: NA
Text: in are leaving within 12 months-that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are given the opportunity to serve, as they

Speaker: NA
Text: should be, as the reserve component of one

Speaker: NA
Text: army. The Reserve and the Australian Def-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence Force have a great deal to offer. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunately, they are not being used properly.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some adverse implications. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clear that the manpower policies of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government have allowed our defence

Speaker: NA
Text: forces to run down. We have said that many

Speaker: NA
Text: times before. A defence force is not there

Speaker: NA
Text: just to sustain itself; it is there to do a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Look at the wide eyes and the looks of

Speaker: NA
Text: surprise on the faces of Government mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers when they are actually asked to do a

Speaker: NA
Text: job like providing a contingent for Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some 300 engineers are going this month,

Speaker: NA
Text: another 300 or so in six months and maybe

Speaker: NA
Text: another 300 after that. It will make life

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult, because of the shortage of man-

Speaker: NA
Text: power in the Australian Army, to fulfil all

Speaker: NA
Text: the commitments which should be fulfilled

Speaker: NA
Text: by it. A policy of wastage· and deliberate

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions in the manpower ceilings of units

Speaker: NA
Text: has brought this about. It is not as though

Speaker: NA
Text: this is going to be a one-off. The fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can expect more of these commitments,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in our own region, a region which

Speaker: NA
Text: is showing increasing signs of instability and

Speaker: NA
Text: in which we should be much more involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the other problems with this de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment is that, despite what the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment says, we all know that our commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: under the defence cooperation program will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be reduced. That is a great pity

Speaker: NA
Text: because that defence cooperation program,

Speaker: NA
Text: far from being reduced, should be greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded. It is Australia's demonstration that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is, and wants to be, involved in the region

Speaker: NA
Text: in which we live. It is time the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: came to grips with the isolationist policy it

Speaker: NA
Text: has followed, particularly in the last two

Speaker: NA
Text: years since the production of the White Pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: per, and threw it out of the window and

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'Yes, we are involved. This is our re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion; we are going to make a major contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to keeping the peace because that is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential to the security of this country'. One

Speaker: NA
Text: does not adopt these isolationist policies and

Speaker: NA
Text: sit back with a defence of mainland Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia concept and say, 'Come and get us if

Speaker: NA
Text: you can'. It is stupid, it is discredited, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is time it was changed.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the commitments we should have

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken last year and the year before was

Speaker: NA
Text: a reasonable commitment to the Persian Gulf.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly we have observers there now, but

Speaker: NA
Text: what was Australia's response when the war

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Persian Gulf was creating enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties for the Western world in particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar in the supply of oil, when international

Speaker: NA
Text: sea lanes of communication were being

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened? Under this Government the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse was, 'We will put some divers on

Speaker: NA
Text: stand-by in Perth'. A pathetic commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has to realise that Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia's contribution to these peacekeeping op-

Speaker: NA
Text: erations has to be made if we are to have

Speaker: NA
Text: any credibility in the Western world as a

Speaker: NA
Text: reliable ally.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have touched briefly on the role of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: servists. I am very pleased to see that two

Speaker: NA
Text: have been included in the initial contingent,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a promise of more to come. Once again,

Speaker: NA
Text: the implication of this deployment of troops

Speaker: NA
Text: is the reconsideration of the role of the Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serve. In Australia we have a very small '

Speaker: NA
Text: regular component but we have an enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: reservoir of reservists who have shown over

Speaker: NA
Text: the years that they are capable, with train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, of doing the job. What we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: realise is that they need to be told that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is their role and not be left withering on the

Speaker: NA
Text: shelf, with lack of equipment and lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: proper direction, looking for a job to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this context I would very much ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that the role of so many of the Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: units is the guarding of static facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: war break out. The Minister here last week-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I agree with him-came to the conclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion again that a major threat to the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian mainland was not likely. If that is so,

Speaker: NA
Text: why are we wasting all this money on Kan-

Speaker: NA
Text: garoo 89, for example, when we have this

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment, this requirement, to get more

Speaker: NA
Text: and more involved in our region? Why are

Speaker: NA
Text: we wasting $100m on Kangaroo 89, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: basically an exercise for the defence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian mainland, when the Minister is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently scouring the Defence Force for

Speaker: NA
Text: further cuts, such as another FI8 squadron

Speaker: NA
Text: to go, anFlll squadron to go, further man-

Speaker: NA
Text: power cuts, further ships to be taken out of

Speaker: NA
Text: service? It is a ridiculous concept. What I

Speaker: NA
Text: am saying is that the role of the Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: should be reconsidered so that it can play a

Speaker: NA
Text: more active part within the Defence Force.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion I just want to say this: Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment speakers this afternoon have con-

Speaker: NA
Text: demned the role of South Africa-and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that role is highly suspect. But it should

Speaker: NA
Text: be remembered, and I put it on the record,

Speaker: NA
Text: that for the last 10 years or so there have

Speaker: NA
Text: been 50,000 Cuban troops serving in Angola

Speaker: NA
Text: and Namibia, and it is about time the Cu-

Speaker: NA
Text: bans were given the condemnation the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment so freely gives to South Africa,

Speaker: NA
Text: which, after all, is going to supply a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of the logistic support for this force

Speaker: NA
Text: under very difficult circumstances.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Text: Hughes) (5.39)-1 do not

Speaker: NA
Text: propose to speak this afternoon for all my

Speaker: NA
Text: allotted time but it would be remiss of me if

Speaker: NA
Text: I were not to make some substantial com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment since I am the Federal member for the

Speaker: NA
Text: seat of Hughes, from which these troops will

Speaker: NA
Text: leave. I also speak in my capacity as the

Speaker: NA
Text: convener Qf the Government members' def-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence forces action committee, so I have a

Speaker: NA
Text: very special interest in the subject matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate. I do not propose to descend into

Speaker: NA
Text: petty party point scoring and to demean this

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion, as I believe the shadow Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for defence, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCPherson ( Mr White), has done, but rather

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak about what I believe are the high-

Speaker: NA
Text: minded principles, the idealism and commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to a peaceful and more secure world

Speaker: NA
Text: which lie at the heart of the debate before

Speaker: NA
Text: the House this afternoon.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I make the comment that we on

Speaker: NA
Text: should this side of the chamber, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people and the defence forces and their fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ilies in this country will start to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition seriously when it debates defence

Speaker: NA
Text: policy and does two things. That will be,

Speaker: NA
Text: first, when the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCPherson is elevated to the shadow Cabi-

Speaker: NA
Text: net. At the moment he really is not regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: as a prominent member of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and, for that reason, defence has been effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively downgraded in the eyes of service per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonnel and their families. The second thing

Speaker: NA
Text: that has to be done for the Opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: gain any credibility at all in matters pertain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to defence is for it somehow to manage

Speaker: NA
Text: to reconcile the massive inconsistencies be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the expressed fiscal policies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and the very bland assurances

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have from the shadow Minister on

Speaker: NA
Text: defence expenditure. Having said that, I make

Speaker: NA
Text: . it very clear that I believe this is a debate

Speaker: NA
Text: that ought to rally all the Parliament around

Speaker: NA
Text: the single call of support for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force. To the very great credit of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard)

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke), they

Speaker: NA
Text: managed to do just that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We, in the Australian Labor Party, are

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely proud of our contribution, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: country, to the United Nations, since the

Speaker: NA
Text: formation of that very important body.

Speaker: NA
Text: People sometimes forget the role that Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Evatt played in the conference in San Fran-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisco in April 1945 at which he was a driving

Speaker: NA
Text: force for reform and for the strengthening of

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations charter. Even the New

Speaker: NA
Text: York Times recorded, when Dr Evatt finally

Speaker: NA
Text: left that conference, that he had arrived as

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually an unknown single, second-string

Speaker: NA
Text: delegate with the background of a professor

Speaker: NA
Text: and Labor politician but left recognised as

Speaker: NA
Text: the most brilliant and effective voice of the

Speaker: NA
Text: small powers: he was a leading statesman for

Speaker: NA
Text: the world's conscience. Dr Evatt's contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was not just a contribution for his party

Speaker: NA
Text: and his ideals: it was a contribution for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The peacekeeping contingent that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: sending to Namibia is, as I have indicated,

Speaker: NA
Text: something from which all Australians can

Speaker: NA
Text: take great pride. In his speech to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: this afternoon, the Prime Minister talked

Speaker: NA
Text: about the concerns that had existed, about

Speaker: NA
Text: the arc of instability stretching from south-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Africa through the Persian Gulf, through

Speaker: NA
Text: Afghanistan and southern Asia on to Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: China. He said-and I commend him for his

Speaker: NA
Text: vision-that we now see if not an arc of

Speaker: NA
Text: peace at least an arc of peacemaking. We,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Government of this country, are very

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to be associated with that initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: The previous speakers in this debate have

Speaker: NA
Text: talked at very great length about the very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant details of the contribution being

Speaker: NA
Text: made to the peacekeeping force. Suffice it to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that almost one-half of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Army capability will be participating in that

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping force. Having had the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity, some considerable time ago, to visit

Speaker: NA
Text: the troqps that will be going to Namibia and

Speaker: NA
Text: to see the vehicles and the heavy equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: painted with the United Nations logo in

Speaker: NA
Text: white, I was extremely proud to see that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia could participate in that way to

Speaker: NA
Text: work towards the creation of a better world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, it is not the first time that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have participated in that way. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: long history of participation going right back

Speaker: NA
Text: to 1947 and 1950. I mention our participa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on the UN Committee for Indonesia,

Speaker: NA
Text: our contribution to the Balkans and our

Speaker: NA
Text: presence in the Sinai. The list goes on. I

Speaker: NA
Text: stress that the participation in those efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: has generally been with the bipartisan sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port of the Parliament as a whole.

Speaker: NA
