Text: As the Prime Minister indicated, the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: of Namibia has been on the international

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda for 70 years. It is a credit to the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: that, finally, a tortuous path to the resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: of that conflict and occupation in Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: has finally been negotiated. The goal of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dependence and self-determination for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Namibia is a cause that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: long been very proud to be associated with.

Speaker: NA
Text: I must say that, when the shadow Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for defence referred to the· South African

Speaker: NA
Text: role as highly suspect, I thought he was

Speaker: NA
Text: mildly understating by a factor of about 100

Speaker: NA
Text: the South African role of occupation over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 70 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer-And the Cuban role.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Text: And the Cuban role. My

Speaker: NA
Text: position is straight down the middle. My

Speaker: NA
Text: great regret is that that support for inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence and self-determination is not ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: parently shared by that one speaker within

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: I particularly want to comment on the

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions of service of the personnel. Here

Speaker: NA
Text: again, it is a pity that the debate was low-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered to a party partisan contribution. It seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to me that all the Parliament ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied with the conditions that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: secured for service personnel. The shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister took us back to 1978 and expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: concern that, through all that time, nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: had been done to resolve the precise condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of service. I knew that we were often

Speaker: NA
Text: called on by the Opposition to answer for its

Speaker: NA
Text: version of the sins of our Government but I

Speaker: NA
Text: did not really think that we were responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: for taking the knocks for the actions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser Government back in 1978. Be that as

Speaker: NA
Text: it may, as the convener of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: members defence forces action committee, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been determined, along with my Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues representing defence constituen-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies, to ensure that the conditions of service

Speaker: NA
Text: of these troops were second to none.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very pleased that the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Science and Personnel ( Mrs Kelly),

Speaker: NA
Text: who shared our concern, has been successful

Speaker: NA
Text: in arguing the case for justice and fairness

Speaker: NA
Text: for these troops and their families. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Armed Forces Federation and its

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal President, Mr Bob Copley, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased with the result because they too

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly supported the conditions of service.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not propose to talk in detail about those

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions of service because they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to by a number of speakers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of this debate but I believe that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will meet with wide support. Those condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are not some form of charity; they are

Speaker: NA
Text: the right for those service personnel-and

Speaker: NA
Text: the families-because their lives are on the

Speaker: NA
Text: line. Even up to 1985, some 650 personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: had lost their lives in the United Nations·

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping forces. Of course, that figure is

Speaker: NA
Text: higher now. When they go to Namibia, our

Speaker: NA
Text: own servicemen will, in many cases, be

Speaker: NA
Text: working in dangerous areas. It is their right

Speaker: NA
Text: to have adequate support and their families'

Speaker: NA
Text: right to ensure that they have adequate sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port and remuneration commensurate with

Speaker: NA
Text: their responsibilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude on this note: we have a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal to be pleased about in the advance that

Speaker: NA
Text: the region and the world are making in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect of Namibia. It is indeed a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: step for the resolution of a conflict that has

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened that region and, at times, the

Speaker: NA
Text: wider planet. In South Africa there still re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mains a further blot on the international

Speaker: NA
Text: landscape. It is my hope that, in the years

Speaker: NA
Text: to pass, we will be able to stand as members

Speaker: NA
Text: of Parliament in this chamber and support

Speaker: NA
Text: an active United Nations role in resolving

Speaker: NA
Text: the problems of South Africa.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: Farrer) (5.49)-It

Speaker: NA
Text: is time to inject some reality into this debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: By virtue of the statement of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Hawke), the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: committed some 300 Australian soldiers to a

Speaker: NA
Text: distant part of the African continent. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: the commitment is to the west coast of the

Speaker: NA
Text: African continent, to that war-torn country

Speaker: NA
Text: of Namibia which adjoins Angola, Zambia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Zimbabwe, Botswana and, of course, South

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa. Let there be no doubt about the

Speaker: NA
Text: deadly seriousness of the situation faced by

Speaker: NA
Text: these Australian diggers heading off to that

Speaker: NA
Text: distant land in 1989. In one sense, it is his-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory repeating itself. Whilst the guerilla war-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare has waxed and waned over recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: with the presence of large numbers of Cuban

Speaker: NA
Text: guerillas and troops from various other coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries, including South Africa, the reality is

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are still lingering remnants of that

Speaker: NA
Text: guerilla war.

Speaker: NA
Text: Equally, there are minefields which :will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be addressed by the Australian con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tingent. I have to tell the House that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: chilling terror to have to work in any way,

Speaker: NA
Text: shape or form in an operational sense with

Speaker: NA
Text: minefields-entering minefields and clearing

Speaker: NA
Text: areas which were mined during the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: that terrorist war. It can be the most peace-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful, tranquil scene, but that can be tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed in a matter of just one second to

Speaker: NA
Text: instant death or massive injury, -and horrific

Speaker: NA
Text: situations can arise very quickly when mines

Speaker: NA
Text: are detonated in the process of clearing

Speaker: NA
Text: minefields and passing through areas near to

Speaker: NA
Text: where the mines have been sown. It certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: requires absolute professionalism, and I have

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt that members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Army will be providing that absolute profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionalism with our commitment in the course

Speaker: NA
Text: of the next month or so when they go to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia. I just feel that the House, sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: here in this remote location of Canberra in

Speaker: NA
Text: this wonderful new Parliament House, ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be aware, in terms of this debate, that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are committing Australian soldiers to quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerous situation. The real element of

Speaker: NA
Text: danger will not emerge perhaps ilntil after

Speaker: NA
Text: the first tour of duty over the first six months

Speaker: NA
Text: has been completed. Therefore, it is some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that the House should not do lightly.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of the historical context of a

Speaker: NA
Text: debate of a similar nature, I went back

Speaker: NA
Text: through Hansard to find the debates relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to the original commitment of an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: force to Vietnam. I remind the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Robert Menzies, as Prime Minister, made

Speaker: NA
Text: a similar type of ministerial statement on 29

Speaker: NA
Text: April 1965. Having made that statement,

Speaker: NA
Text: having revealed the invitation and having

Speaker: NA
Text: announced the decision of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to send a force to Vietnam, that

Speaker: NA
Text: was followed on 4 May by a reply by the

Speaker: NA
Text: then Leader of the Opposition, the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Melbourne, Mr Arthur Cal-

Speaker: NA
Text: well. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, on behalf of all my colleagues of Her

Speaker: NA
Text: Majesty's Opposition, I say that we oppose the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's decision to send 800 men to fight in Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: nam. We oppose it firmly and compietely.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a matter of record in this debate this

Speaker: NA
Text: day with the sending of this contingent to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia that the Federal Government on

Speaker: NA
Text: the one hand, and the Federal Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: on the other hand, are extending bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: support to the contingent. That is in very

Speaker: NA
Text: sharp contrast to the way in which 800 Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians were sent to Vietnam under that

Speaker: NA
Text: original ministerial statement in 1965. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, a very divisive period ensued. At no

Speaker: NA
Text: stage did those of us sent to Vietnam enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: the unanimous support which, happily, these

Speaker: NA
Text: troops going to Namibia will enjoy conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quent upon this bipartisan support indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: in the course of this debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should perhaps just look for a moment

Speaker: NA
Text: at the country of Namibia. It is on the south-

Speaker: NA
Text: C west coast of Africa and has an area of some

Speaker: NA
Text: 824,269 square kilometres. It lies, as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said, in south-west Africa with South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: to the south and south-east, Botswana to the

Speaker: NA
Text: east and Angola to the north. The territory

Speaker: NA
Text: has a long coastline on the Atlantic Ocean.

Speaker: NA
Text: Significantly, there are a number of key eth-

Speaker: NA
Text: nic groups of quite large size, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ovambo of 587,000 and the Kavango of

Speaker: NA
Text: 110,000, with a total population of 1,184,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia has at various stages in recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: had over 100,000 troops of one kind or an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other, including a Cuban contingent of guer-

Speaker: NA
Text: illas, forces from South Africa and the local

Speaker: NA
Text: army raised by the then South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration under a national service

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme which was introduced a few short

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago. It is a war ravaged land and a

Speaker: NA
Text: land where mines have been sown. It does

Speaker: NA
Text: require a great deal of help as it moves along

Speaker: NA
Text: the path to independence and, hopefully, to

Speaker: NA
Text: workable democracy. Australia clearly has a

Speaker: NA
Text: vital role to play. I would join with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke), the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition ( Mr Howard) and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers in wishing our contingent well.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, it is I!.bsolutely essential that

Speaker: NA
Text: those who are going know exactly on what

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds and conditions they will be going to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia, how they will be protected, and

Speaker: NA
Text: what arrangements will be made for their

Speaker: NA
Text: next of kin in the event of injury or death.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we have now learnt during the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate, that has not been spelt out in

Speaker: NA
Text: detail at this stage by the Government. What

Speaker: NA
Text: has been said is that a number of the condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions providing for a tax free situation for

Speaker: NA
Text: the contingent have been approved, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome and support,along with certain day

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances and so forth for these troops who

Speaker: NA
Text: will be divided into two basic groups, a head-

Speaker: NA
Text: quarters group back in the Namibian capital

Speaker: NA
Text: and another one towards the northern bor-

Speaker: NA
Text: der. That is acceptable, but the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has stopped short of resolving the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: with regard to repatriation cover or peace-

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping force cover under part IV of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Entitlements Act or whether there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a declaration of operational service

Speaker: NA
Text: or not. That has not yet been resolved, not-

Speaker: NA
Text: withstanding the fact that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: knew for some time that this debate was

Speaker: NA
Text: coming up, that it knew for an even longer

Speaker: NA
Text: period that the commitment was coming up

Speaker: NA
Text: and that there had been lengthy discussions

Speaker: NA
Text: about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to the Minister at the table, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Veterans' Affairs ( Mr Hum-

Speaker: NA
Text: phreys), that he has an absolute obligation,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the interests of fair play and in the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ests of this Parliament and this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: before the contingent leaves Australian soil

Speaker: NA
Text: to go to Africa, to resolve this in clear cut

Speaker: NA
Text: terms and do the right thing by those being

Speaker: NA
Text: sent overseas. It is a very serious decision

Speaker: NA
Text: and one which obviously has not been taken

Speaker: NA
Text: lightly. Equally, the arrangements for their

Speaker: NA
Text: repatriation and their care in the event of

Speaker: NA
Text: injury and/or death have to be spelt out. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the Minister, in conjunction with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Defence Science and Per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonnel ( Mrs Kelly), will finalise these ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements before the Ides of March so that

Speaker: NA
Text: the troops will know in clear-cut terms where

Speaker: NA
Text: they stand. Certainly my colleagues, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard); the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Minister for defence, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCPherson ( Mr White); and the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Minister for defence support, Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor Newman, who are all visiting the unit

Speaker: NA
Text: next Sunday, share those concerns, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: assure the Minister that we will be pressing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government for a clear-cut statement

Speaker: NA
Text: before our soldiers go to conditions in Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: which are going to be very uncertain. These

Speaker: NA
Text: matters need to be resolved.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two other brief areas I would

Speaker: NA
Text: mention. Presumably, the forces will be eli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gible for the new Australian Service Medal.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a great pity that I have to tell the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that 25 years after that speech by

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert Gordon Menzies committing troops

Speaker: NA
Text: to Vietnam there is still a major dispute in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the granting of the Vietnam Serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ice Medal to those who served on HMAS

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney and other logistical support ships. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has still not been resolved after 2t decades.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do hope that this contingent will qualify

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Australian Service Medal and that

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be clear-cut and will be covered in

Speaker: NA
Text: the summation. Finally, let me say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence service home loan eligibility, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is normally granted to those who go forward

Speaker: NA
Text: in the service of their country with the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Army, Royal Australian Navy and

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Air Force, has been with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn for enlistees who have enlisted since

Speaker: NA
Text: May 1985. To be fair, they would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: truly eligible until they had completed six

Speaker: NA
Text: years of service. We now have a situation

Speaker: NA
Text: where this quite large contingent of 300

Speaker: NA
Text: troops is going forward, and again there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt as to whether they will be eligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence service home loans scheme, which

Speaker: NA
Text: might otherwise be termed the defence serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ice caravan loans scheme, as its value has

Speaker: NA
Text: been static for nine years at a mere $25,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Notwithstanding the fact that its value has

Speaker: NA
Text: been eroded, surely those going to Africa in

Speaker: NA
Text: this contingent should have an eligibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence service home loans scheme, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope the Government will clarify this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Humphreys-What are you going to

Speaker: NA
Text: put it up to?

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: The Minister has the

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility, under the terms of his

Speaker: NA
Text: oath of office as Minister for Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, with regard to this contingent going

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australia to Africa. He must answer

Speaker: NA
Text: the people. and to that contingent and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families with regard to their repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements. Hopefully, there will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: juries; hopefully there will be no deaths.

Speaker: NA
Text: we have heard the Minister say that there

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be an expectation of some casualties.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is a deadly serious business that

Speaker: NA
Text: House is about this afternoon here in Canoverseas

Speaker: NA
Text: berra, removed from the realities of the Afdanger

Speaker: NA
Text: rican situation or the tensions of a unit

Speaker: NA
Text: preparing for embarkation from Holsworthy,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, to Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remind the House that we have very

Speaker: NA
Text: serious obligations that we owe those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to serve our country yet again.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely it is the obligation of each and every

Speaker: NA
Text: member, and above all the Minister for Vettions

Speaker: NA
Text: erans' Affairs, to see that

Speaker: NA
Text: are fully honoured. I wish our contingent

Speaker: NA
Text: well in terms of its work and service on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of Australia.

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Text: Warringah) (6.02)- matter

Speaker: NA
Text: If we look back 10 years almost to the day,

Speaker: NA
Text: we find in the Australian Financial Review

Speaker: NA
Text: of 22 February 1979 the following report of

Speaker: NA
Text: a speech by the then Prime Minister, Mr the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser:

Speaker: NA
Text: We will offer an engineer contingent of 250 officers

Speaker: NA
Text: and men together with a national headquarters and

Speaker: NA
Text: support element of 50 to Namibia or to the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: force to go and supervise-

Speaker: NA
Text: hopefully, at that stage--....:

Speaker: NA
Text: the transition of Namibia to an in(\ependent state.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, that did not happen at that

Speaker: NA
Text: stage and now, 10 years down the line, we

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the present Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke)

Speaker: NA
Text: reiterating those comments almost in identi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal terms. Naturally enough, we on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House support the Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government in the decision that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has taken in committing Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian troops to the role that they will have

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United Nations (UN) force in

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The role of Australian forces in peacetime

Speaker: NA
Text: but in difficult circumstances is one which

Speaker: NA
Text: they have filled with great distinction in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past. I notice that the Prime Minister said

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise is likely to last about a year. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the light of previous experience, I hope he is

Speaker: NA
Text: right. But I doubt whether he will be correct

Speaker: NA
Text: in the belief that it will be for only a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: to As I have said, the Opposition supports the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision, but it does show up in rather

Speaker: NA
Text: armarked contrast the very poor decision of

Speaker: NA
Text: inthe Government in a previous year in remov-

Speaker: NA
Text: But ing the Australian contingent to the multi-

Speaker: NA
Text: national force in the Sinai. I think there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal to be gained for serving men in

Speaker: NA
Text: this the Australian armed forces to have some

Speaker: NA
Text: experience. Whilst there is very real

Speaker: NA
Text: involved, particularly in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: current decision, I think it does provide op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunities for Australian defence personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: to experience conditions outside Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and to put their training to a very real test.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, I do not think for a moment

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian troops involved will not

Speaker: NA
Text: discharge their duties in the highest tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Services and forces

Speaker: NA
Text: those obligations over the years.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some things that worry me about

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision. I remember when 10 years ago

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government of the day was discussing a

Speaker: NA
Text: before it came to a decision. A report

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Canberra Times of 16 January 1979,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the decision was being canvassed, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government at this stage has been warned that

Speaker: NA
Text: Army is too thinly spread to carry out the duties

Speaker: NA
Text: with which it is charged with as well as mount major

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas commitments even of a passive kind.

Speaker: NA
Text: If that was the case in 1979, how much more

Speaker: NA
Text: so is it the case today? We all know of the

Speaker: NA
Text: parlous situation in relation to the retention

Speaker: NA
Text: of trained Service personnel within the armed

Speaker: NA
Text: forces in Australia. I note the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are going to be involved in this

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise in Namibia. According to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's speech:

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very large and important commitment for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, comprising almost half-

Speaker: NA
Text: almost half-

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Army's construction engineering capability.

Speaker: NA
Text: Careful planning, including the use of Reservists,

Speaker: NA
Text: been required to ensure that high-priority engineering

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks closer to home can still be performed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope he is correct. I very much doubt it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think we can truthfully say that al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though we will allocate almost half of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Army's construction and engi-

Speaker: NA
Text: neering capability to an overseas commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, particularly one in Namibia, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a long way away, we can at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time say that we are in a position to carry

Speaker: NA
Text: out, and we will carry out, those tasks which

Speaker: NA
Text: confront us both in Australia and in our

Speaker: NA
Text: more immediate environs. I think that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very pious hope, and I would like to see it

Speaker: NA
Text: more carefully analysed. I think it points out

Speaker: NA
Text: once again the condition with which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian defence forces find themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: confronted under the continuing policies of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government. The Prime Minister said

Speaker: NA
Text: he was pleased:

Speaker: NA
Text: - . . that it has been possible to minimise the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the deployment on support to the opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional deployment force, exercise Kangaroo 89, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence cooperation program in the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific ...

Speaker: NA
Text: This was reiterated by the Minister for Def-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence ( Mr Beazley) in his contribution to this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. Again I say that on the sheer facts

Speaker: NA
Text: of the situation it really does leave us very

Speaker: NA
Text: thin on the ground, particularly in this most

Speaker: NA
Text: important area of the engineering and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction capability of the Services. I make

Speaker: NA
Text: that comment again mindful of the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the region in which we live is not as stable

Speaker: NA
Text: as was the case in the past, and certainly is

Speaker: NA
Text: not as stable as we would like to see it.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been situations in recent years,

Speaker: NA
Text: which we can all bring to mind instantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: which have confronted Australia with some

Speaker: NA
Text: questions which so far, thank goodness, have

Speaker: NA
Text: not required us to mobilise the defence forces

Speaker: NA
Text: in any significant way. But given the sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: uation in the South Pacific and in areas to

Speaker: NA
Text: our north, it is not impossible to envisage a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation which would require the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: defence forces to be utilised in a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity than has been the case in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already mentioned the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: almost half of our engineering capacity and

Speaker: NA
Text: capability is going to be involved in this

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise in Namibia, and that makes me really

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about the continuing policy which

Speaker: NA
Text: has this Government is going to direct towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian defence forces. I support the

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment of these troops. I think the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have made this commitment really

Speaker: NA
Text: should concentrate the minds of the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Government in relation to its

Speaker: NA
Text: defence policies generally, so that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: look to have a Defence Force capability

Speaker: NA
Text: which is properly aligned with the potential

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities which it may be required to

Speaker: NA
Text: fulfil in our own area.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some other aspects of the deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion which have been touched on by my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues. I particularly mention the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing words of the Prime Minister:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has also ensured that members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian contingent be adequately compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sated for the hardships and dangers they will face

Speaker: NA
Text: through a comprehensive and generous set of condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of service, including the payment of special

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Naturally enough, I support that. He

Speaker: NA
Text: continued:

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) will be

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking an amendment to the Income Tax Assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Act to exempt the pay and allowances earned

Speaker: NA
Text: by Defence Force personnel while they are on tour

Speaker: NA
Text: with UNTAG. Repatriation benefits appropriate to

Speaker: NA
Text: the tasks and hazards encountered will also be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: In providing those benefits-which I sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port-I hope that other service personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: who have served in previous commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: will not' be overlooked. It would be most

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair if Defence Force personIlel who have

Speaker: NA
Text: served Australia with distinction in previous

Speaker: NA
Text: times were disadvantaged in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: special benefits which appear to be going to

Speaker: NA
Text: be made for these service personnel going to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Overall, as we have heard, the forces in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved will be facing a most serious task. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be a holiday experience for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will be going to play a most significant

Speaker: NA
Text: role in, amongst other things, mine clearing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anybody who has the slightest comprehen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of the difficulties and dangers involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in that sort of exercise will understand

Speaker: NA
Text: the troops will face very real dangers.

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in the area to which they are being

Speaker: NA
Text: sent is an unstable· one. These servicemen

Speaker: NA
Text: will face real dangers. They will playa most

Speaker: NA
Text: significant role in the overall combination

Speaker: NA
Text: which is being put together by the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations. Their tasks will be highly signifiincome

Speaker: NA
Text: cant. I, along with all member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, wish them well in the confident belief

Speaker: NA
Text: that they will maintain the very highest

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions of Australian Defence Force personand

Speaker: NA
Text: nel serving overseas.

Speaker: Mr STEELE HALL
Text: Boothby) (6.12)-1

Speaker: NA
Text: support the proposition to commit Austrament

Speaker: NA
Text: lian troops to Namibia for peacekeeping pursmaller

Speaker: NA
Text: poses with mixed feelings. It is not a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: area of Australia's making. It involves the

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement of wars caused through other

Speaker: NA
Text: people's interests. Certainly I support the

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks that have been made here today in

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing to the attention of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence ( Mr Beazley) and the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that the lives and the welfare of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's contingent should be protected

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever possible. The cause is worthwhile

Speaker: NA
Text: because world politics have altered so much.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have now seen the retreat of those

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which have been supported by Ruswent

Speaker: NA
Text: sian interests around the world-a retreat

Speaker: NA
Text: from interfering by force and by the supply

Speaker: NA
Text: of arms from outside countries. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that it is the current agreements which

Speaker: NA
Text: have obviously been made-quietly at times

Speaker: NA
Text: and sometimes publicly-which have led

Speaker: NA
Text: this opportunity in Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: So Australia can join in this initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: knowing that it is not simply a one-off situthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ation in the sense of this country in isolation

Speaker: NA
Text: being involved in preparations for demohas

Speaker: NA
Text: cratic government arising out of a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of internal turmoil and warfare but, rather,

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is part of a move around the world

Speaker: NA
Text: to establish order in place of the anarchy

Speaker: NA
Text: and armed conflict that has been occurring.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians can feel pleased indeed that

Speaker: NA
Text: is taking place in their own hemisphere,

Speaker: NA
Text: Southern Hemisphere, in a continent that

Speaker: NA
Text: may be far removed from us but which

Speaker: NA
Text: important to us.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the early part of last year, I made

Speaker: NA
Text: very short visit to Namibia, involving one

Speaker: NA
Text: day and one night at Windhoek. Whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: was short, it enabled me to form a few

Speaker: NA
Text: that conclusions, some of which I believe may

Speaker: NA
Text: The have been right. But the major conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: which I formed was very wrong. Windhoek,

Speaker: NA
Text: the capital of Namibia, is a modern city with

Speaker: NA
Text: modern amenities, which is able to support

Speaker: NA
Text: its society and which has a very good stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard of living for those who enjoy a good

Speaker: NA
Text: and a good lifestyle in Namibia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: Opporemember going to the museum of natural

Speaker: NA
Text: history and being amazed at the extent to

Speaker: NA
Text: trawhich it showed the history of the peoples

Speaker: NA
Text: the geographic development of that

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The contrasts were extreme. Their Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: House is a modern building-much

Speaker: NA
Text: than this but of no less quality. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was quite amazing to view the galleries and

Speaker: NA
Text: the lobbies of that Parliament House, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structed with so many adornments of local

Speaker: NA
Text: art, with magnificent murals of the animals

Speaker: NA
Text: that migrate across the plains of Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: That contrasted so much to the armed forces

Speaker: NA
Text: which are so evident in the streets of Wind-

Speaker: NA
Text: hoek. They were there in force, moving about

Speaker: NA
Text: in their sixes and dozens, obviously on the

Speaker: NA
Text: way to the war somewhere in the north of

Speaker: NA
Text: that country or in Angola. South African

Speaker: NA
Text: eletroops were very evident indeed. When we

Speaker: NA
Text: into, say, a paper shop-there are very

Speaker: NA
Text: modern shops in that city-we were frisked

Speaker: NA
Text: at the door for arms. Yet what a normal

Speaker: NA
Text: no scene it was in the local pet shop, where

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian cockatiels were for sale at 26 rand

Speaker: NA
Text: a pair. It is a city of contrasts which no

Speaker: NA
Text: to doubt would have extended further if one

Speaker: NA
Text: had time to look at life in Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The conclusion I made, after looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities there and the obviously very

Speaker: NA
Text: high quality infrastructure that South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: built there-in the form of public build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings, transportation and the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture, dry though the country may be

Speaker: NA
Text: by current standards-was that South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: would not get out; that it would not allow

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia its freedom. I made that conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: this last June and within a few months I was

Speaker: NA
Text: the proven very wrong indeed. South Africa has

Speaker: NA
Text: now agreed to negotiations to establish par-

Speaker: NA
Text: is liamentary democracy in that country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I guess that what has caught so many of

Speaker: NA
Text: a us by surprise-perhaps even South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: itself-has been the obviously open or tacit

Speaker: NA
Text: it agreements reached between the two major

Speaker: NA
Text: power groups in the world. The different.

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude of the comml:'nist world, -s. it is

Speaker: NA
Text: being squeezed economlCall- t- a pO-ItIO';l of

Speaker: NA
Text: some reality in regard to Its IntrusIon Into

Speaker: NA
Text: other parts of the world, into outside spheres

Speaker: NA
Text: of influence, has led to this sort of -gree­

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It is very pleasing indeed that It has

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred. If one looks at the opposing forces,

Speaker: NA
Text: one sees an agreement which has been ham-

Speaker: NA
Text: mered out of a warfare conducted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: left of the left in the sense of the Cuban

Speaker: NA
Text: troops to the north and Angola and, in some

Speaker: NA
Text: ways, the very fascist organisation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: South African Government. There could

Speaker: NA
Text: hardly be two greater extremes in the world

Speaker: NA
Text: today. Therefore, one would have thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that their conflict would have been more

Speaker: NA
Text: deeply carried on into the future. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: greater powers that be have b-en. able t.o

Speaker: NA
Text: establish this agreement by negotiation. ThIs

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps heralds much greater optimism for

Speaker: NA
Text: the world than has been warranted until

Speaker: NA
Text: now.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very pleased to support this move

Speaker: NA
Text: involving Australian troops. I simply end by

Speaker: NA
Text: reaffirming that support by saying that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure they will be sensibly led. As has been

Speaker: NA
Text: stated here today, I hope they are led with

Speaker: NA
Text: a view to preserving their welfare. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: not want to see Australian troops injured or

Speaker: NA
Text: killed while involved in someone else's war,

Speaker: NA
Text: a war that has not been constructed by or

Speaker: NA
Text: contributed to by Australia. If that manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of our troops involved is maintained, I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the great prestige -hich they en-oy

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world and their capacIty as AustralIan

Speaker: NA
Text: service people to perform will be matched

Speaker: NA
Text: by a sensible oversight of their activities to

Speaker: NA
Text: the degree that their welfare is safeguarded

Speaker: NA
Text: so that they can return home to Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: soil.

Speaker: Mr HALVERSON
Text: Casey) (6.l9)-Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore beginning my speech, I warmly endorse

Speaker: NA
Text: the comments of my colleagues the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Warringah ( Mr MACKellar)

Speaker: NA
Text: and the honourable member for Boothby

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Steele Hall) on this important topic.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today, many of those speaking have .looked

Speaker: NA
Text: at the contribution of Australian serVIcemen

Speaker: NA
Text: in this rather desolate part of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we have not really seen thus far is a

Speaker: NA
Text: clear indication of the background to our

Speaker: NA
Text: very real commitment .to -am-bia. I .thought

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be worth whIle In thIS cloSIng part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the debate examining the reasons that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are about to serve in this very

Speaker: NA
Text: challenging part of southern Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia, as many honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: who have contributed to this debate have

Speaker: NA
Text: already said, formerly known as So.uth West

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa, is a vast, 824,000 squ-re kIlometres,

Speaker: NA
Text: arid mineral-rich African terntory, bordered

Speaker: NA
Text: to the north by Angola and to the south and

Speaker: NA
Text: south-east by South Africa. There is a spar-

Speaker: NA
Text: tan population of about 1.5 million souls. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was first colonised by the Germans in 1884.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1920 South Africa assumed control under

Speaker: NA
Text: a League of Nations mandate. In the years

Speaker: NA
Text: that followed South Africa established a

Speaker: NA
Text: thorough administrative, political and eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic dominance in the territory. When the

Speaker: NA
Text: much-despised apartheid system was intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced into South Africa after World War II

Speaker: NA
Text: it was also applied to Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the UN succeeded the League of

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations in 1945 South Africa refused to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter into a new trusteeship arrangement with

Speaker: NA
Text: it and since 1946 the UN and South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: have been in conflict over the political status

Speaker: NA
Text: of the territory. As a result of South Africa's

Speaker: NA
Text: refusal to submit reports on its administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Namibia, the 1966 session of the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: General Assembly resolved that South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: should be stripped of its mandate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: territory and that responsibility should be

Speaker: NA
Text: vested in the UN appointed Council for Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: mibia. A long process of UN sponso.red de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate on Namibia has continued to thIS day.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the 1960s South Africa moved to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: solidate its control in the territory and the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of apartheid, notably in the .area

Speaker: NA
Text: of severely limiting indigenous people's nghts

Speaker: NA
Text: in landholding, were intensified. In October

Speaker: NA
Text: 1966 the predominant nationalist movement,

Speaker: NA
Text: the South West Africa People's Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: (SWAPO), launched a guerilla war against

Speaker: NA
Text: the South African military presence. Exten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive armed conflict has continued ever since.

Speaker: NA
Text: The UN has made intensive efforts to at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempt to achieve the peaceful solution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibian issue leading to independence for

Speaker: NA
Text: the territory. South Africa partic.ipat-d in a

Speaker: NA
Text: series of talks with the UN, whIle SImulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: neously attempting to maximise its control

Speaker: NA
Text: in the territory and moving to develop an

Speaker: NA
Text: elected political structure within Namibia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The attainment of black majority rule in

Speaker: NA
Text: Angola and Mozambique in 1975 and in

Speaker: NA
Text: Zimbabwe in 1980 placed further pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: on the South Africans. In 1978 efforts by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western members of the Security Council to

Speaker: NA
Text: reconcile the protagonists in the dispute over

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia led to the adoption of Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Council Resolution 435. It provided for a

Speaker: NA
Text: cessation of hostilities, withdrawal of South

Speaker: NA
Text: African troops and free elections supervised

Speaker: NA
Text: by the military and civilian United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Transitional Assistance Group (UNTAG),

Speaker: NA
Text: the aim of which was independence for Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: mibia. Australia has offered to contribute

Speaker: NA
Text: troops and UNTAG peacekeeping forces for

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 10 years. In December 1986 Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia announced that from 1986-87 $lm per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum would be spent on scholarships for

Speaker: NA
Text: African refugees from South Africa and Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: mibia. In May 1987 sanctions applied to

Speaker: NA
Text: South Africa were extended to Namibia. In

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1985 the Australian Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Hawke) asserted that the need for Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: mibian settlement remains as strong as ever;

Speaker: NA
Text: only the urgency has increased. Indeed, by

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1986 some 12,000 Namibians had

Speaker: NA
Text: been killed in the 20 years war of

Speaker: NA
Text: independence.

Speaker: NA
Text: In mid-June 1985 South African attempts

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve an internal solution were greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced by the establishment of an interim

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Transitional Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: National Unity (TGNU) in Namibia based

Speaker: NA
Text: on the multi-party conference (MPC) , a

Speaker: NA
Text: group of internal parties which does not in-

Speaker: NA
Text: clude SWAPO. This move met with wide-

Speaker: NA
Text: spread international condemnation. The UN

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Council passed Resolution 566, to-

Speaker: NA
Text: tally rejecting this internal solution, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary-General issued a statement con-

Speaker: NA
Text: demning the move as a further obstacle in

Speaker: NA
Text: the path of a negotiated settlement in

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia. The 1987 report, however, indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated that the MPC TGNU was not as pliant

Speaker: NA
Text: as South Africa would like it to be and that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was declining to set up the ethnically

Speaker: NA
Text: system of electorates which would ensure a

Speaker: NA
Text: weak and divided successor state, easily

Speaker: NA
Text: manipulated by South Africa. The TGNU

Speaker: NA
Text: was aiming for a nationwide vote for an

Speaker: NA
Text: assembly which would run the country and

Speaker: NA
Text: draft a constitution.

Speaker: NA
Text: In April 1988 South Africa's President de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cided to reassert South Africa's authority in

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia. President Botha gave Louis Pienaar,

Speaker: NA
Text: the South African appointed administrator,

Speaker: NA
Text: the right to overrule the Cabinet, call ra-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially based elections for each of the region's

Speaker: NA
Text: 11 ethnic groups, and impose sweeping press

Speaker: NA
Text: censorship laws. The most important aspect

Speaker: NA
Text: of this development was that the administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor had the power to veto any move to

Speaker: NA
Text: repeal Proclamation AG8, a key piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: apartheid legislation that entrenches white

Speaker: NA
Text: social and economic privilege. By being un-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to remove apartheid, the TGNU has

Speaker: NA
Text: lost virtually all hope of ever gaining any

Speaker: NA
Text: popular support.

Speaker: NA
Text: Meanwhile, diplomacy continued. In July

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986 a special UN conference on Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: was held in Vienna, attended by representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives of 128 governments. Their decisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: including a demand for comprehensive sanc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions against South Africa to force it to grant

Speaker: NA
Text: independence, were endorsed by UN special

Speaker: NA
Text: session later in the year. In April 1987 the

Speaker: NA
Text: UN Security Council discussed Namibia for

Speaker: NA
Text: four days. Until August 1988 10 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive negotiations had failed to resolve

Speaker: NA
Text: the dispute, which had been complicated by

Speaker: NA
Text: South African insistence on linking the with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawal of its forces from Namibia with a

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal of the Cuban presence in Angola.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, on 8 August 1988 Cuba, Angola

Speaker: NA
Text: and South Africa, with American mediation,

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to a 14-point accord.

Speaker: NA
Text: . The main features of the agreement are

Speaker: NA
Text: an immediate ceasefire between on the one

Speaker: NA
Text: hand the armed forces of Cuba and Angola

Speaker: NA
Text: and on the other the South African Army;

Speaker: NA
Text: South African troop withdrawal from An-

Speaker: NA
Text: gola by August 1988-and this deadline was

Speaker: NA
Text: the met; the establishment of a joint military

Speaker: NA
Text: committee composed of military officers from

Speaker: NA
Text: Angola, Cuba, South Africa and Namibia to

Speaker: NA
Text: monitor the withdrawal of South African

Speaker: NA
Text: troops from Angola; to recommend to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary-General of the UN the date 1

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1988 for the beginning of imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: based mentation of UN Security Council Resolu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 435; the estimated 50,000 Cuban troops

Speaker: NA
Text: based in Angola will withdraw from the ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ritory; the 7,500-man UN force to be sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: Namibia by 1 April 1989-some months be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the elections are due to be held; a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: of non-intervention in neighbouring territo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries; South Africa stops assisting the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Union for the Total Independence of Angola

Speaker: NA
Text: (UNIT A); and Angola stops providing as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistance to SWAPO and the African Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Congress (ANC)-and presumably this

Speaker: NA
Text: also means that an independent Namibia

Speaker: NA
Text: would not permit ANC guerillas to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: out of its territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House' can see that the extensive

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts of many people have contributed over

Speaker: NA
Text: many years to what now looks like being a

Speaker: NA
Text: solution to a problem that has plagued the

Speaker: NA
Text: world for many years. We now see Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian troops-in fact, about half of the en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gineering component of our Army-being

Speaker: NA
Text: dep-oyed to this very challenging and hostile

Speaker: NA
Text: environment. These troops will be involved

Speaker: NA
Text: !n the. building of roads and airfields, repair-

Speaker: NA
Text: mg bndges, constructing buildings and forti-

Speaker: NA
Text: fications, removing minefields and setting up

Speaker: NA
Text: watch towers, water and sewerage systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will be led by Colonel Richard Warren

Speaker: NA
Text: and represent the cream of Australian def-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence manpower. It behoves us all on both

Speaker: NA
Text: sid- of this Parliament to support this op-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration with great will. It is a dangerous and

Speaker: NA
Text: as 1 say, hostile environment. Australian sol-

Speaker: NA
Text: -iers will almost certainly be killed there. It

Speaker: NA
Text: IS appropriate on this night for Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout this country to recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges that are in store for our troops. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: only hope that the Government in its wis-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom, deciding to deploy these troops there

Speaker: NA
Text: recognises the enormous challenges that it

Speaker: NA
Text: has set u- and 1 trust that the logistic sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port that IS so necessary to provide such an

Speaker: NA
Text: operational component so far away with its

Speaker: NA
Text: -usc1e receives all the support that this na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion can offer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

Text: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Staples:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which Mr Braithwaite had moved by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of amendment:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view

Speaker: NA
Text: to substituting the following words: 'whilst not de-

Speaker: NA
Text: clining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) notes the concerns of service-providers in ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: hering to th- changed arrangements, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: -ack of fundmg, and at the lack of flexibility

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 the arrangements which are diminishing the

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of care to our aged; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) expresses its concern at the diminishing mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rale of the providers of services to the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: because of various Government initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the commissioning of the report

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm Still an Individual'.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: my remarks by giving a brief recapitulation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the points 1 made in the chamber last

Speaker: NA
Text: week in reference to the Aged or Disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: Persons Homes Amendment Bill 1988. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill seeks to introduce a number of changes

Speaker: NA
Text: covering a broad spectrum and concerns the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry which provides essential care and

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the aged and disabled in society.

Speaker: NA
Text: To use the words of the director of one such

Speaker: NA
Text: institution in my electorate, the Hawke Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: -rnment is being politically dishonest in say-

Speaker: NA
Text: 109 that by 1990 no-one will be required, by

Speaker: NA
Text: law, .to pay more than 87.5 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensIOn and supplementary assistance for ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: commodation in nursing homes. The effect

Speaker: NA
Text: of this 87.5 per cent ceiling will undoubtedly

Speaker: NA
Text: be -o heap massive pressure on the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: as It attempts to continue to provide an

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable level of service to the patients in

Speaker: NA
Text: its care, as prices rise and a lid is put on its

Speaker: NA
Text: charges. 1 point out that not all people are

Speaker: NA
Text: financially disabled and, for years, the

Speaker: NA
Text: wealthy have, to some degree, subsidised the

Speaker: NA
Text: less well off.

Speaker: NA
Text: The consequences of instituting a ceiling

Speaker: NA
Text: on th- charges of nursing homes will be, of

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity, that homes concentrate on caring

Speaker: NA
Text: for patients in categories 1, 2 and 3, which

Speaker: NA
Text: attr-ct the highest level of subsidy, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: detnment of those in categories 4 and 5.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dementia patients are deemed to be in cat-

Speaker: NA
Text: egories 4 and 5-those needing the least

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of care-but dementia patients can

Speaker: NA
Text: often keep staff fully occupied with the tasks

Speaker: NA
Text: ?f fe-ding, toileting and dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: lOcontmence.

Speaker: NA
Text: If a nursing home's budget is restricted by

Speaker: NA
Text: the type of patients it has and the amount it

Speaker: NA
Text: can charge, the only way to overcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: shortfall is to decrease the level of service.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is precisely the situation that leads to

Speaker: NA
Text: -he neglect of an individual's dignity, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: m the case of communal clothing. Dementia

Speaker: NA
Text: or not, people should not need to suffer

Speaker: NA
Text: neglect. Another aspect of the same point is:

Speaker: NA
Text: -ha- about the staff? By pressuring the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: s-ltution the staff have that pressure passed

Speaker: NA
Text: directly on to them. They have to work in

Speaker: NA
Text: an environment where they never have time

Speaker: NA
Text: to do the job well, and are never able to

Speaker: NA
Text: have the satisfaction of making a patient

Speaker: NA
Text: comfortable and happy because they are too

Speaker: NA
Text: busy jumping from crisis to crisis and serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: icing only the most fundamental needs. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: see two crises looming: firstly, a situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: which patients in categories 4 and 5 will only

Speaker: NA
Text: be accepted in voluntary institutions, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will then become overloaded and under-

Speaker: NA
Text: financed; and, secondly, a staff shortage

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a tremendous amount of debate

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Government's declared decision to

Speaker: NA
Text: cut total nursing home beds to a level of 40

Speaker: NA
Text: per hundred of the population aged over 70.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1987 there were an estimated 167,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people aged 65-plus in South Australia, mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing up 12 per cent of the State's total pop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ulation. By the year 2021 it is predicted that

Speaker: NA
Text: that group will represent 17.3 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the population. Further, by that time there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be an estimated 22,800 people in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia aged 85-phis, compared with 13,222

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1987, an increase of 72 per cent in that

Speaker: NA
Text: short timespan. That dramatic change must

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate something to everyone who is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with planning aged services and resi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dential care.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the moment in South Australia there

Speaker: NA
Text: are 7,700 aged persons in 160 nursing homes

Speaker: NA
Text: and about 5,740 aged persons in 125 hostels.

Speaker: NA
Text: Half the nursing home residents are aged 85

Speaker: NA
Text: years and over. If bed occupancy in nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes in the year 2001 corresponds with the

Speaker: NA
Text: present aged percentage, that same percent-

Speaker: NA
Text: age of people aged 85 and over will be

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for 6,622 beds. The present overall

Speaker: NA
Text: number of nursing home beds is 7,700. If no

Speaker: NA
Text: more beds are available in South Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: by the year 2001-and the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: indicating in this legislation that it intends

Speaker: NA
Text: decrease them-that will leave only 78 beds

Speaker: NA
Text: available to people under the age of 85.

Speaker: NA
Text: What does the Government want people to

Speaker: NA
Text: do-take it in turns to sleep?

Speaker: NA
Text: This is only one example of the inade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quacy of the Government's thinking on the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject of planning for the future with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard to adequately providing a broad range

Speaker: NA
Text: of options in the interests of the aged in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. There is no doubt that the pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate sector will feel the pinch severely. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the voluntary sector which will be

Speaker: NA
Text: left to pick up and care for categories 4 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 patients that the private sector may feel it

Speaker: NA
Text: has to pass over in order to better survive

Speaker: NA
Text: by filling its beds with the categories 1, 2

Speaker: NA
Text: and 3 patients that attract a higher subsidy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where is the Government's logic in trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: cut costs by limiting resources, then turning

Speaker: NA
Text: around and boasting that by 1990 no person

Speaker: NA
Text: in a nursing home, regardless of tQe personal

Speaker: NA
Text: resources at his disposal, will have to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 87.5 per cent of the pension for

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation in a nursing home? On the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of the problem there are the hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: tels. I received a letter from the Administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor of the Churches of Christ Retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: Services Inc. in my electorate. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The haste with which the Hostel Recurrent Fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing agreement has been brought forward is typical of

Speaker: NA
Text: other changes we have had to cope with in the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not sure if the problem lies with the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Public Service. However, we have been told

Speaker: NA
Text: in no uncertain terms that failure to sign or changing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Agreement will put our subsidies at risk.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of particular concern in this climate is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister can change the conditions, and the thought

Speaker: NA
Text: of the consultation process only reminds that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a sham in the past . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: You will notice my criticism that the Disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: Code is now to apply fully. This condition was

Speaker: NA
Text: changed without consultation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The upshot is that nearly every hostel for the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia no longer complies with the require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. This must be the height of stupidity since we

Speaker: NA
Text: have previously built for the aged and had no

Speaker: NA
Text: troubles.

Speaker: NA
Text: It now seems that the Government is saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: since some aged people are disabled, all should be

Speaker: NA
Text: treated as disabled.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps they should have said that, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: 5% of the units should be for the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: abled . . . but they didn't,

Speaker: NA
Text: He has been told that such a requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: to would have been received far more favoura-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly, especially as a prospective condition for

Speaker: NA
Text: new buildings. The Administrator says he

Speaker: NA
Text: feels that the trouble lies in the central office

Speaker: NA
Text: in Canberra, where unrealistic goals and

Speaker: NA
Text: deadlines are being set and pursued to the

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrassment of local staff. The Adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trator has made it clear to the department

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that he signed the agreement un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der extreme protest. Australians must be

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about being heavied, bullied or

Speaker: NA
Text: blackmailed. He makes the point that by far

Speaker: NA
Text: the majority of the hostels for the aged in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia have been designed for the aged,

Speaker: NA
Text: not the disabled. A requirement to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: for the disabled aged by expecting a propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of rooms in a complex to be so designed

Speaker: NA
Text: seems more reasonable than presuming all

Speaker: NA
Text: aged people are disabled. Short of bulldozing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Churches of Christ Retirement Services'

Speaker: NA
Text: 145 hostels and rebuilding-and at what

Speaker: NA
Text: cost-the organisation cannot comply with

Speaker: NA
Text: the requirement. The Administrator makes it

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clear that he feels the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: over-regulating the industry. That is the issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have said that there are many good as-

Speaker: NA
Text: pects of the legislation before us. The major-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of the nursing home and hostel industry

Speaker: NA
Text: is keen to see old people retain their individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: uality and dignity. However, that which is

Speaker: NA
Text: not specified in the legislation and is being

Speaker: NA
Text: left to either regulation or interpretation by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister or the Public Service is already

Speaker: NA
Text: causing deep concern within the industry as

Speaker: NA
Text: several significant problems 100m large on

Speaker: NA
Text: the horizon. This legislation, in the form

Speaker: NA
Text: presented to the· House, is not the panacea

Speaker: NA
Text: it pretends to be.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude with this warning: those ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proaching consumer status should be deeply

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about the future of this industry;

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise they may find that what they need

Speaker: NA
Text: may not be there when they need it.

Speaker: Ms CRAWFORD
Text: Forde) (8.09)-Many

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers have addressed the Aged or Dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: abled Persons Homes Amendment Bill, which

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to amend the 1954 Act. The Bill at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempts to pursue a policy which gives this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government a total aged care policy and

Speaker: NA
Text: will provide for an extended range of care

Speaker: NA
Text: options to meet individual needs. Surely, no-

Speaker: NA
Text: one in our community would suggest that, as

Speaker: NA
Text: we as a community become more aged,

Speaker: NA
Text: people should not be treated as individuals.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is precisely what the Bill seeks to do. It

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to do it in a number of ways, but

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly through the funding program.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we see in this funding program is an

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement whereby people are looked at

Speaker: NA
Text: in categories and whereby their needs are

Speaker: NA
Text: met. It attempts not simply to categorise

Speaker: NA
Text: people into one set of nursing home people,

Speaker: NA
Text: one set of hostel people, or one set of people

Speaker: NA
Text: in individual programs, but rather it looks at

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole basis of the kind of services which

Speaker: NA
Text: are provided. It attempts to address the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: consistencies which are currently in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals for the funding of nursing homes and

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels. It attempts to seek that out. It also

Speaker: NA
Text: attempts to provide quality care for all aged

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens within our community, irrespective

Speaker: NA
Text: of their financial situation and, hopefully,

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of where they live and who the

Speaker: NA
Text: care providers are.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of us can cite many examples of a

Speaker: NA
Text: wide range of care that is available to the

Speaker: NA
Text: aged people in our community. It is impera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive that, if we are to address the care of the

Speaker: NA
Text: aged within our community in a total way,

Speaker: NA
Text: we acknowledge, firstly, that they are indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals and, secondly, that people have needs

Speaker: NA
Text: and that these needs must be addressed in a

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative way. Many of the care providers

Speaker: NA
Text: feel threatened because they are not willing

Speaker: NA
Text: to be flexible enough to offer changes. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, there are many good care providers

Speaker: NA
Text: within our community who see and welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill as an attempt to address the situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion realistically.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am interested to hear the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: putting on a ceiling of 87t per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions of those people in aged care will

Speaker: NA
Text: place great pressure on the industry. One is

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to ask: What does he view as a real-

Speaker: NA
Text: istic figure for people to pay for their care

Speaker: NA
Text: and needs? After all, this is subsidised by

Speaker: NA
Text: government and is subsidised by taxpayers,

Speaker: NA
Text: and all of us must share the common respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility of the care for the aged. A figure of

Speaker: NA
Text: 87t per cent of pensions equalises the burden

Speaker: NA
Text: and sets a realistic figure and goal so that

Speaker: NA
Text: people will not be ripped off. Let us face it;

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the findings in our earlier nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home review found that many people were

Speaker: NA
Text: being charged for services they were not

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving and that they were being over-

Speaker: NA
Text: charged for services which were very often

Speaker: NA
Text: of a very poor quality.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I talk of quality I am always forced

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at a nursing home within my own

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate which is known as Canossa, which

Speaker: NA
Text: provides a very wide range of services. It

Speaker: NA
Text: exemplifies the kind of service and the qual-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of service which this Bill hopes to emu-

Speaker: NA
Text: late for all Australians. The Canossa Hospital,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is run by the Canossan Sisters of

Speaker: NA
Text: Charity, provides hostel accommodation,

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing accommodation, and specific accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation for Italian speaking people in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community who in their later years find that

Speaker: NA
Text: they like to have things familiar, and lingu-

Speaker: NA
Text: istically familiar, around them. It also pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides respite care within its walls and, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, it has a very active residents associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation. People are treated as individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: the care providers in this home have no

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty with the funding arrangements, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the quality care that is expected, and with

Speaker: NA
Text: the 87t per cent which they currently charge,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is welcomed because they understand

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness, justice and equity for all aged

Speaker: NA
Text: in our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The residents reflect that individuality.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those who are mobile are often seen down

Speaker: NA
Text: the street. Those who are not are provided

Speaker: NA
Text: with buses or taxis and with means of going

Speaker: NA
Text: places. At a number of functions which I

Speaker: NA
Text: have had in my electorate the residents from

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular hostel and nursing home stand

Speaker: NA
Text: out because they are individuals, because they

Speaker: NA
Text: are prepared to stand up and be counted,

Speaker: NA
Text: and because they have not lost any of those

Speaker: NA
Text: great attributes that we admire in people

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of age. Surely if we are to offer

Speaker: NA
Text: people dignity in their later years we cannot,

Speaker: NA
Text: and We must not, forget that they are indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals. I find it extraordinary that people

Speaker: NA
Text: would suggest that the Chris Ronalds report

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm Still an Individual, which this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: takes into consideration, is in any way a

Speaker: NA
Text: reflection on the care that is provided in

Speaker: NA
Text: some homes. If people find it a reflection on

Speaker: NA
Text: them, all I can say is that they are obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: breaching individual binds. I can cite a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of examples, which I will not do here,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I think we are all aware of certain homes

Speaker: NA
Text: where any sense of dignity, any sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: individuality, is taken away and where people

Speaker: NA
Text: are ruled by fear-fear that if they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: conform they will be thrown out on the

Speaker: NA
Text: street, fear that if they do not do as they are

Speaker: NA
Text: told they will be thrown out on the street.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are talking about adult people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: given very much of their lives to this country

Speaker: NA
Text: and here they are in their later years, when

Speaker: NA
Text: they should be surrounded by comforts, when

Speaker: NA
Text: there should be a degree of respect, in places

Speaker: NA
Text: where some care providers insist that they

Speaker: NA
Text: conform to what they consider to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary mores. I am very pleased that Chris

Speaker: NA
Text: Ronalds and her review team, as part of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and as part of our total aged care pack-

Speaker: NA
Text: age, are embarking upon an education and

Speaker: NA
Text: information program throughout our com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity, and are offering to nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: residents, to hostel residents and to others

Speaker: NA
Text: the acknowledgment that they have rights,

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have dignity, and with that, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, responsibility to themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, it is not only they who have

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility; the care providers also have

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility. This Bill, by seeking to look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the way in which care providers spend

Speaker: NA
Text: their money, attempts to make people re-

Speaker: NA
Text: people sponsible. I am sure that nobody in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House would suggest that we as the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment can continue to give money to people

Speaker: NA
Text: and not find them accountable. It is surely a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of concern to us that if we give

Speaker: NA
Text: money to hostels and to nursing homes they

Speaker: NA
Text: must give the kind of services for which the

Speaker: NA
Text: money is given.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier I heard the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Adelaide talk about dementia patients.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Adelaide per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps is unaware of a very large program that

Speaker: NA
Text: is already operating under the nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: and aged care program which specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: targets dementia patients. In my own elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate at Neilson Home, Matron Buxton runs

Speaker: NA
Text: an excellent program for dementia patients.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those people are treated as individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: the quality of their life has been expanded.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has enabled people to develop and to live

Speaker: NA
Text: a more worthwhile existence within that

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home. It is indicative of the kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: range of services one can offer if one is more

Speaker: NA
Text: flexible about funding-which is exactly what

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill is about. It is not about care provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ders saying that there is one way of doing

Speaker: NA
Text: things. There is never one way of doing

Speaker: NA
Text: things for individuals. There is a whole range

Speaker: NA
Text: of ways, all of which are equally valid, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the same way that the categories set out that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a range of needs and a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: services which have to be provided within

Speaker: NA
Text: that community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have cited one hostel and nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: which offers a wide range of services within

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate. There are also other nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes which offer different kinds of services

Speaker: NA
Text: and which, because of the nature of their

Speaker: NA
Text: clients and the nature of their residents, tend

Speaker: NA
Text: to be much less able to expand into the

Speaker: NA
Text: community but are able to bring the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity into them. Many school children are

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in nursing homes. I am thinking in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular of Sinnamon Retirement Village,

Speaker: NA
Text: where the local school children have an

Speaker: NA
Text: 'adopt a granny' program. They go into the

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home and are very much part of

Speaker: NA
Text: that community.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is all able to be funded. It is part of

Speaker: NA
Text: a total aged care package. It is all part of a

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of life. It is all part of a quality

Speaker: NA
Text: program. This is not to say that this is the

Speaker: NA
Text: only way this should occur, but under this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill such programs can and will be ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: panded. Individuals who wish to participate

Speaker: NA
Text: in such programs will be able to do so. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: imperative that many residents in nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes have the opportunity to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: feel part of a world that is considerably

Speaker: NA
Text: wider than the acre or so upon which their

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home or hostel is built. It is this very

Speaker: NA
Text: issue that is at the heart of the changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the aged and disabled peoples homes re-

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements. It is the fact that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged that aged people in our com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity have demands and needs and are

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals. Through this Bill we will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to meet those demands, to meet those

Speaker: NA
Text: needs, and at a price which we can be sure

Speaker: NA
Text: people are accountable for and at a price

Speaker: NA
Text: which pensioners can afford. The whole issue

Speaker: NA
Text: of equity is at the heart of this Bill. I com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr HICKS
Text: Riverina-Darling) (8.20)-ln

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking to the Aged or Disabled Persons

Speaker: NA
Text: Homes Amendment Bill 1988 I must once

Speaker: NA
Text: again express my strongest concern at the

Speaker: NA
Text: apparent stringent conditions being placed

Speaker: NA
Text: by this Federal Government on those people

Speaker: NA
Text: wishing to provide care for the elderly. To

Speaker: NA
Text: be fair may I first of all thank the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Housing and Aged Care ( Mr Staples) for

Speaker: NA
Text: his courtesy in speaking with the delegation

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Cobar Shire Council. Over a very

Speaker: NA
Text: long period the people of Cobar have been

Speaker: NA
Text: pointing out to the appropriate authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: the problems that the Lilliane Brady Village

Speaker: NA
Text: was facing in operating a small nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: in an isolated area and trying to survive

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Federal Government's new nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing home funding policies. New initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: have recently been taken by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to these smaller nursing homes so

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate the Minister on a start in the

Speaker: NA
Text: right direction.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the new proposals do not over-

Speaker: NA
Text: come all of the problems facing small iso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated nursing homes such as the Lilliane

Speaker: NA
Text: Brady Village. In the first place, the new

Speaker: NA
Text: funding formula under the nursing and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal care component does not adequately

Speaker: NA
Text: cover the salaries of the staff. In the case of

Speaker: NA
