Text: the Lilliane Brady Village, a director of nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and a deputy director of nursing must be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided. Because of the isolation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home and the relatively small popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation of Cobar, attracting staff of exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: the required level of experience is difficult.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, a second year trained sister

Speaker: NA
Text: may be able to do the work required but the

Speaker: NA
Text: only sister available may be a seven-year

Speaker: NA
Text: trained sister who should be, and therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be, paid the award wage that his or

Speaker: NA
Text: her experience attracts. Because the rates set

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government are averaged right across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia the figure arrived at is well below

Speaker: NA
Text: that which in practice does apply to isolated

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes. Of course, this applies not

Speaker: NA
Text: only to nursing home wages but to most

Speaker: NA
Text: wage cost structures in isolated areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government would have us believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the flexibility of the care aggregate mod-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule, or CAM, arrangements enables service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers to overcome a variety of problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: It fails, however, to address the matters of

Speaker: NA
Text: staff availability in many areas, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in isolated locations. It also fails to address

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter of nursing homes having to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the requirements of the outcome standards,

Speaker: NA
Text: the national complaints unit, the State health

Speaker: NA
Text: departments and the myriad of other per-

Speaker: NA
Text: former indicators by which service providers

Speaker: NA
Text: are constantly monitored by government. As

Speaker: NA
Text: the quality of care deteriorates-which inev-

Speaker: NA
Text: itably must occur as a result of government

Speaker: NA
Text: funding cuts and the inability of nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes to charge patients more than 87.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of their pension-extra stress will be

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on nursing home staff. The stress on

Speaker: NA
Text: nurses is going to accelerate, particularly on

Speaker: NA
Text: the director of nursing. As nurses find the

Speaker: NA
Text: professional care required to be greater than

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of hours allocated by the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment they will turn to other forms of

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing outside nursing homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us now look at another situation which

Speaker: NA
Text: has developed in relation to the care for the

Speaker: NA
Text: aged, this time in the city of Broken Hill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members may recall me previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously bringing to their attention the pending

Speaker: NA
Text: closure of Kalinda Court and Allura Lodge,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are two wards of the Broken Hill Base

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospital that care for elderly long stay

Speaker: NA
Text: patients. The New South Wales State Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Health, Mr Collins, recently made

Speaker: NA
Text: a statement confirming the closures and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: peated what we all know to be true-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, that the finance for the care of those

Speaker: NA
Text: people is the responsibility of the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. He also reiterated that the hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pital wards in question were beyond the stage

Speaker: NA
Text: of rehabilitation and should be demolished.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where does this leave Broken Hill's elderly

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens who need care? In the first place,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is already a very long waiting list for

Speaker: NA
Text: both hostel and nursing home accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. There are only two nursing homes pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ently operating in Broken Hill-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Centenary Nursing Home and St Anne's

Speaker: NA
Text: Nursing Home. Both are in a parlous situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion because of costs that are unique to

Speaker: NA
Text: Broken Hill and, as with the situation apply-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in Cobar, they will not be able to survive

Speaker: NA
Text: on a Government cost rate that is based on

Speaker: NA
Text: an averaging across Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not my intention to argue the merits

Speaker: NA
Text: or otherwise of the industrial system that has

Speaker: NA
Text: developed in Broken Hill over the years. But

Speaker: NA
Text: this system has certainly placed tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: . pressure on the whole of the aged care sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem in that city. The New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Nursing Association is seeking to have some

Speaker: NA
Text: of these conditions apply to nurses employed

Speaker: NA
Text: at the two Broken Hill nursing homes. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are seeking the payment of the Broken Hill

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance of $12.40 a week and the provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of an additional one week of annual

Speaker: NA
Text: leave. Both of these are standard provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Broken Hill award. This would cause

Speaker: NA
Text: an estimated increase in the running cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: both nursing homes as at 1 July 1988 of

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately $60,130, or 4.21 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget for 1988-89. If all conditions that

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to the Broken Hill Base Hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: staff were insisted on-and thankfully they

Speaker: NA
Text: are not-the position would be even worse.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact when the administrators made repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentations for economic relief from the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment of Community Services and Health

Speaker: NA
Text: because of these additional costs, the reply

Speaker: NA
Text: from the departmental representative stated

Speaker: NA
Text: in part:

Speaker: NA
Text: I am somewhat surprised by your request, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet your request for special treatment for the

Speaker: NA
Text: of Broken Hill would at the very least, require

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to the National Health Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we now face the situation that not only

Speaker: NA
Text: are the present nursing homes facing great

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty and the possibility that they may

Speaker: NA
Text: not be able to continue for much longer

Speaker: NA
Text: under the cost structure presently applying

Speaker: NA
Text: in Broken Hill, but these costs, unless totally

Speaker: NA
Text: funded by the Federal Government or eased

Speaker: NA
Text: by local industrial agreements, will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that no entrepreneur or church group will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to have further nursing home beds

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated for Broken Hill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Government has expressed a

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to have more hostel type accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation provided in lieu of nursing home beds.

Speaker: NA
Text: Presently Aruma Lodge provides a high

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of hostel accommodation in Broken

Speaker: NA
Text: Hill but many more beds are required. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of this, over the past four years South-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Cross Homes, the present administrators

Speaker: NA
Text: of the two nursing homes in Broken Hill,

Speaker: NA
Text: have applied for funding for hostel accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation. Unfortunately, despite the long

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting lists for this accommodation, they

Speaker: NA
Text: have been unsuccessful. I doubt if they will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply again because, as the Voluntary Care

Speaker: NA
Text: Association has recently pointed out, anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: who builds this accommodation under the

Speaker: NA
Text: new guidelines for funding announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Government over a period of time

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be economically viable whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they were built in Broken Hill or anywhere

Speaker: NA
Text: else. Therefore, the cost structures applying

Speaker: NA
Text: in Broken Hill would rule that accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion out completely unless Broken Hill were

Speaker: NA
Text: treated as a special case by the Federal Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment or special industrial conditions were

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiated.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was interested to read in the Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Daily Truth, Broken Hill's daily newspaper,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Barrier Industrial Council in Broken

Speaker: NA
Text: Hill has arranged a deputation to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Housing and Aged Care on the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of nursing homes and hostel accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation in Broken Hill. I am accustomed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Barrier Industrial Council, for reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: best known to its members, ignoring me as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Member in its applications to

Speaker: NA
Text: various Ministers on a range of issues. On

Speaker: NA
Text: this occasion I am disappointed because care

Speaker: NA
Text: for Broken Hill senior citizens is of universal

Speaker: NA
Text: concern and certainly should be approached

Speaker: NA
Text: homes on bipartisan lines. Perhaps I may be misin-

Speaker: NA
Text: an terpreting the situation. The invitation has

Speaker: NA
Text: not arrived yet, but I am looking forward to

Speaker: NA
Text: it in the mail. Broken Hill is going to need

Speaker: NA
Text: a united front if it is to provide adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: services for its elderly citizens with the

Speaker: NA
Text: and Federal conditions presently applying,

Speaker: NA
Text: and if we adopt a disunited front we will do

Speaker: NA
Text: so to the detriment of those elderly citizens.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1986 the Government endorsed the

Speaker: NA
Text: findings of the Nursing Homes and Hostels

Speaker: NA
Text: Review which recognised that there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: need to develop a total aged care policy with

Speaker: NA
Text: an expanded range of care options to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: individual needs. The Government under-

Speaker: NA
Text: took to introduce a series of measures di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rected at the expansion and better resourcing

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sector. In other words, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was going to make additional resources

Speaker: NA
Text: available that would enable more elderly and

Speaker: NA
Text: invalid people to remain in their homes. As

Speaker: NA
Text: I have recently relayed to the House, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: not as yet seen any evidence of this financial

Speaker: NA
Text: support in my electorate, and this applies

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly to Broken Hill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The concern over the matter of care for

Speaker: NA
Text: the elderly and infirm citizens of Broken Hill

Speaker: NA
Text: has become an issue of serious concern to its

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens and because of this great concern a

Speaker: NA
Text: petition has been circulated in the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity which I am sure will be signed by most

Speaker: NA
Text: of the people of Broken Hill. This petition

Speaker: NA
Text: will in due course be presented to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Throughout Australia there are still great

Speaker: NA
Text: problems existing in the provision of nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home and hostel accommodation. Both Cobar

Speaker: NA
Text: and Broken Hill are unique cases that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire particular attention and I call on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and the Government to take urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: action that will help to overcome the very

Speaker: NA
Text: real problems existing in those areas.

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Text: Scullin) (8.29)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: measures contained in the Aged or Disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: Persons Homes Amendment Bill 1988 are

Speaker: NA
Text: quite technical in nature but they are part

Speaker: NA
Text: of a continuing program by this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to improve aged care and care for disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: people. As has been outlined by previous

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers, this is but the fifth stage in an

Speaker: NA
Text: eight-stage program to improve institutional

Speaker: NA
Text: care for older people. That plan was an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced in 1986 and arose out of the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's response to a number of reviews

Speaker: NA
Text: that over the years have been well discussed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the community and open to great debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was first the Auditor-General's report

Speaker: NA
Text: back in 1981, which was followed by an

Speaker: NA
Text: local Expenditure Committee report, the MCLeay

Speaker: NA
Text: report, followed by a Senate committee re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port known as the Giles report. Finally there

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Department of Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: report of the nursing homes and hostels re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view. Much that is contained in this report

Speaker: NA
Text: formed the basis for the present Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's strategy in the area of nursing homes

Speaker: NA
Text: and hostels. The particular piece of legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion before us tonight goes a long way to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards putting in place the legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements for the provision of hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: services. Importantly, it will ensure that those

Speaker: NA
Text: hostel services are better targeted.

Speaker: NA
Text: One criticism that has often been made of

Speaker: NA
Text: the way Australia has developed its nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home and hostel services is that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been planned on an ad hoc basis and that

Speaker: NA
Text: people and governments respond only to

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions that are placed before them. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has seen the error of this form

Speaker: NA
Text: of action and it has decided that, as in other

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, we should be doing what we can on a

Speaker: NA
Text: needs basis. I think even honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers opposite have acknowledged the success

Speaker: NA
Text: with which this has been carried out.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another important aspect of the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is that people will be assisted in having

Speaker: NA
Text: hostel places in the form of respite care

Speaker: NA
Text: made available to them. I think that respite

Speaker: NA
Text: care, in providing services for the aged and

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled, is an area of great importance that

Speaker: NA
Text: has started to be opened up. It is of impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to the older person or the person with

Speaker: NA
Text: the disability and it is important to the qual-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of life of a carer at home. Often because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the permanent nature of the funding ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements for both nursing home and hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: places, families have been prevented from

Speaker: NA
Text: having some relief, some respite, from their

Speaker: NA
Text: onerous duties. Now, as we see in this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation and in previous legislation for nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home arrangements, the way has been opened

Speaker: NA
Text: for those carers to provide for their families

Speaker: NA
Text: by allowing those they are caring for to go

Speaker: NA
Text: into hostels on a respite basis. I think that is

Speaker: NA
Text: important. It ties in with the overall strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government in the provision of insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutional care for older people and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: programs that give a range of options to

Speaker: NA
Text: older people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Often we hear that there has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: provided the amount of consultation that

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps there should have been. I think we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to reject that, given the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: reports that were provided to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment before the policy was set in place in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986 and given the gradual way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's policy has been put into place.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is unfair in the extreme to suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: the voices of not only the people in nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes or hostels but also the care providers

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been heard when they have proper

Speaker: NA
Text: comments and criticisms to make.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we also look at the appropriateness of

Speaker: NA
Text: the program, much has been made about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's objective of 100 residential

Speaker: NA
Text: places per 1,000 people aged 70 and over. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, the criticism from those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: rarely relates to the mix of those places, a

Speaker: NA
Text: mix which will see 60 hostel places to 40

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home places. It is suggested that

Speaker: NA
Text: suddenly the rug will be pulled from under

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of nursing homes in the provision

Speaker: NA
Text: of places. That is not the case. This will be

Speaker: NA
Text: a gradual process and does not necessarily

Speaker: NA
Text: mean, as I believe some of those sitting op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite have suggested, that there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale closures.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is unfortunate that, in the area of aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care, when presented with a scenario like

Speaker: NA
Text: this the Opposition often chooses to tug on

Speaker: NA
Text: the fear of change itself that is ever present

Speaker: NA
Text: in the elderly population. I believe that that

Speaker: NA
Text: is not the way to go. This is an area of

Speaker: NA
Text: policy where we should all be working to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether, and that is why the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged the need to put into place

Speaker: NA
Text: gradual changes. Those opposite perhaps for-

Speaker: NA
Text: get when they raise these points that a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of what we are talking about tonight is the

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriateness of the level of care. When

Speaker: NA
Text: we suggest that in some cases nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment is not appropriate, that is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism of individual nursing homes or of

Speaker: NA
Text: the nursing home industry in total. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: simple statement of fact that often the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who reside in nursing homes do not require

Speaker: NA
Text: the level of care that is provided by nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes. Therefore we put into place a proper

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure, as in this Bill, for improvements

Speaker: NA
Text: to hostel care, which is an option that gives

Speaker: NA
Text: another level of care to the elderly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nursing homes and hostels should be seen

Speaker: NA
Text: in their relationship to such programs as the

Speaker: NA
Text: home and community care program where

Speaker: NA
Text: for aged and disabled people the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment attempts, with the cooperation of State,

Speaker: NA
Text: local government and other community

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies, to put in place a wide and varied

Speaker: NA
Text: range of programs that will assist those people

Speaker: NA
Text: for as long as possible to remain in their own

Speaker: NA
Text: homes and to keep their independence and

Speaker: NA
Text: an ability to remain within the community

Speaker: NA
Text: that is able to support them. In the past,

Speaker: NA
Text: these options were not available and, unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunately, people were often inappropriately

Speaker: NA
Text: placed in nursing homes. At least there is

Speaker: NA
Text: now a realisation that we have to look more

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully at the appropriateness of the treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that is given to people who find them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves in this situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow Minister for community serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ices and aged care, the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dawson ( Mr Braithwaite), in his opening

Speaker: NA
Text: speech earlier in this debate also referred, as

Speaker: NA
Text: he did in his second reading amendment, to

Speaker: NA
Text: the report I'm Still an Individual. Unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately, he took a very dismissive attitude to

Speaker: NA
Text: the report and, I felt, unfairly belittled what

Speaker: NA
Text: it had to say. He quite extraordinarily

Speaker: NA
Text: plucked from what is a lengthy document-

Speaker: NA
Text: some 170 pages or so-one anecdotal story

Speaker: NA
Text: about a patient and about that person's pet

Speaker: NA
Text: and the effect it had on the person's place-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in a nursing home. To do that is to

Speaker: NA
Text: dismiss the value of such a document. The

Speaker: NA
Text: value of this document is not just to patients,

Speaker: NA
Text: to people who reside in nursing home accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation, but to all those who are involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the provision of these services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot understand why the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would be expressing, as it does in its amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, concern at the diminishing morale of

Speaker: NA
Text: the providers of services to the aged because

Speaker: NA
Text: of various Government initiatives, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the commissioning of the report I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: Still an Individual. That seems to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that in commissioning reports about user

Speaker: NA
Text: rights we are placing the Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: some sort of direct adversarial role with serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ice providers. That is a nonsense. Service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers, along with residents, were in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in the formulation of the report and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are able to be involved in the continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing community consultations surrounding this

Speaker: NA
Text: report. That is important. It is yet further

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence of this Government's ability to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to provide opportunities for consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. When we have the upshot of this, when

Speaker: NA
Text: we see that care providers can work in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sultation with those who represent residents

Speaker: NA
Text: and with the residents themselves, we will

Speaker: NA
Text: have a better situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to raise briefly some of the matters

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been raised in the report. One of

Speaker: NA
Text: them was the lack of information that resi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents of nursing homes suggested they had

Speaker: NA
Text: about their options. It was said that they had

Speaker: NA
Text: not been informed about the range of options

Speaker: NA
Text: available to them and that, whether it was

Speaker: NA
Text: because a relative wanted to get rid of them

Speaker: NA
Text: by putting them in institutional care or they

Speaker: NA
Text: were acting in ignorance, in some cases there

Speaker: NA
Text: have been inappropriate placements. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: a sad feature. It is all right for me, as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government, to stand here and say

Speaker: NA
Text: that that is a sad situation, but I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is addressing the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance of providing the appropriate informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to those individuals that find themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: in a situation of looking for appropriate care.

Speaker: NA
Text: Remarks are made about the life in these

Speaker: NA
Text: homes, but importantly the report indicates

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the residents contacted many had

Speaker: NA
Text: positive things to say about nursing homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: That needs to be stressed. The negative as-

Speaker: NA
Text: pects of nursing homes are portrayed, but

Speaker: NA
Text: there are positive aspects and they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be stressed. I have no doubt that the major-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of people that work in the nursing homes

Speaker: NA
Text: area-even if it is referred to as an indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try-have respect for their clients and have

Speaker: NA
Text: their best interests at heart. But sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: the sort of atmosphere that those people are

Speaker: NA
Text: in-the shadow Minister mentioned this-

Speaker: NA
Text: leads to stress. They know that they cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: give additional time to residents. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciative of the fact that perhaps they

Speaker: NA
Text: should do a little bit better, but there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: need to do that not only in the context of

Speaker: NA
Text: the way the provider feels but also in the

Speaker: NA
Text: context of the way the resident feels. The

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home situation is in some ways a

Speaker: NA
Text: form of communal living and there is a need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be constantly aware of the rights of pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vacy of residents who have gone from a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation of living at home by themselves or

Speaker: NA
Text: from a situation in which the trigger point

Speaker: NA
Text: of the need to go into institutional care is

Speaker: NA
Text: the loss of a spouse. There is a need to treat

Speaker: NA
Text: those residents with dignity and respect.

Speaker: NA
Text: All in all, as has been acknowledged in

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate by many speakers on both sides

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House, in the majority of cases it is

Speaker: NA
Text: seen that what is being attempted in the area

Speaker: NA
Text: of aged care in total and, in particular, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the nursing homes and hostels area is an

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to set in place appropriate care and

Speaker: NA
Text: a range of options of care that will enable

Speaker: NA
Text: those who are either part of our older pop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ulation or who are suffering forms of disabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ities that require them to go into residential

Speaker: NA
Text: type care to be catered for, that the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: are being thought out in a strategic way, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the changes should be as gradual as possible

Speaker: NA
Text: and that all those involved should be kept

Speaker: NA
Text: properly informed and be able to make com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and be involved in the strategic way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which these policies are being put in place.

Speaker: Dr WOODS
Text: Lowe) (8.43)-1 must say

Speaker: NA
Text: I am absolutely amazed. I presume that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Scullin ( Mr Jenkins)

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have any nursing homes in his elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate. He is so far out of touch with what

Speaker: NA
Text: is happening that that can surely be the only

Speaker: NA
Text: possible explanation for such nonsense. He

Speaker: NA
Text: says that hostel care is another level of sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port. I point out that it has been there for

Speaker: NA
Text: some considerable time. It is not another

Speaker: NA
Text: level of support. In fact, it is an inappro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate level of support for many of the pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tients who need closer and more careful

Speaker: NA
Text: attention and who are now, because of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's actions, being pushed into

Speaker: NA
Text: hostel care. For him to say that the home

Speaker: NA
Text: and community care program will take care

Speaker: NA
Text: of some of the problems at the same time as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is destroying the guts of

Speaker: NA
Text: that program means that he is completely

Speaker: NA
Text: out of touch with what is actually happening

Speaker: NA
Text: in the real world.

Speaker: NA
Text: His comments on the I'm Still an Individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ual report bear no resemblance to what many

Speaker: NA
Text: workers in the area feel about that report. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will address that in some detail later. He

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that the rug will not be pulled from

Speaker: NA
Text: under these people. All he was saying was

Speaker: NA
Text: that the rug will be pulled; it will jl,lst be

Speaker: NA
Text: pulled a little more .slowly than some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them think. He is quite right when he says

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are talking about the appropriate-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness of the level of care. That is the key

Speaker: NA
Text: concern that we, in the Opposition, and many

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the nursing home and caring

Speaker: NA
Text: industry-if one wants to use that word-

Speaker: NA
Text: have; that the level of care in many of these

Speaker: NA
Text: residences is entirely inappropriate to their

Speaker: NA
Text: needs. That way the Government can cut

Speaker: NA
Text: costs and save more money at the expense

Speaker: NA
Text: of this very vulnerable group in our society.

Speaker: NA
Text: The resident classification instrument

Speaker: NA
Text: (RCI), for example, may in general terms

Speaker: NA
Text: be an admirable concept. It is basically aimed

Speaker: NA
Text: at getting a balance between the various

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of care and what is offered in the

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes and an appropriate remuner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation for those levels. Although the concept

Speaker: NA
Text: is very good, ideology takes over. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: the socialist intrusion of stamping everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: with a number; they are all on some point

Speaker: NA
Text: scoring system. Certainly there is no flexibilin

Speaker: NA
Text: ity and there is no concern about the individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: uality of the people concerned. The RCI

Speaker: NA
Text: structure forces patients, in many cases, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately into hostels. I think it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: clear from the representations that I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has received also that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are now a number of people who are too

Speaker: NA
Text: frail to be in hostels and who are now,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the inflexibility of the RCI, pushed

Speaker: NA
Text: into the hostel accommodation. It is an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: strument of government control.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although we over here certainly support

Speaker: NA
Text: the concept that as many genuinely suitable

Speaker: NA
Text: people as possible should be looked after in

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels rather than in nursing homes, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a major concern that a number of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people now in hostels and going into hostels

Speaker: NA
Text: in the near future as a result of this and

Speaker: NA
Text: associated legislation, are too frail to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels. They will stay in hostels which, al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though the staff do a superb job, are in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: now underfunded. They need more staff and

Speaker: NA
Text: the funds for those staff are clearly not

Speaker: NA
Text: forthcoming from this Government. As I say,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is cost cutting exercise at the expense of

Speaker: NA
Text: the patients.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am amazed at what a wonderful job

Speaker: NA
Text: most hostels do under the pressures they

Speaker: NA
Text: have at present. We often hear of hostels

Speaker: NA
Text: where there is only a single qualified nurse

Speaker: NA
Text: on at a given time to look after the needs of

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of patients. The staffing levels

Speaker: NA
Text: there may be okay if the patients are fit and

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty well able to look after themselves, as

Speaker: NA
Text: was the concept for hostels, but the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of frail patients in those hostels has been

Speaker: NA
Text: increased so markedly that the support ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices, the nursing services and the medical

Speaker: NA
Text: services are rapidly becoming inadequate. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is fair to say that a number of these institu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are both overstressed arid understaffed

Speaker: NA
Text: for the types of patients they are now ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pected to care for. One point I endorse and

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome is the proposed admission of carers

Speaker: NA
Text: into hostels with the patients themselves. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is a thoroughly laudable concept and one

Speaker: NA
Text: which, once the system has been worked out

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately, I am sure will work to the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of both patients and their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Scullin talked

Speaker: NA
Text: about the aim of 60 places per thousand frail

Speaker: NA
Text: patients over the age of 70 years. Only 40 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the relevant numbers per thousand would be

Speaker: NA
Text: a nursing home. He failed to mention that

Speaker: NA
Text: this means there would be a reduction on

Speaker: NA
Text: current figures from 72,000 to 47,000 nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes places-a reduction of 25,000 places.

Speaker: NA
Text: He also conveniently forgot to mention that

Speaker: NA
Text: those 25,000 places would be lost pretty well

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely from the private sector. As is often

Speaker: NA
Text: the case, the Government-the left wing of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government at least-is targeting the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector of the nursing home industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been the backbone of the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: for many years. It is also very clear that if

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact any new nursing homes were permit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted to set up in operation, they would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be receiving any recurrent funding. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: they very rarely get capital funding in any

Speaker: NA
Text: case. It is quite clear that this is an attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: to remove the private element of the nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time, hostel places will go up

Speaker: NA
Text: from 43,000 to 70,500. There is only one

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation to make from these figures;

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, quite clearly there will be a large

Speaker: NA
Text: number of very frail patients who would

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise have been in nursing homes but

Speaker: NA
Text: who will now be in hostels. Some of those,

Speaker: NA
Text: hopefully a large number, will be appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately in hostels. Equally it is very clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: a large number of those nursing home pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tients should be in nursing homes and should

Speaker: NA
Text: stay there rather than being shoved down

Speaker: NA
Text: the line to the cheaper-this is the key to

Speaker: NA
Text: it-hostel accommodation. As I say, those

Speaker: NA
Text: 25,000 nursing home beds will come pretty

Speaker: NA
Text: well entirely from the private industry. There

Speaker: NA
Text: will be no funding for new nursing homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: But more than that there is a attack on

Speaker: NA
Text: another element in the private nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: sphere in particular, and that is those nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes with less than 20 beds. On the one

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, the Government is saying that small is

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful, that is, that we should get patients

Speaker: NA
Text: out into the community to live in community

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes, community homes of four,

Speaker: NA
Text: five or six people. On the other hand, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is this pressure on nursing homes to either

Speaker: NA
Text: close down or amalgamate if they happen to

Speaker: NA
Text: be small, which in this regard means less

Speaker: NA
Text: than 20 beds. So we lose that family atmos-

Speaker: NA
Text: phere, intimacy, closeness or the concept that

Speaker: NA
Text: big is beautiful. Big is clearly not beautiful,

Speaker: NA
Text: but from a government's bureaucratic point

Speaker: NA
Text: of view it is easier to handle one big organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation rather than several small ones-the

Speaker: NA
Text: bigger the better. This is part of the brave

Speaker: NA
Text: new world bureaucracy-more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra control in many areas-that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Housing and Aged Care ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Staples) has looming over us.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government also has an amazing

Speaker: NA
Text: cheek to release propaganda in the form of

Speaker: NA
Text: a leaflet entitled I'm Still an Individual,

Speaker: NA
Text: edited by Chris Ronalds. The implication in

Speaker: NA
Text: this document is that the rights of residents

Speaker: NA
Text: have been usurped. It is a fair interpretation

Speaker: NA
Text: of not only the documents itself but the press

Speaker: NA
Text: conferences that have accompanied it that

Speaker: NA
Text: the residents themselves may be misused, in

Speaker: NA
Text: poor conditions and have not only a host of

Speaker: NA
Text: other complaints but are the norm rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than the exception. I agree that there may

Speaker: NA
Text: be some bad apples in the nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: sphere. We are all aware that some nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes are not as good as others. But this a

Speaker: NA
Text: a gross. misrepresentation of the situation. A

Speaker: NA
Text: number of the witnesses who were inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: viewed by the team producing this document

Speaker: NA
Text: have spoken to me about being misquoted

Speaker: NA
Text: and selected quoting of their comments. They

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that the interpretation which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: put on their own comments is entirely inap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriate to what they were trying to say to

Speaker: NA
Text: the team writing this particular document. I

Speaker: NA
Text: should point out that residents in nearly every

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home in the Nursing Home Associa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion already have their own charter of rights

Speaker: NA
Text: and responsibilities and freedom. It is that

Speaker: NA
Text: way round. It is not only a question of their

Speaker: NA
Text: rights but also their responsibilities, and

Speaker: NA
Text: is entirely appropriate. The vast majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes provide not only freedom to

Speaker: NA
Text: them as individuals but good caring,. good

Speaker: NA
Text: basic amenities and good food. On the whole,

Speaker: NA
Text: the nursing homes are run by caring, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: passionate people. This document was de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed very neatly by one of my constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: whose parents are in the Jesmond Nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: Home in my constituency as 'a trendy piece

Speaker: NA
Text: of paper that will get a lot of publicity but

Speaker: NA
Text: do nothing for the old people'.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite two-faced for the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to support this recommendation that aged

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the community should have more

Speaker: NA
Text: say in where they go and what their rights

Speaker: NA
Text: are when it is the Government's own cost

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting policies which restrict entry to nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing homes to the very frail who are often

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to communicate their wishes anyway.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is pure hypocrisy. Freedom of the individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ual is paramount and does generally occur.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government should support that and

Speaker: NA
Text: this document does not help that concept.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another matter related to this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: problem is the question of resident funded

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels. In New South Wales alone there are

Speaker: NA
Text: some 600 resident funded hostel beds, mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: run by the Uniting Church and, to a lesser

Speaker: NA
Text: extent, the Seventh Day Adventist Church.

Speaker: NA
Text: Basically, the concept here is that residents,

Speaker: NA
Text: on their retirement, make an interest free

Speaker: NA
Text: loan to the board running the hostel to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for their accommodation in their retirement.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a refundable loan. This is true self-

Speaker: NA
Text: help. The only funding that these hostels get

Speaker: NA
Text: from the government is a subsidy for addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional nursing. Apart from this, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely self-supporting. In many cases, these

Speaker: NA
Text: are people who have often scrimped and

Speaker: NA
Text: saved for their own retirement. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: looked after themselves. It actually cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: Government costs. The 600-odd beds in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, forgetting about the inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: rate under this Government, is over $1O.8m

Speaker: NA
Text: at 1980 prices. What has happened now, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, is that there is a requirement that

Speaker: NA
Text: one in five patients in these resident funded

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels be financially disadvantaged. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: laudable aim-and I am happy to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should provide places for financially dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: abled people-but, unfortunately, this dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: criminates against people who have scrimped

Speaker: NA
Text: and saved for their retirement. For example,

Speaker: NA
Text: that Woodfield, one of the nursing homes in the

Speaker: NA
Text: inner west of Sydney, instead of paying

Speaker: NA
Text: $55,000 as an interest free loan, has in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased that to cover the cost of the extra

Speaker: NA
Text: financially disabled people to $68,750. In

Speaker: NA
Text: effect, this is an extra capital tax upon a

Speaker: NA
Text: group of aged people. It is yet another pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: alty on those who have actually tried to save

Speaker: NA
Text: and provide for their own retirement. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty on thrift.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe very strongly that we should en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage self-help and not penalise it. It seems

Speaker: NA
Text: that this problem has arisen because Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Staples, the Minister, was not even aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that resident funded hostels existed. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: the same Peter Staples who this evening in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed the Pharmaceutical Society of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia that he would not turn up for its

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting because it was going to criticise him

Speaker: NA
Text: and he duly did not turn up to the meeting.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the Peter Staples, the Minister, who

Speaker: NA
Text: is supposed to be aware of the situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: his Government.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Ronald

Speaker: NA
Text: Edwards )-Order! I suggest to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member that he should refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister by his appropriate title.

Speaker: Dr WOODS
Text: It changes so often. Is it

Speaker: NA
Text: Aged Care?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Nevertheless,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is beholden upon the honourable mem:ber

Speaker: NA
Text: to be certain of the Minister's title if he

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes to refer to him.

Speaker: Dr WOODS
Text: Resident funded hostels

Speaker: NA
Text: should be clearly excluded from this bureau-

Speaker: NA
Text: cratic outrage. The charities involved, mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: the Uniting and Seventh Day Adventist

Speaker: NA
Text: churches, have been pushed into signing so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called lOF agreements for their continued

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. They have signed these under pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: test. Amongst the other problems they have

Speaker: NA
Text: are the extra bureaucratic requirements in

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the financially disabled people's

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations. For example, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: requires information of a legal nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: residents' rights. It requires extra details, al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though it does not actually say which records

Speaker: NA
Text: it requires, of residents' private arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: with the nursing homes. All this has to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: a form to be determined by the Department.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the charities say, which form? It is clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: a Commonwealth form. It is more intrusion

Speaker: NA
Text: and ministerial control, which may be ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pealing to the relevant Minister, but is not

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate to the good care of these

Speaker: NA
Text: residents.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been submissions from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Challenge Foundation about the concept

Speaker: NA
Text: which is embodied in this legislation of mov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing people, particularly the inteHectually dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: abled, out from this sort of hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation into community homes of

Speaker: NA
Text: four or five people. We all think that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: admirable in principle, but there are a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of problems in doing this. Some of these

Speaker: NA
Text: intellectually disabled people in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: will never cope in houses of four or five

Speaker: NA
Text: people. To cope adequately, most will need

Speaker: NA
Text: increased care and increased financial sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port to provide that care. As far as we can

Speaker: NA
Text: see, the Government is not planning to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide the necessary financial infrastructure to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow the appropriate care for these people

Speaker: NA
Text: to survive in the community home concept.

Speaker: NA
Text: . The intellectually disabled are, indeed, a very

Speaker: NA
Text: . special case. If appropriate care is not avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able in community based accommodation,

Speaker: NA
Text: then they may well find that this approach

Speaker: NA
Text: is not only of no benefit but actually detri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental to their ongoing self-esteem and self-

Speaker: NA
Text: management. The Richmond scheme high-

Speaker: NA
Text: lighted some of the problems involved in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area. Unfortunately, the Government has not

Speaker: NA
Text: learnt from those particular problems. Hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: tel style accommodation can be every bit as

Speaker: NA
Text: good as cottage style accommodation, so long

Speaker: NA
Text: as it is run by the appropriate organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: with caring, involvement, experience and the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary financial infrastructure. I appeal to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government not to throw out the baby

Speaker: NA
Text: with the bath water in regard to this partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ular aspect of the intellectually disabled.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another question related to this whole leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation, clearly not spelt out completely to

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody's satisfaction, is the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: moving people away from sheltered work-

Speaker: NA
Text: shops and reducing or abolishing the funding,

Speaker: NA
Text: depending on which Government represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ative of the week one listens to. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition supports the concept that the

Speaker: NA
Text: intellectually disabled should be moved out

Speaker: NA
Text: if possible into general industry, into the

Speaker: NA
Text: community, we and a large number of the

Speaker: NA
Text: parents of these people are very concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: that a large number of people who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: suitable to be moved out into the community

Speaker: NA
Text: will be moved out inappropriately. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: will, therefore, fail in the move to the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: side community. Instead of going to a shel-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered workshop or the equivalent, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: be forced to stay at home. There is a need

Speaker: NA
Text: for a number of procedures. There is a need

Speaker: NA
Text: to educate the community. The community

Speaker: NA
Text: into which these people are moving needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: be--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Blunt-Not to mention the trade

Speaker: NA
Text: unions.

Speaker: Dr WOODS
Text: Especially the trade unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The community needs to be trained in the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems which these people actually face,

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise we will find that they are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: menial tasks, they will be the butts of abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: and humour, and they will be exploited.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of these people have been through

Speaker: NA
Text: that before they went to the sheltered work-

Speaker: NA
Text: shops and have come through that problem

Speaker: NA
Text: only to be faced now, because of this Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's action, with the possibility of being

Speaker: NA
Text: put back there. For that small number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the sheltered workshops, we en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirely support the concept of moving them

Speaker: NA
Text: into industry and exposing them to the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: side world. The Government needs to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that the funding to support this is en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirely available. For those for whom it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, and never will be possible, either

Speaker: NA
Text: sheltered workshops or similar organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: would be entirely appropriate and need to

Speaker: NA
Text: ?e supported. I mention in passing that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Job support scheme has done a superb job in

Speaker: NA
Text: this regard, but it does need more financing

Speaker: NA
Text: and expanding to have a larger impact upon

Speaker: NA
Text: what is in fact a very significant number of

Speaker: NA
Text: intellectually disabled people.

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, I would like to say, therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the changes which the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: in mind may be very admirable in principle

Speaker: NA
Text: but they need to be implemented very care-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully, with adequate funding and with train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and education for the outside community.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to retain the good points of the

Speaker: NA
Text: current systems. We do not need change for

Speaker: NA
Text: change's sake. We need to minimise the

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucracy and the red tape involved not

Speaker: NA
Text: only for the patients but also for the nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes and other organisations which are in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in caring for what is a very vital and

Speaker: NA
Text: important part of our community.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: Berowra)

Speaker: NA
Text: (9.01)-1 do not propose to detain the House

Speaker: NA
Text: for long, but I wish to make just a few

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary remarks to the very compre-

Speaker: NA
Text: hensive survey of the subject by my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: league the honourable member for Lowe (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Woods), who has just resumed his seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Smith-A good speech.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: An excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. The Aged or Disabled Persons Homes

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill is within the context of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's changed approach to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: v-sion of acco-modation for the aged and

Speaker: NA
Text: dIsabled followmg the 1986 nursing homes

Speaker: NA
Text: and hostels review. This approach has now

Speaker: NA
Text: been in place for the last 18 months. In

Speaker: NA
Text: concept it is a 'needs based' approach, in

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast to what was referred to as the 'sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission model' of previous years. Faced with

Speaker: NA
Text: the inevitable expansion of aged persons ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: commodation with the ageing of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: population-this is so well documented I will

Speaker: NA
Text: not give any figures-this Bill seeks to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: a 'bet-er targeting', or rather a more specific

Speaker: NA
Text: targetmg, of government subsidised services

Speaker: NA
Text: to persons in need and to areas in need-as

Speaker: NA
Text: there are areas apparently disadvantaged in

Speaker: NA
Text: the aged care accommodation stakes. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are circumstances in which it is imperative

Speaker: NA
Text: to contain government expenditure-it is

Speaker: NA
Text: good to see that the Minister for Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: and Aged Care ( Mr Staples) and his De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment recognise that, because this cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be said of the Treasurer, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Blaxland ( Mr Keating), who has

Speaker: NA
Text: very complacently said that the process of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure reduction has gone about as far

Speaker: NA
Text: as it can. It certainly has not, as the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will very soon come to recognise. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are p.lenty of studies around by reasonable,

Speaker: NA
Text: practIcal men that. could give the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment a lead in this, and which are not the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'mindless shrieks of ideologues', as the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer accused last Budget time.

Speaker: NA
Text: So in circumstances where it is imperative

Speaker: NA
Text: t? contain government spending, the empha-

Speaker: NA
Text: SIS on a needs based approach is entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate, and I accept that. It is a pity

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government does not more widely

Speaker: NA
Text: embrace the principle-and I have particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly in mind the health care system. But

Speaker: NA
Text: while the principle of a needs based ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach is a good one, I get worried when

Speaker: NA
Text: such a policy is to be administered by

Speaker: NA
Text: socialists.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cowan-You must have flexibility.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: That is what it

Speaker: NA
Text: will not have if it is administered by social-

Speaker: NA
Text: ists, and I will come back to that in a mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. When we study the detail and the real

Speaker: NA
Text: thrust of this legislation, we see there is

Speaker: NA
Text: serious cause for concern, as Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers who have preceded me have pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out. First, there is nothing in this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: or funding approach designed effectively to

Speaker: NA
Text: utilise and encourage the private sector. As

Speaker: NA
Text: my colleague the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Macquarie ( Mr Webster) put it the other

Speaker: NA
Text: night, that is counterproductive to, and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: deed a betrayal of, the interests of the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: persons the legislation is intended to help, It

Speaker: NA
Text: is difficult to escape the conclusion that

Speaker: NA
Text: is on the Government's side an underlying

Speaker: NA
Text: antagonism towards the involvement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector in providing these services-

Speaker: NA
Text: not just discouragement of new private en-

Speaker: NA
Text: terprise hostels and nursing services, but ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements that will have the effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: phasing out, driving out, existing private en-

Speaker: NA
Text: terprise establishments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Braithwaite-Quite deliberately.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: Quite deliber-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately, as the shadow Minister says. The pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate sector is being squeezed at both ends,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly nursing homes. They will be pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vented by this legislation from taking more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 87.5 per cent of pension from patients,

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of whether the patients can af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ford to pay more. That provision is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented as a great plUS: The Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: Government avers that by 1990-shades of

Speaker: NA
Text: the reference to children in poverty-no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: will be required to pay more than 87.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of pension for accommodation in a

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home. Again it is like no-one having

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay more than the schedule fee for medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal services-if people can get them. But in

Speaker: NA
Text: typical socialist fashion, that commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: begins to foul up the overall aged accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation and care situation. It pretty effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively does away with the private enterprise

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for the top end of the market and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in that way, adds to the overall imbalance,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed shortage, of accommodation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have only to consider the parallel sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: uation of school funding to recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong-headedness of eliminating capital

Speaker: NA
Text: funding to private sector service providers.

Speaker: NA
Text: In not doing so it is like cutting off one's

Speaker: NA
Text: nose to spite one's face, as my colleague put

Speaker: NA
Text: it the other night. Thus capital funding sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port for private schools allows the school

Speaker: NA
Text: itself and the provision of schooling at a

Speaker: NA
Text: lesser cost to the taxpayer than if fully pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided by the public sector. That same consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration surely applies to hostels.

Speaker: NA
Text: Added to this, there is the squeeze from

Speaker: NA
Text: the official funding components, the so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: standard aggregate module (SAM) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: care aggregate module (CAM) components.

Speaker: NA
Text: The latter, CAM, has been suggested by

Speaker: NA
Text: some to mean 'caring attitude missing' from

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government! But there is a squeeze re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sulting from these being set at levels which

Speaker: NA
Text: are notably less than the actual cost figures

Speaker: NA
Text: there supplied by the private nursing home asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciations, and all this puts the private hostels

Speaker: NA
Text: and homes under great pressure. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: out there-this does not seem to be recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised by the Government-a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure, apprehension and even despair at

Speaker: NA
Text: this time. One cannot counter that just by

Speaker: NA
Text: pointing to some private operators, under

Speaker: NA
Text: whom admittedly there has been insufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: care and dedication, and some patient ne-

Speaker: NA
Text: glect, and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat: a reasonable and responsible ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to policy in this area would recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: the potential for the private sector playing a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant role in meeting future accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation and care needs, which are going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: very large indeed. But this Government, in

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast with that, has seen fit to inhibit and

Speaker: NA
Text: discourage such a private sector role, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: longer term detriment of the aged citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I spoke at the beginning of two Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns at the Government's approach. Its

Speaker: NA
Text: failure to encourage a larger participation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the private sector is one. The second is the

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucratic rigidity and inflexibility that my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague referred to a moment ago, inevita-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly associated with such a centralised public

Speaker: NA
Text: sector biased community service planning

Speaker: NA
Text: operation-this bureaucratic outrage, as my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague the honourable member for Lowe

Speaker: NA
Text: called it a moment ago. In this respect I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: only to refer to an initiative by certain public

Speaker: NA
Text: spirited citizens who belong to a local com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity organisation from the township, sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: urb, of Berowra in my electorate. I mention

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly Messrs Bill and Ernie Foster. I

Speaker: NA
Text: say 'township' deliberately, because the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity of Berowra in my electorate is some-

Speaker: NA
Text: what isolated and is situated between

Speaker: NA
Text: Hornsby-Asquith-Mount Colah, which is the

Speaker: NA
Text: northern limit of metropolitan Sydney, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hawkesbury River, which forms the

Speaker: NA
Text: northern border of my electorate. This is by

Speaker: NA
Text: no means a high income area when com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with some other parts of this electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: division.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposal to which I refer is the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of a low cost residential accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation and care complex for the frail and

Speaker: NA
Text: aged in the Berowra township. The commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity organisation that I referred to is in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to make a significant capital contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to the project but, of course, the sum

Speaker: NA
Text: available is by no means adequate to fund

Speaker: NA
Text: the construction costs in their entirety. The

Speaker: NA
Text: essence of the case put for this proposal is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Berowra township is, as I have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: a somewhat isolated community with a pop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ulation now of the order of 16,000 people.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no aged accommodation whatsoever

Speaker: NA
Text: anywhere near it. The fact is that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole Hornsby-Berowra area, which stretches

Speaker: NA
Text: from the northern outskirts of Hornsby right

Speaker: NA
Text: up to and including Wisemans Ferry-an

Speaker: NA
Text: area of the order of 10 times the size of the

Speaker: NA
Text: balance of the regional planning area-there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no aged accommodation at all. Yet, the

Speaker: NA
Text: application for assistance for this proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: meets with a stereotyped bureaucratic re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse. A recent response from the relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth department reads as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: As you may be aware, the Government has adopted

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommendations made in the Nursing Home

Speaker: NA
Text: and Hostel Review. That is, the growth of residential

Speaker: NA
Text: care services should be planned on the basis of ratio

Speaker: NA
Text: of 100 residential care places per 1,000 people aged

Speaker: NA
Text: 70 and over in all areas of Australia. The objective

Speaker: NA
Text: is to achieve 60 hostel places and 40 nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: places per 1,000 aged people. Funding rounds are

Speaker: NA
Text: now concentrating on those areas that have a hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: ratio of 30 or less places per 1,000 aged people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also wish to advise that a planning area takes in

Speaker: NA
Text: account the ratio of residential care services provided

Speaker: NA
Text: in the entire Local Government Area, not areas

Speaker: NA
Text: within the LGA.

Speaker: NA
Text: The planning area for Hornsby-Ku-Ring-Gai has

Speaker: NA
Text: a combined hostel and nursing home ratio of 172

Speaker: NA
Text: places per 1,000 aged people.

Speaker: NA
Text: It goes on to express regret that the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal could not be funded. What appears in'

Speaker: NA
Text: no way to be taken into account is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant local government area includes a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of very large retirement complexes,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the Mowll Village and related vil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lages complex at Castle Hill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cowan-It has a wonderful reputation.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: Yes, it has. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to say that it is among the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: and the very best in all Australia. This com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plex draws its clients from all over Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales and, for that matter, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. I repeat that no allowance is made for

Speaker: NA
Text: that fact. The guideline figures quoted in the

Speaker: NA
Text: response that I read out and confirmed in

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation are inflexibly applied as a

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucratic imperative and completely ne-

Speaker: NA
Text: glect the reality of this local situation. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: this very worthy local initiative has been

Speaker: NA
Text: stifled. Some way of affording it any assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance at all has, apparently, not even been

Speaker: NA
Text: explored. I take this opportunity to appeal

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister and the Department to sit

Speaker: NA
Text: down and have another look at this worthy

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal from this organisation in Berowra.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition is not opposing this Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: nor the needs principle on which it is based.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we express serious concerns about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's approach, such as those to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have referred. I support the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that was moved by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dawson ( Mr Braithwaite).

Speaker: Mr COWAN
Text: Lyne) (9.l6)-Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: can rightfully claim to be fairly well down

Speaker: NA
Text: the track so far as the care of our aged

Speaker: NA
Text: people is concerned. I think the Aged or

Speaker: NA
Text: Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 1988, which we are discussing this evening,

Speaker: NA
Text: is just another step in what the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: sees as being needed to keep up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: advancement of aged care. As the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Berowra (Dr Harry Ed-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards) pointed out, we agree with the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to which the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dawson ( Mr Braithwaite) has moved a

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading amendment. But I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: point out certain factors relating to it that

Speaker: NA
Text: are of some concern to the Opposition. From

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to this debate, I believe that certain

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members also see problems in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to realise that taxpayers' money

Speaker: NA
Text: is being used for the care of certain people

Speaker: NA
Text: within our society. Today over five million

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are drawing a pension of some

Speaker: NA
Text: kind-principally the age pension. Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth and State governments have a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment to contribute towards certain care.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think there is any great objection

Speaker: NA
Text: to this in principle, but there are certain

Speaker: NA
Text: things that we have to be careful about in

Speaker: NA
Text: this respect. Both governments and opposiquirements

Speaker: NA
Text: tions must realise that when taxpayers' money

Speaker: NA
Text: is being made available for the care of

Speaker: NA
Text: tain groups within the community, governliament

Speaker: NA
Text: ments must keep some control. The 'What

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation before the House is a typical

Speaker: NA
Text: ample of a government on the one hand

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to keep control of taxpayers' money

Speaker: NA
Text: and on the other hand protecting certain

Speaker: NA
Text: people, such as the underprivileged, low

Speaker: NA
Text: come earners and other people in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity who need help. None of us object to

Speaker: NA
Text: this because we have hearts that are that

Speaker: NA
Text: way inclined. I am sure that the privileged

Speaker: NA
Text: in our community want to help those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are less fortunate. But we have to appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: that the standards of care must be kept

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly so far as health is concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to make sure that what we are it

Speaker: NA
Text: doing, with good intentions-and the legisan

Speaker: NA
Text: lation before us is an example of this-does

Speaker: NA
Text: not ultimately mean that somebody or some

Speaker: NA
Text: group within the community will be disadmust

Speaker: NA
Text: vantaged. I particularly refer to financially,

Speaker: NA
Text: physically or mentally disadvantaged people

Speaker: NA
Text: who want to be and should be in a nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home or institution. These people should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be further disadvantaged.

Speaker: NA
Text: People are living longer today. If there is

Speaker: NA
Text: one thing that aged people do not want, it

Speaker: NA
Text: stress. They need health care. I am conto

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned that aged people from the metropoltributions

Speaker: NA
Text: itan areas have turned up in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: office and have told me that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: worked for a lifetime just to put a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: money aside so as they can care for themisations

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. But because of asset testing and

Speaker: NA
Text: high costs of living today they are unable

Speaker: NA
Text: live the lifestyle that they would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: retirement or meet their demands for housto

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and health care. This is a tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: stress upon many Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: One thing that members of this House,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether in government or in opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: should seek to avoid is placing continual

Speaker: NA
Text: stress on aged people within the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each one of us will eventually reach the

Speaker: NA
Text: stage where this problem arises. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has the problem of inflation. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: only country in the world with that problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition we have so many regulations that

Speaker: NA
Text: today one almost needs to be a bush lawyer

Speaker: NA
Text: to cope with the demands of the social

Speaker: NA
Text: curity system, with its regulations and

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with aged care. One needs

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a legal mind or the assistance of

Speaker: NA
Text: cersomebody such as a member of Federal Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: whom one can consult and ask,

Speaker: NA
Text: does all this mean?'. Even honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: exmembers need expert assistance in under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing the requirements of the social se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity system. We are fortunate that officers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Department are available to assist us

Speaker: NA
Text: into advise constituents about these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many aged persons are coming to my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate to live, having retired from the met-

Speaker: NA
Text: ropolitan areas. They are attracted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate because homes are cheaper, the

Speaker: NA
Text: geography of the area is good, the atmos-

Speaker: NA
Text: phere is marvellous to live in. It is because

Speaker: NA
Text: up, of my experience with these people that I

Speaker: NA
Text: sound the warning to the Government that

Speaker: NA
Text: is dealing with taxpayers' money. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: important thing that should not be for-

Speaker: NA
Text: gotten. In any legislation that comes before

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament there must be flexibility. We

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the foundation of legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: that comes before us to see what its effect is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be on the ordinary people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. We must ensure that the legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: flexible so that aged people can be cared for

Speaker: NA
Text: properly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let honourable members never forget that

Speaker: NA
Text: is private enterprise has contributed immensely

Speaker: NA
Text: aged care in Australia. The greatest con-

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made by community

Speaker: NA
Text: groups and churches, organisations that over

Speaker: NA
Text: the years have displayed greater foresight

Speaker: NA
Text: of than any government ever has. These organ-

Speaker: NA
Text: have raised the money for aged care

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishments.. I can point to people who

Speaker: NA
Text: to . contributed, beyond their means, sums of

Speaker: NA
Text: in $2,000 and $3,000 and even up to $100,000

Speaker: NA
Text: support the establishment of a nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home in their own community. I can cite the

Speaker: NA
Text: example at the moment in the Great Lakes

Speaker: NA
Text: Shire of people at Bulahdelah who have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponded in relation to the 40 nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: beds that were advertised as available within

Speaker: NA
Text: the shire. Within one week the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: that small township with a population of just

Speaker: NA
Text: over a thousand raised more than $300,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: the with the support and backup of the sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rounding rural community. These people,

Speaker: NA
Text: who have good hearts, said that they wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: a nursing home to accommodate aged people

Speaker: NA
Text: sewithin their community-men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: rewho are not being cared for. They have said

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Government, 'We will comply with

Speaker: NA
Text: your policy and we will put up the money'.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will put up double the fee, if need be,

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide their share of the cost of a 40-

Speaker: NA
Text: bed nursing horne. They will equip the horne

Speaker: NA
Text: and run it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remind the House that farming commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity groups grow the vegetables and fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: that are needed in the nursing homes. They

Speaker: NA
Text: corne in with their baskets full and the ladies

Speaker: NA
Text: of the group cook cakes for the aged people.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are an example of the wonderful co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation that this nation needs. I mention

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter because it is so important and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government should never overlook it.

Speaker: NA
Text: These local citizens cook the cakes and grow

Speaker: NA
Text: the vegetables and fruit; they also provide

Speaker: NA
Text: butter and milk and other things to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: the local community nursing horne or hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: and units. The important fact is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of the local community are part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision of aged care accommodation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Never let us reach the stage in this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try where we, as members of Parliament, do

Speaker: NA
Text: anything to take away any of that pride from

Speaker: NA
Text: these local people or discount in any way

Speaker: NA
Text: the generosity that they display in contrib-

Speaker: NA
Text: uting to the atmosphere and environment of

Speaker: NA
Text: every individual within the aged care estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment. I am not dealing with the techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: calities of the legislation, I am dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of what people want. The av-

Speaker: NA
Text: erage Australian citizen wants to care for his

Speaker: NA
Text: mother and father, his uncle or cousin, or

Speaker: NA
Text: the poor old person who lives next door or

Speaker: NA
Text: down the road. Those are the people we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to think about and that is why I speak

Speaker: NA
Text: again about flexibility. Like the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Page ( Mr Ian Robinson), I visit

Speaker: NA
Text: the nursing homes in my electorate as often

Speaker: NA
Text: as I can. I do not know of one person in a

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing horne in my electorate who should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be there. I do not know of one person

Speaker: NA
Text: who could genuinely be taken out of a nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing horne in my electorate and put into a

Speaker: NA
Text: hostel. I do not think any of these people

Speaker: NA
Text: could care for themselves. They need a max-

Speaker: NA
Text: imum of care. They need care 24 hours a

Speaker: NA
Text: day because they are ill and aged. They

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot get out of their beds for most of the

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot see the position that Government

Speaker: NA
Text: members talk about when they say that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are aged patients in nursing homes who could

Speaker: NA
Text: be in a hostel. Where does one draw the line

Speaker: NA
Text: within a hostel? At what stage does one

Speaker: NA
Text: bring in nursing? These are all matters that

Speaker: NA
Text: are categorised in the Bill that will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: be worked out as time goes on. At the mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment two or three nursing homes are being

Speaker: NA
Text: constructed in my electorate. Already there

Speaker: NA
Text: are a dozen or more nursing homes and

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels within my electorate. As I said, from

Speaker: NA
Text: a geographical point of view the area is an

Speaker: NA
Text: ideal place to go to live. I have been involved

Speaker: NA
Text: with these establishments not for one year

Speaker: NA
