Text: but for 35 or 40 years. I helped to start one

Speaker: NA
Text: in the days when people said, 'There will be

Speaker: NA
Text: nobody to occupy the beds. Who are we

Speaker: NA
Text: going to get to occupy them?'. We started

Speaker: NA
Text: with 18 beds and such was the demand that

Speaker: NA
Text: three months after they were opened there

Speaker: NA
Text: were 70 people waiting for beds.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it comes to categorising these people,

Speaker: NA
Text: I would not like to be a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment team. It will have great difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: fitting in with the requirements of categoris-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation that the Government is placing within

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation. I have not attended the sem-

Speaker: NA
Text: inars to hear these things spoken about. It

Speaker: NA
Text: may be that the method of categorisation

Speaker: NA
Text: has already been worked out very thor-

Speaker: NA
Text: oughly, but the existing nursing homes and

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels want to know a lot more about

Speaker: NA
Text: categorisation and particularly about the

Speaker: NA
Text: reimbursements they are going to receive. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is important for the administrators of a nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing horne or hostel to know these things.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today there are many different designs of

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels and nursing homes. I give full credit

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Department of Housing and Aged

Speaker: NA
Text: Care for adopting and approving new types

Speaker: NA
Text: of designs. I mention the example of Har-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourside Haven at Nelson Bay within my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, which accommodates almost 300

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the units, the hostel and the nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing horne. It is a marvellous place. The De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment has recently approved another 40-

Speaker: NA
Text: bed hostels. The administrators would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: build another twoor three-storey building.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the matter with that, so long as a

Speaker: NA
Text: lift is installed in the building? This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of change that is corning into these

Speaker: NA
Text: establishments today. Clusters are also be-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming a feature of nursing homes and hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: tels, which I think is a good idea. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent designs. I pay tribute to the

Speaker: NA
Text: churches, the community groups and the

Speaker: NA
Text: lodges that over the years have gained tre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendous experience in the design of these

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions for the convenience of the guests

Speaker: NA
Text: in them and the nurses and administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: staff who have to cope with the demands of

Speaker: NA
Text: the running of the establishment. It is impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant that we look at these designs to know

Speaker: NA
Text: in what direction we are going. The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Lowe (Dr Woods) made

Speaker: NA
Text: an important point when he spoke earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: about categorisation. We do not want the

Speaker: NA
Text: stage to be reached where an aged person,

Speaker: NA
Text: who has over a lifetime contributed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: well-being of the nation, will be categorised

Speaker: NA
Text: as one, two, three, four or five, and known

Speaker: NA
Text: as such. We do not want this. I hope it never

Speaker: NA
Text: happens to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Braithwaite-It happens.

Speaker: Mr COWAN
Text: As the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dawson said, it happens and he pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: this out when he led for the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: in the debate. We do not wimt this to hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pen to any Australian, whether he or she be

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal, poor person or the wealthiest

Speaker: NA
Text: person in Australia. I do not care who the

Speaker: NA
Text: person is; he or she should not be catego-

Speaker: NA
Text: rised. I ask the Government and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Housing and Aged Care ( Mr Staples) in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular to be careful to see that this

Speaker: NA
Text: not happen, for the sake of the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. We do not want to see such a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation arise.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is wrong with a pensioner paying

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 87t per cent of his pension to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards his nursing home accommodation? If

Speaker: NA
Text: the pensioner has some money set aside and

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to help with the running of the home,

Speaker: NA
Text: or assist in getting more nursing home or

Speaker: NA
Text: hostel beds, what is wrong with his being

Speaker: NA
Text: able to contribute more? The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: says that by 1990 nobody will pay more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 87.5 per cent of his pension towards the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of accommodation in a nursing home. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: what it is directing its attention to; we all

Speaker: NA
Text: know about that. But what is wrong with a

Speaker: NA
Text: person who wants to contribute more, to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist the home or hostel, doing so if he

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes?

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know-both the Opposition and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government-that in aged care in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia we have a tiger by the tail. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: great responsibility in this area. We hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government will be' able to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: this responsibility. We hope, in the process,

Speaker: NA
Text: that future governments will give encourage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to community groups, churches, lodges

Speaker: NA
Text: and other private enterprise groups, to cater

Speaker: NA
Text: for this need. The provision of beds is im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant. We do not want to socialise this

Speaker: NA
Text: country and present the Government with a

Speaker: NA
Text: fast track method completely to take over

Speaker: NA
Text: and control these community groups.

Speaker: NA
Text: The States will say that they have nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home patients in hospital beds around the

Speaker: NA
Text: States. They are scattered here and there.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that that is so. They have some

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility to look after them, too. But

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact is that the planning that we do in

Speaker: NA
Text: the short and long term I am sure will be

Speaker: NA
Text: very good. We do not know whether there

Speaker: NA
Text: may be a hidden agenda. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dawson referred to this point.

Speaker: NA
Text: He knows what I mean. What is the hidden

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda? We hope that there is not one. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that we are only at a certain stage

Speaker: NA
Text: with regard to aged care in Australia-and

Speaker: NA
Text: rightfully so, because we must be flexible.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to adjust the situation as time goes

Speaker: NA
Text: by. We have to meet the extra demands that

Speaker: NA
Text: we will have.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to be parochial and I have

Speaker: NA
Text: does not been since I was first elected to this

Speaker: NA
Text: place. As a Federal member of parliament I

Speaker: NA
Text: can say that the only money that we get

Speaker: NA
Text: directly for our electorates is for aged people

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation and private schools-unless

Speaker: NA
Text: a community employment program grant is

Speaker: NA
Text: available around the corner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ian Robinson-Or a road or two.

Speaker: Mr COWAN
Text: That is right; perhaps a

Speaker: NA
Text: road or two.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr COWAN
Text: We used to get it. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: look after my electorate in terms of aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care. I will fight any legislation that is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered by this House that I do not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: is in the interests of the 20 to 25 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: my total constituency who have retired in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, in one of the best parts of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Those people have had enough

Speaker: NA
Text: worry in regard to the assets test and many

Speaker: NA
Text: other matters. We do not want to see aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care become a problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appeal to the Government to think of

Speaker: NA
Text: the matters that we have spoken about in

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate . I spoke earlier about the Nelson

Speaker: NA
Text: Bay Harbourside Haven. Legacy provided

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for three beds there. Those beds

Speaker: NA
Text: have been in place for a year or so, yet they

Speaker: NA
Text: are still empty as they have not been ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved. I hope that the Minister will soon

Speaker: NA
Text: approve those three beds and make them

Speaker: NA
Text: available to people who need them. I spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: of Bulahdelah. I can talk about Taree, Tun-

Speaker: NA
Text: curry-Forster, Port Macquarie--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer-Port Macquarie-Riv-

Speaker: NA
Text: erwood Village.

Speaker: Mr COWAN
Text: That is right; very good.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bushland Place now for Taree; Dungog,

Speaker: NA
Text: Stroud and Gloucester. All of those com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities have gone out of their way to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: money. They have initiated it. Nobody has

Speaker: NA
Text: said to them, 'You people should have this'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The communities have said this. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: sought the respect, support and cooperation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the churches, the masonic lodge or some

Speaker: NA
Text: other body. They are on the way to provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this accommodation. The ladies are cook-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing cakes and the farmers are growing fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: and vegetables, and providing milk. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: all involved in the fund raising.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ian Robinson-Milk and honey.

Speaker: Mr COWAN
Text: As the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Page said, they are providing the milk

Speaker: NA
Text: and honey. Is that not the atmosphere that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to retain in Australia? This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: bread and butter stuff that the people of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country want. I am sure the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown)

Speaker: NA
Text: would agree with me on this point: the people

Speaker: NA
Text: want meat, too. They like fillet steak. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: my good friend will help the aged; I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt about that. Those are just some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: comments I wish to make in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. I think they are very basic. If

Speaker: NA
Text: ever we get away from the basics of aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care, goodness help Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: problem I want to raise tonight in discussing

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation is the fact that the milk and

Speaker: NA
Text: honey that the honourable member for Lyne

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Cowan) talked about will not overcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the problems that some nursing homes in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate have as a result of this and related

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. I particularly want to raise some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the concerns that country people have

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Government's aged care policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fundamental to this legislation is the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's move to categorisation of patients

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of funding nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: residents. The impact of that program will

Speaker: NA
Text: be devastating for a number of country nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing homes unless the program is changed or

Speaker: NA
Text: amended. In effect, the Government is say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, 'We will assist in funding according to

Speaker: NA
Text: the extent of care required'. No one would

Speaker: NA
Text: argue with that. I well remember the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: last year when the categorisation was being

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced. We on this side of the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment raised a number of concerns about its

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation but agreed with the thrust

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposal. The problems that we fore-

Speaker: NA
Text: cast have now arisen. One of the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the level of funding for each category

Speaker: NA
Text: of patient has been set so that the larger

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home, with a patient profile which

Speaker: NA
Text: has a spread across the range of classifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, will be viable, whereas the smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: homes without that advantage-without the

Speaker: NA
Text: spread of patients from each classification-

Speaker: NA
Text: will suffer a significant reduction in subsidy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will give a couple of examples from my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. In the town of Berri, which has a

Speaker: NA
Text: population of 7,000 people, is St Catherine's

Speaker: NA
Text: Home for the Aged. There is a nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: with 18 beds and a hostel with 16 beds,

Speaker: NA
Text: catering for the needs of that moderate sized

Speaker: NA
Text: . town of 7,000 people. Under the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed by this Government it will suffer a

Speaker: NA
Text: funding cut of up to $86,000. I say to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Lyne that the cook-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of all the cakes in the world will not

Speaker: NA
Text: raise the sort of money that will be cut from

Speaker: NA
Text: its funding. A town just down the road,

Speaker: NA
Text: Barmera, has a population of 4,300. It has a

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home with 20 beds, adjacent to and

Speaker: NA
Text: run by the hospital in Barmera. Up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $91,000 will be cut from its budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Up the road, the other way, up river to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards Canberra, is Renmark, with a popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation of 7,700. Its nursing home has 20 beds

Speaker: NA
Text: and its hostel has 12 beds. It is another small

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home, catering for the needs of that

Speaker: NA
Text: community. Those nursing homes are going

Speaker: NA
Text: to suffer under the proposed funding ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements put forward by this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: because they do not have access to a large

Speaker: NA
Text: population and they cannot choose the pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tients that come along, to ensure they get a

Speaker: NA
Text: few category 1 patients, a few category 2

Speaker: NA
Text: patients, a few from category 3, and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: They cannot get that spread and so they

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot get the sort of subsidy that the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment believes is the norm. It is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: norm in the country. To some extent the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government appears not to have acknowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edged that because it has put out a paper

Speaker: NA
Text: called Small Nursing Homes. The response

Speaker: NA
Text: in that paper is directed quite clearly to

Speaker: NA
Text: those smaller nursing homes, especially small

Speaker: NA
Text: country nursing homes. The response from

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government is, 'Get big or get out'. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will quote from the section entitled 'Over-

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the Proposal'. Paragraph 6 (a) reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: State Offices are to hold discussions with the

Speaker: NA
Text: etors of all small homes to facilitate the amalgama-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion or expansion of these homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is it. The State office of the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: department will talk to these homes and say,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'You've got two options: you get big or you

Speaker: NA
Text: get out'. Let us look at the options. One is

Speaker: NA
Text: for such homes to get big. If one is running

Speaker: NA
Text: a nursing home in the Riverland, one cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: get big because the Government says, 'We

Speaker: NA
Text: will not approve any more beds. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: enough beds in the area now'. In fact, there

Speaker: NA
Text: probably will be a few more-up to 10 more

Speaker: NA
Text: beds by 1996. So what option is one left

Speaker: NA
Text: with? The option is to get out. Is that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's policy? What the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is saying is, 'You needn't really get out, but

Speaker: NA
Text: you'll have to amalgamate'. That means close

Speaker: NA
Text: one of them and amalgamate with a town

Speaker: NA
Text: up the river, or down the river in the case

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Riverland.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Duncan-Or across the river.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and Education Services is quite right.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, one could go across the river

Speaker: NA
Text: in Berri to Loxton. There is a bit of a prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem because the South Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has promised to put a bridge across the

Speaker: NA
Text: river, but it has failed to come up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. It keeps diverting the funds to yet

Speaker: NA
Text: another broken promise, to other roadways.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are probably in the Minister's bloomin'

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Harry Edwards-It is a well repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: think the margin has been dropping every

Speaker: NA
Text: election and I suggest that with the candi-

Speaker: NA
Text: date we have got this time around it may

Speaker: NA
Text: well drop to a negative. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has identified some of these smaller homes

Speaker: NA
Text: as falling into a special category, so the first

Speaker: NA
Text: thing I did in relation to a number of these

Speaker: NA
Text: small nursing homes in country areas in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate was to see whether they fall into

Speaker: NA
Text: this special category.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two types of special homes: the

Speaker: NA
Text: first are remote homes, and the others are

Speaker: NA
Text: what are called other special homes. Remote

Speaker: NA
Text: homes are ones that are a long way from

Speaker: NA
Text: anywhere. They have to range from 100 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 250 kilometres from another home, presum-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably. That just does not apply in my area. It

Speaker: NA
Text: propriprobably applies to Oodnadatta and maybe

Speaker: NA
Text: Alice Springs, but it does not apply to most

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas in South Australia. The Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment goes on to say that the definition of

Speaker: NA
Text: 'remote' is now being reconsidered with fig-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures as low as 75 kilometres not being en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirely excluded. Even so, that will not apply

Speaker: NA
Text: to all the towns I have mentioned here

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight. So they do not fall into the category

Speaker: NA
Text: as currently defined as 'remote'. Are they

Speaker: NA
Text: special homes? Special homes are general

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose homes that cater for people who

Speaker: NA
Text: have cultural and language differences or

Speaker: NA
Text: dietary requirements. Aboriginal and most

Speaker: NA
Text: ethnic homes would meet this criterion. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Berri home has two Aboriginals in it-one

Speaker: NA
Text: in the nursing home and one in the hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: home-but I doubt whether that will fall

Speaker: NA
Text: into the category of a special home. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has provided some exemptions,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they are so limited as to not meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: need, certainly in country areas in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government, it seems to me, will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to review the application of these rules

Speaker: NA
Text: and see whether it cannot either amend the

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption categories to broaden them or

Speaker: NA
Text: amend the classification system. Unless the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is willing to take a more reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able, realistic and responsible look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: particular problems of some of these country

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes providing care to their com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities, the only option, it appears, is to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt its line of 'Get big or get out'. Is this

Speaker: NA
Text: a viable, alternative? I have said already that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not possible under the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: rules to get big-for example, in the River-

Speaker: NA
Text: land-because it will not allow the beds. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a catch 22 situation. Let me read to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House from a letter that I have received

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Barmera Nursing Home which looks

Speaker: NA
Text: at the proposal being put to them by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government-the 'get big or get out' pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal. The letter I have from the director of

Speaker: NA
Text: that nursing home says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposal suggests several areas at which small

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes should look, these areas being amal-

Speaker: NA
Text: gamation with another home to increase bed num-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers, expansion by getting approval to increase bed

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers, purchase of a home that is closing down-

Speaker: NA
Text: there could be a few of those around with

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government in charge-

Speaker: NA
Text: or closing down our nursing home and selling the

Speaker: NA
Text: beds.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have given these options very careful consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration and find that none of these options are

Speaker: NA
Text: suitable. Firstly, to amalgamate with another home

Speaker: NA
Text: means that we have to relocate one or the other

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home to one site at significant capital cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would result in one of our communities in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Riverland being without a nursing home and there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore .the elderly residents could no longer continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to live in the towns in which they have grown up.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Braithwaite-Is the Government going

Speaker: NA
Text: to contribute to the capital cost?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: tal cost. The letter goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: To amalgamate and leave the nursing home situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated in the present location does not achieve any

Speaker: NA
Text: significant savings. Also, the grant for which private

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise home would be eligible for to assist in

Speaker: NA
Text: amalgamation or expansion of $4,000 per bed is

Speaker: NA
Text: grossly inadequate and does not go anywhere near

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting capital costs involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the Minister: what is the cost of estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishing these new beds? If homes want to

Speaker: NA
Text: amalgamate, they will have to shut one down

Speaker: NA
Text: and build the beds adjacent to one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing homes. I bet the Government cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: build a bed for $4,000, yet that is the assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance it will give homes. The letter further

Speaker: NA
Text: states:

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to expansion of nursing home beds, this

Speaker: NA
Text: option would not be supported by your Department

Speaker: NA
Text: as it is currently considered that the Riverland area

Speaker: NA
Text: in which Barmera is located already has too many

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home beds.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the point I was making earlier. The

Speaker: NA
Text: letter continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: To purchase a home that is closing down would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a very expensive exercise as I believe nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home beds are valued at between $20,000 and $35,000

Speaker: NA
Text: per bed and we would still require Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: approval to have these beds relocated if this was a

Speaker: NA
Text: viable option.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is another route that is closed off by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. The letter goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to closing the nursing home and selling

Speaker: NA
Text: our beds, this would result in having to relocate 20

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home residents to other nursing homes. This

Speaker: NA
Text: would mean residents being accommodated outside

Speaker: NA
Text: of their home towns and would have a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on their families and the quality of life that

Speaker: NA
Text: the resident would be able to lead due to reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with his immediate family. It also leaves us

Speaker: NA
Text: with the situation of having a new building approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately four years old going to waste.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other problem is that if these nursing homes

Speaker: NA
Text: were to close down, there could be significant impact

Speaker: NA
Text: on the acute beds at local hospitals and this is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that should not be forgotten as the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of accommodating long term patients in an acute

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital situation is far greater than accommodating

Speaker: NA
Text: them in a nursing home.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that situation the Barmera Nursing Home

Speaker: NA
Text: has looked at the Government's paper and

Speaker: NA
Text: considered what options are open to it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government could cut funding by up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $91,000. What will it do? Will it get big or

Speaker: NA
Text: get out? It says, 'We have looked at the get

Speaker: NA
Text: big option and we are not allowed to take

Speaker: NA
Text: that. If we get out, what will we do with

Speaker: NA
Text: our 20 patients? We have a responsibility to

Speaker: NA
Text: them. We don't want to shove them off to

Speaker: NA
Text: another town up or down the river. Even if

Speaker: NA
Text: the residents and the community agreed with

Speaker: NA
Text: that, how on earth do we fund the shift?'.

Speaker: NA
Text: As you can imagine, Mr Deputy Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Riverland area is up in arms over the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's proposal. The threat to the

Speaker: NA
Text: homes in that area has been taken very se-

Speaker: NA
Text: riously by the community. There was a meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing last week which some 250 people

Speaker: NA
Text: attended. I have received a letter which has

Speaker: NA
Text: also been sent to the Minister for Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: and Aged Care ( Mr Staples). It sets out the

Speaker: NA
Text: community's concern. Do you know, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, that in a couple of days

Speaker: NA
Text: that community got 457 signatures on the

Speaker: NA
Text: letter that was sent to the Minister. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: an indication of the concern about the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pact of these changes that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is making.

Speaker: NA
Text: The resolution of the problem seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: me to be in the Government's hands. It

Speaker: NA
Text: seems that it must take account of the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems of servicing country towns. The Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment can do that only if it acknowledges

Speaker: NA
Text: that the city model does not fit in the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. The Government has to allow the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try nursing homes to continue to operate on

Speaker: NA
Text: a viable basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: These country nursing homes that I, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Lyne and others on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the chamber have referred

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight operate with enormous community

Speaker: NA
Text: support. They provide much needed care to ing home viable.

Speaker: NA
Text: our elderly and infirm in country and city

Speaker: NA
Text: areas alike. Country people surely have

Speaker: NA
Text: much right to access to a nursing home within

Speaker: NA
Text: their community as do city people. It is this

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental right which the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: calling into question with its forced amalChris

Speaker: NA
Text: gamation proposal involving the loss to some

Speaker: NA
Text: communities for their nursing homes. Counwell

Speaker: NA
Text: try people have done a lot for this nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Right now it is the rural exporters who are

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing home the bacon, as the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: says. The only thanks they get from this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is another kick in the teeth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our road funding has been cut; country

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital funds have been cut, especially in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia where recently we saw the

Speaker: NA
Text: State Government cut funding for the Blyth

Speaker: NA
Text: and Tailem Bend hospitals dramatically;

Speaker: NA
Text: our rail services have been cut. Now the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Labor Government is proposing

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant cuts to nursing home funding to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent that some will be forced to close

Speaker: NA
Text: down under this amalgamation proposal.

Speaker: NA
Text: Enough is enough. I urge the Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: review the criteria applying to this area

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. I do not question the goals of this

Speaker: NA
Text: program, as I said at the beginning of my

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution. Generally we agree with the

Speaker: NA
Text: overall approach that has been adopted, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the criteria of funding must take into

Speaker: NA
Text: count the differences in population size in

Speaker: NA
Text: various areas, service delivery and access.

Speaker: NA
Text: They must take into account the differences

Speaker: NA
Text: between city and country to ensure equality

Speaker: NA
Text: of treatment.

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Text: Gippsland) (9.52)- the

Speaker: NA
Text: On 26 February this year, a short while ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: I had the honour and privilege of officially

Speaker: NA
Text: opening the refurbished west wing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Toora nursing home in South Gippsland. This

Speaker: NA
Text: was once a bush nursing hospital that was

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to close in 1984 with the introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: of the insidious Medicare system. But let

Speaker: NA
Text: not dwell on past events; suffice it to

Speaker: NA
Text: local community and committee of manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had the foresight, wisdom and wit to

Speaker: NA
Text: go about providing a much needed facility

Speaker: NA
Text: for their community. There were already

Speaker: NA
Text: some 14 nursing home beds attached to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Toora bush nursing hospital. On its closure

Speaker: NA
Text: it was sought to add another 16 beds so as

Speaker: NA
Text: to to make up that minimum number of 30

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home beds necessary to make a nurs-·

Speaker: NA
Text: To cut a long story short, because there

Speaker: NA
Text: as are a number of aspects of concern to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Toora nursing home that I wish to touch on,

Speaker: NA
Text: I should only say that it took several years

Speaker: NA
Text: is of resolute determinedness on the part of

Speaker: NA
Text: Flynn, the secretary-manager, and Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Ian Park, the president of the committee, as

Speaker: NA
Text: as all of those on the committee and

Speaker: NA
Text: those in the wider community, to bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: a reclassification of those empty bush nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home beds into nursing home beds. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was some capital outlay in converting the

Speaker: NA
Text: west wing of the old bush nursing hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: into the nursing home. As you, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, representing the electorate of Lyne,

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in an earlier speech, these nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes can only exist in rural communities

Speaker: NA
Text: and with dedication and support of the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities they seek to serve. The example of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sigToora nursing home bears out your own

Speaker: NA
Text: words. It was not just the work of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee and the secretary-manager that

Speaker: NA
Text: brought about this wonderful achievement;

Speaker: NA
Text: it was also the ladies auxilliary, led by the

Speaker: NA
Text: of president, Mrs Dene Wogan Browne, as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as a contribution made from a coordinating

Speaker: NA
Text: committee of the adjoining Albertan shire,

Speaker: NA
Text: headed by Mrs Val Niggl. I understand also

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Toora Lions Club played a part in

Speaker: NA
Text: acfitting out the nursing home extensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Toora's opening took place amongst a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of debate about the future accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation for the elderly in our society. It seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to me that what is at issue is how to best

Speaker: NA
Text: direct government resources to the care of

Speaker: NA
Text: aged so that individuals are best served

Speaker: NA
Text: according to their respective needs. In addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, it is also important to lay the founda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of a lasting system of care which will

Speaker: NA
Text: be sufficiently flexible and sensitive to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the changing and growing needs of a popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation which is rapidly ageing. It is vital to

Speaker: NA
Text: me build a system of care for the aged which

Speaker: NA
Text: say the will be able to cope with change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like most mature Western societies Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is undergoing a transformation in its

Speaker: NA
Text: age structure. As a population we are getting

Speaker: NA
Text: older. There are many reasons why this is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening. For the most part the cause of

Speaker: NA
Text: this marked trend in ageing is that the deised

Speaker: NA
Text: cline in birth rate over past decades is taking

Speaker: NA
Text: place against the background of normally

Speaker: NA
Text: high periods of fertility at the mid-century,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in the post-war years which

Speaker: NA
Text: become known as the baby boom period.

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreover, the benefits of modern medicine

Speaker: NA
Text: an- -echnology with our increased quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: life has seen an increase in life expectancy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The statistical implications of these trends

Speaker: NA
Text: are dramatic. The number of people aged 60

Speaker: NA
Text: years and over is expected to rise from

Speaker: NA
Text: million in 1981 to three million by the year

Speaker: NA
Text: 2001 and to five million by the year 2021,

Speaker: NA
Text: meaning that 22 per cent of our population

Speaker: NA
Text: will be aged over 60 by the year 2021.

Speaker: NA
Text: These statistics are very real for governsame

Speaker: NA
Text: ments as they consider how best to plan

Speaker: NA
Text: the care of the elderly into the next century.

Speaker: NA
Text: Between 1981 and 2001 the increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: aged population will mean that governments

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to increase their outlays on the

Speaker: NA
Text: elderly by 131 per cent. This will mean a

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent rise in government outlays in real

Speaker: NA
Text: terms between 2000 and 2021. Already

Speaker: NA
Text: third of the health and welfare budget

Speaker: NA
Text: spent on the elderly, which works out to be

Speaker: NA
Text: some $3,781 for each individual. I might add

Speaker: NA
Text: that on the current numbers 14 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: our population falls within the category

Speaker: NA
Text: elderly. The demand on government expendnity

Speaker: NA
Text: iture will be increased by still another factor.

Speaker: NA
Text: The current decline in the birth rate will

Speaker: NA
Text: mean a reduction in the tax base in future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The lowering of expenditure on the young,

Speaker: NA
Text: owing to their decrease in numbers, will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be anywhere near enough to cover the

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in outlays for the increasing number

Speaker: NA
Text: of elderly.

Speaker: NA
Text: The task for governments is very real. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: only do we have to ensure that the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: grows in order to provide for the funds neceach

Speaker: NA
Text: essary to maintain a viable system for the

Speaker: NA
Text: elderly but we need also to look closely

Speaker: NA
Text: how we can make the system of care more

Speaker: NA
Text: effective by better directing resources whilst hostels.

Speaker: NA
Text: at the same time ensuring every aged person

Speaker: NA
Text: receives a level of support appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: their medical, social and emotional needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: To achieve this end I think it is necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: have regard to a number of basic principles.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the first instance the elderly should,

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate, be supported in their own

Speaker: NA
Text: and in their own communities. Institutionalknown

Speaker: NA
Text: care, whether it be in hostels or homes

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the Toora nursing home, should only

Speaker: NA
Text: be relied upon when no other style of accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation suits the needs of the individual.

Speaker: NA
Text: have Nursing home care, as you would know bet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter than anyone, Mr Deputy Speaker, is the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest and most important level of care

Speaker: NA
Text: available but is also the most expensive.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 1987 figures-the most recent avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able-there were 68,642 beds in nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes nationally. The recurrent expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: two for the same year for nursing homes was

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.1 billion. Assuming each bed available

Speaker: NA
Text: represents an individual, this makes for a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth outlay of $16,439.50 per res-

Speaker: NA
Text: ident. By way of contrast, hostel care for the

Speaker: NA
Text: year represents an outlay of $1,727.26

Speaker: NA
Text: for per person, making 38,800 resident places

Speaker: NA
Text: against recurrent outlays of $67,028,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: the While I am in sympathy with the general

Speaker: NA
Text: trend towards a diversification of the levels

Speaker: NA
Text: of care available to the elderly, it must be

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 said that diversification has its pitfalls.

Speaker: NA
Text: Change can be seized upon too impetuously

Speaker: NA
Text: oneand imbalances can quickly occur in the

Speaker: NA
Text: is provision of vital services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The present Government believes that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is necessary to reduce the past emphasis on

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for nursing homes and, instead, build

Speaker: NA
Text: of up the resources of the hostel and commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: based support systems. Increased fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for hostels will mean that between 1989

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1991 some 12,300 new hostel places will

Speaker: NA
Text: be established nationally against only 1,400

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home beds for the same period. To

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasise this trend in other terms, the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: inernment aims to provide 100 residential

Speaker: NA
Text: places per 1,000 members of the population

Speaker: NA
Text: aged over 70 years. To' achieve the goal of

Speaker: NA
Text: diversification, the Government is seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve a mix of 40 nursing' home places for

Speaker: NA
Text: 60 hostel places by early next century.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will mean that only 10 per cent of new

Speaker: NA
Text: at places allocated in the future will be for

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes; the remainder will be for

Speaker: NA
Text: For us in Victoria this means that between

Speaker: NA
Text: to now and 1992 only 544 new nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: places will be established, whilst 4,814 hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: to places will be created. The implications of

Speaker: NA
Text: this policy are only too obvious. Indicative

Speaker: NA
Text: when of the same reallocation of resources, the

Speaker: NA
Text: homes home and community care scheme, better

Speaker: NA
Text: as HACC, received in excess of an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional $100m between 1985 and 1988,

Speaker: NA
Text: being roughly a 50 per cent increase in fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing within a three-year period. Managing

Speaker: NA
Text: change on this scale and ensuring the main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenance of standards of care gives rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: problems of enormous complexity and pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent governments with significant challenges.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet these are challenges that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment must take up.

Speaker: NA
Text: If it were not of such practical significance

Speaker: NA
Text: I would have been embarrassed to talk of

Speaker: NA
Text: care for the elderly in the terms that I have,

Speaker: NA
Text: of dull statistics and so forth. As a rule, the

Speaker: NA
Text: elderly ought to be spoken of in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: compassion and respect, and that ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: be enough to drive the system on. Moreover,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am uneasy at having referred to the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: in such general terms. After all, the care

Speaker: NA
Text: services I have outlined are designed to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cognise the very diversity of the elderly.

Speaker: NA
Text: ing does not necessarily mean entry into a

Speaker: NA
Text: period of disadvantage and dependency. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is a myth. The facts of old age are that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: a fulfilling stage of life, a period in which

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals and couples might find new ways

Speaker: NA
Text: to continue to make contributions to the

Speaker: NA
Text: family and to the community in however

Speaker: NA
Text: modest a way. The ability to contribute and

Speaker: NA
Text: to feel that life is still valuable depends on

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunities we provide, the doors we

Speaker: NA
Text: _leave open which will enable the elderly to

Speaker: NA
Text: exploit further their skills, talents and

Speaker: NA
Text: ests which have developed over a lifetime.

Speaker: NA
Text: The principles I have outlined are at risk

Speaker: NA
Text: in many nursing homes in Victoria. Let me

Speaker: NA
Text: take as an example of the callousness of

Speaker: NA
Text: some aspects of the Government's new sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem the Toora nursing home. Under the new

Speaker: NA
Text: system, new residents will be classified ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cording to the severity of their disability,

Speaker: NA
Text: categories 1, 2 and 3 being the most in need

Speaker: NA
Text: of direct and constant care, categories 4 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 requiring less care. Under the care aggre-

Speaker: NA
Text: gate module (CAM), subsidies are paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes in relation to the cost per

Speaker: NA
Text: staff hour of providing nursing home care.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this basis a category 1 patient receives

Speaker: NA
Text: 27 nursing care hours per week, category 2

Speaker: NA
Text: receives 23t hours, category 3 receives 20

Speaker: NA
Text: hours, category 4 receives 13 hours and cat-

Speaker: NA
Text: egory 5 receives 10 hours. One can see the

Speaker: NA
Text: decreasing scale of nursing care provided ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cording to the category. The actual subsidy

Speaker: NA
Text: that a nursing home receives varies, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the relative costs of nursing and

Speaker: NA
Text: so forth in each State. In Victoria a category

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 patient attracts a subsidy of $67.60 while

Speaker: NA
Text: a category 5 resident attracts a subsidy of

Speaker: NA
Text: only $25.57. In contrast, the standard aggre-

Speaker: NA
Text: gate module (SAM) provides for a fixed and

Speaker: NA
Text: uniform subsidy according to a government-

Speaker: NA
Text: determined standard required to meet infras-

Speaker: NA
Text: tructure costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many problems with this ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to financing the residential dimension

Speaker: NA
Text: of the aged care policy of the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, the Government's policies represent

Speaker: NA
Text: a barely disguised attack on the private nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing home sector of the aged care system. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Housing and Aged Care ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Staples) has no sympathy, no understanding,

Speaker: NA
Text: no tolerance and certainly no proper attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: toward private sector nursing homes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Age- policy of this Government will simply re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire private nursing homes to reduce their

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments to providing care to a broad

Speaker: NA
Text: band of patients in need of close care and

Speaker: NA
Text: supervision. Moreover, the Government sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem suffers from rigidity in its application

Speaker: NA
Text: and is based on a dangerous assumption about

Speaker: NA
Text: the uniformity of the residential care system.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my own electorate, Gippsland, one

Speaker: NA
Text: community has struggled to raise the funds

Speaker: NA
Text: to reconstruct a one-time bush nursing hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pital and refashion it into a high standard

Speaker: NA
Text: interprivate nursing home. I refer to the refur-

Speaker: NA
Text: bished Toora nursing home. Sadly, despite

Speaker: NA
Text: the happiness of the official opening on 26

Speaker: NA
Text: February, the Toora nursing home faces a

Speaker: NA
Text: bleak future owing to the Government's in-

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitive and dogmatic approach to nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home funding. Like many private nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes, the Toora nursing home has found

Speaker: NA
Text: that the funding mechanism, CAM, simply

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot ensure that it can provide the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of care needed by its residents. In practice,

Speaker: NA
Text: it knows that the health of a particular pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tient fluctuates on an almost day to day

Speaker: NA
Text: basis. It knows that the level of care-this is

Speaker: NA
Text: crucial-and therefore the level of staffing is

Speaker: NA
Text: never stable and that in matters like this it

Speaker: NA
Text: is vital to have staff on hand.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Housing and Aged Care,

Speaker: NA
Text: who is at the table to take charge of this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, must answer this fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: misconception on the part of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Nursing care for the aged is not static

Speaker: NA
Text: or rigid. In addition, the Secretary-Manager,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chris Flynn, the Director of Nursing,

Speaker: NA
Text: Elaine Scott, and the Deputy Director of

Speaker: NA
Text: Nursing, Sissel Leorke, have found that CAM

Speaker: NA
Text: does not accommodate the particular needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of a rural community. Unlike nursing homes

Speaker: NA
Text: in urban areas, which have access to consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: erable capital and a fixed and concentrated

Speaker: NA
Text: supply of residents, the Toora nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: has had to make do with considerably more

Speaker: NA
Text: humble resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said earlier, the Toora nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: is really grafted on to a bush nursing hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal. It was a community effort based upon

Speaker: NA
Text: funds largely raised locally and it was de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to meet a pressing community need.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the physical constraints of the refur-

Speaker: NA
Text: bished nursing home are poorly understood

Speaker: NA
Text: by the system the Government wishes to

Speaker: NA
Text: impose upon the community. The Toora

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home requires three night staff to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet its needs. Instead of being built in a

Speaker: NA
Text: figure eight shape or in the shape of a square,

Speaker: NA
Text: both of which designs permit a high degree

Speaker: NA
Text: of supervision by way of a central nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: centre, the former bush hospital is limited by

Speaker: NA
Text: its history, in order to maximise the safety

Speaker: NA
Text: and well-being of its residents, to a minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: of three night staff on duty. If two are re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to lift a patient at one end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: home which regrettably is built in a straight

Speaker: NA
Text: line, another must be in attendance at the

Speaker: NA
Text: other end of the hospital. But the resident

Speaker: NA
Text: classification index does not permit staffing

Speaker: NA
Text: at this level. It does not permit the particular

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of the physical history of the nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home to determine its staffing needs. And,

Speaker: NA
Text: by so doing, the rigidity of the funding mech-

Speaker: NA
Text: anism I have outlined places the residents in

Speaker: NA
Text: jeopardy. This is even more apparent when

Speaker: NA
Text: I bring to the House's attention that' there

Speaker: NA
Text: are four or five patients suffering from de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentia in the home. Constant supervision is

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore a priority in an environment of this

Speaker: NA
Text: sort.

Speaker: NA
Text: The particular characteristics of the local

Speaker: NA
Text: community also mitigate against the imposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of uniform funding arrangements sought

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government. Unlike the homes in the

Speaker: NA
Text: urban centres, the Toora Nursing home does

Speaker: NA
Text: not have a steady waiting list of residents

Speaker: NA
Text: who will assume the status of category 1 or

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 patients. The home will not therefore have

Speaker: NA
Text: a steady provision of subsidy at the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: level. This causes difficulties in that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: patients, such as the dementia patients, who

Speaker: NA
Text: require a great deal of supervision, but who

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be adequately taken care of in hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: type accommodation. The finances of the

Speaker: NA
Text: home are therefore placed in extreme diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cultyas the bulk of their residents have been

Speaker: NA
Text: classified as category 4 or 5 and therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: attract the lowest level of funding-a disin-

Speaker: NA
Text: centive designed to weed out patients of this

Speaker: NA
Text: kind and force them into hostel accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation which does not suit their needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has given rise to another problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: Though residents might not in some cases be

Speaker: NA
Text: strictly suited to a nursing home environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, where can they go to when they live

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural or isolated areas? They do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: at their disposal the virtually unlimited re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources of the cities. Is it intended that they

Speaker: NA
Text: uproot themselves from the communities in

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have grown up, in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: have raised families and grown old? Is this

Speaker: NA
Text: the intention of the legislation? The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: is so critical for the Toora Nursing Home as

Speaker: NA
Text: it struggles to meet the needs of its commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity that it has already transferred over

Speaker: NA
Text: $30,000 from its capital budget to its oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating budget in order to keep the home sol-

Speaker: NA
Text: vent. And the problem is getting worse. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has a waiting list of predominantly category

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 and 5 patients who require more care than

Speaker: NA
Text: a hostel can provide them but who cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: live in the community any longer by them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. The Government needs to address the

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of the Toora Nursing Home.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Cowan)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honourable member's time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has moved in haste to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plement measures to require the care of the

Speaker: NA
Text: aged to be administered on .a needs basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those words would seem to express a fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: straightforward and, no doubt, to those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have no real knowledge of care of the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: in nursing homes and hostels, a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition. We have a circumstance in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has moved not just in haste

Speaker: NA
Text: but really in stealth. It has changed drasti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally the guidelines with little opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: for the community to become aware of its

Speaker: NA
Text: intentions, to understand the import and to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to comprehend what is really occur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ring. There is always a need to change a

Speaker: NA
Text: system that has been in operation for a long

Speaker: NA
Text: time-to update, to meet the trends of the

Speaker: NA
Text: time and so on. But what we have in this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and the measures previously intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced by way of regulation and by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: decision of the Government is nothing more

Speaker: NA
Text: or less than an iron-clad directive to all those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been participants, who have

Speaker: NA
Text: work-ed for years, in many instances, to cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate a system providing care for the aged, on

Speaker: NA
Text: a basis of a direct relationship between units

Speaker: NA
Text: for aged persons, hostels and a nursing home.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the north coast of New South Wales,·

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a very substantial demand for care

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the proportion of aged in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community. I have had close and long expe-

Speaker: NA
Text: rience with the work that has been under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken there by recognised institutions, public

Speaker: NA
Text: committees and bodies that have been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for the creation of a chain of nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing home and hostel facilities, which are of

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest possible standard. That has been

Speaker: NA
Text: done with the tremendous support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community and with fund raising referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: by my colleagues who have spoken including

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Lyne ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowan) and the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowper ( Mr Nehl). Of course, also from

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House, the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Dawson ( Mr Braithwaite) very clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: stated some of the important considerations

Speaker: NA
Text: of this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is overlooking the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is all very well to create a blue-print

Speaker: NA
Text: and to try meticulously to spell this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: out on a theoretical basis. It is another mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for it to be put effectively into practice.

Speaker: NA
Text: We see an untidy mix between the important

Speaker: NA
Text: element of capital funding and the subse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quent requirement for maintenance funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hence the determinations that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: get big and then get out, as referred to by

Speaker: NA
Text: my colleague from South Australia the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the impact of that on existing homes and

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions and the danger it poses for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future in the requirements to provide ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quately across the community in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: aged care facilities, straight accommodation

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels and nursing homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is all very well to say that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: great need to move from' the submission

Speaker: NA
Text: model that was so clearly understood by the

Speaker: NA
Text: community for so long. This concept was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced in the Menzies Government by

Speaker: NA
Text: the late Sir Earle Page as Minister for Health .

Speaker: NA
Text: who provided enormous leadership in this

Speaker: NA
Text: field a very long time ago. In my area today,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are still one or two homes that were

Speaker: NA
Text: built as a direct result of his energetic ap7

Speaker: NA
Text: proach at that time to make it possible for

Speaker: NA
Text: capital funding to be provided and to set the

Speaker: NA
Text: starting point for the establishment of effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive care of the aged. This, to a large extent,

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be jettisoned under this new direction

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition. They are indeed new directions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The administration of homes for the aged in

Speaker: NA
Text: both nursing homes and hostels is becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: a nightmare because the maintenance fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing is now being provided on a basis referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to clearly in this debate by some of my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues-this is without question-that is

Speaker: NA
Text: hampering the day to day operation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: system. There is no clear and definitive an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer in overcoming the problems that have

Speaker: NA
Text: arisen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Housing and Aged Care

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Staples) has not been very closely in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in this debate. I hope that tomorrow

Speaker: NA
Text: he answers many of the questions that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been raised-and answers them in a clear

Speaker: NA
Text: and understandable fashion. One of the first

Speaker: NA
Text: matters that I hope he clears up is the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of pushing out the private nursing homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, it is a determination by the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment that they should be squeezed out.

Speaker: NA
Text: If that is to be the agenda, I want to know

Speaker: NA
Text: how the projected future creation of facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: will cater for all of the needs that are so

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious, if one makes an assessment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: communities and the proportion of aged per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons, and the percentages so dramatically

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland ( Mr MCGauran). It is a challenge

Speaker: NA
Text: that must be met in this day and age. We

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want it to be met by gross waste and,

Speaker: NA
Text: by failure to have effective administration,

Speaker: NA
Text: effective Government oversight and all the

Speaker: NA
Text: rest. But we do not want it to be so admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: istered that we get down to the incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: process that there is a Star Chamber process

Speaker: NA
Text: to determine who will get the benefits and

Speaker: NA
Text: how they will get those benefits. The con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tents of this legislation does just that.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a very great worry to the medical

Speaker: NA
Text: profession in many parts of Australia, cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly in my own electorate, and it is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: great worry to the administrators of existing

Speaker: NA
Text: health services to find that the restrictions

Speaker: NA
Text: that are envisaged will in fact create very

Speaker: NA
Text: great difficulties in giving advice to families

Speaker: NA
Text: when a family member. becomes aged and is

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer in a state of health that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as safe for home care. We will not

Speaker: NA
Text: have the facilities. We may well find that an

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible situation will be created where

Speaker: NA
Text: families cannot find an answer to that prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem. They can go back to their local medico

Speaker: NA
Text: who can say that a particular person should

Speaker: NA
Text: be in a nursing home, but the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: that will determine whether that is so may

Speaker: NA
Text: well say that there is no case. So what hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pens? You get great trauma and the situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in which home care, even the visitations,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a service that is provided in most

Speaker: NA
Text: communities these days to assist, by all sorts

Speaker: NA
Text: of trained people, will not adequately cover

Speaker: NA
Text: the need.

Speaker: NA
Text: This occurs for a very obvious reason.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless we have the impetus, which was al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways part and parcel of the system, where

Speaker: NA
Text: funds are raised by communities able to do

Speaker: NA
Text: this-and when that was done the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was prepared to come forth with its

Speaker: NA
Text: share of the capital requirement to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities-we are going to have a circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance in which the community will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting, as it has in the past, the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: provision. Maybe that is a saving for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in the long term, because there

Speaker: NA
Text: is less of a financial requirement in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance, but what does that do for the

Speaker: NA
Text: needy? What does that do for the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities that expect to have adequate provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion? The answer from the Government is,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Oh, here are the statistics. We are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide X number of beds for X number of

Speaker: NA
Text: aged people in' every community'. Where

Speaker: NA
Text: does that fall to the ground? It falls to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ground because the geographical locations

Speaker: NA
Text: set out for the various regions are not prac-'

Speaker: NA
Text: tical. They are not practical because they

Speaker: NA
Text: just take into account local government areas

Speaker: NA
Text: and regions without regard to the nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: those communities in terms of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who live there. They disregard distance and

Speaker: NA
Text: community of interest, and they do not re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cognise the obvious overlapping there is when

Speaker: NA
Text: a region has to look at the delineation of its

Speaker: NA
Text: local government boundaries.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to explain why this is sheer non-

Speaker: NA
Text: sense. Unless you have a relationship be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the provision of nursing homes and

Speaker: NA
Text: hostels and the availability of medical serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ices, ambulance services and many other

Speaker: NA
Text: things that aged people need, they are left

Speaker: NA
Text: really in isolation. It does not work. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: go back just a short time span, there was the

Speaker: NA
Text: advent of the concept that a nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: and a hostel should be of a particular size

Speaker: NA
Text: and that it was an advantage if it had some

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship to an existing institution, proba-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly a hospital that had a modern kitchen

Speaker: NA
Text: and modern laundry, and it could share those

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities. I can quote examples at Macksville

Speaker: NA
Text: in the electorate of Cowper-my colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Cowper knows

Speaker: NA
Text: this location very well-and at Grafton in

Speaker: NA
Text: my own electorate and so the list would go

Speaker: NA
Text: on if one were to name all the locations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The relationship between a public hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: in terms of its kitchens, laundries and so on

Speaker: NA
Text: and a nursing home or hostel has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty good proposition. But now that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: really regarded any longer as significant. The

Speaker: NA
Text: idea now is that one just looks at the statis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tics. The people in the local government

Speaker: NA
Text: areas do not even try to work out how that

Speaker: NA
Text: fits into the overall community pattern and

Speaker: NA
Text: say, 'This is how we are going to do it'. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that is. simply a blueprint for disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: in the long term.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a need for a different kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: provision in a variety of locations. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard from South Australia and Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: about the problem of bush hospitals and

Speaker: NA
Text: small institutions. In parts of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales there is a similar circumstance. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Riverina-Darling ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hicks) referred to that circumstance. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: more heavily populated areas of the coast

Speaker: NA
Text: the circumstances are totally different. The

Speaker: NA
Text: creation of the larger related community style

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities for the aged there, is much more

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate-units, hostels and a nearby

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home-so that there can be a blend

Speaker: NA
Text: of the facilities and the services and a means

Speaker: NA
Text: of administration that is practical. The en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couragement of local support to enable that

Speaker: NA
Text: to work and be ongoing has not been recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised under this legislation in a practical

Speaker: NA
Text: way. The community is really in the dark as

Speaker: NA
Text: to what the ultimate procedure for encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement and support will be. All the local

Speaker: NA
Text: communities know is the kind of answer that

Speaker: NA
Text: one of my colleagues earlier this evening

Speaker: NA
Text: read in response to a letter written by a local

Speaker: NA
Text: committee seeking advice as to the steps that

Speaker: NA
Text: should be taken in order to have facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: created in that particular locality. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: received similar letters. The detail contained

Speaker: NA
Text: in the letters might be very clear to those

Speaker: NA
Text: who sent out the correspondence for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and might be very clear to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department, but it does not tell the local

Speaker: NA
Text: people a darn thing. As far as the local

Speaker: NA
Text: member is concerned, he is usually the last

Speaker: NA
Text: to know these days what is going on. I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to say to the Minister that that is a sorry

Speaker: NA
Text: state of affairs. It does not matter which side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House one is on. Over the years this

Speaker: NA
Text: has always been a bipartisan process. Homes

Speaker: NA
Text: for the aged have not been a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: playing politics. If it is to trend that way, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a pretty sorry state of affairs. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that members of this House have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately informed by the Minister. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been no general advice and no letter that

Speaker: NA
Text: says, 'This is the new system, this is how it

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to operate'. We all have to go cap

Speaker: NA
Text: in hand to someone and start asking a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: questions to find out what is happening in

Speaker: NA
Text: our electorates. I believe that applies to

Speaker: NA
Text: members on both sides of the House. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: say to the Minister that when he responds

Speaker: NA
Text: to the debate later he should particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: take on board the significance of that.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the moment or two that is left to me,

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to say that the Minister might also

Speaker: NA
Text: give some update on the press statement,

Speaker: NA
Text: which he issued in response to the report on

Speaker: NA
Text: the operation of nursing homes, it has caused

Speaker: NA
Text: a great deal of concern to excellent nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes throughout Australia which, it is sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gested, are under scrutiny in that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: not been doing their job. I believe that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very unsatisfactory situation. There have been

Speaker: NA
Text: 44 proposals mooted apparently in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: how institutions should in future be run.

Speaker: NA
Text: Forty-four major reforms have been recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended; How can one have those reforms

Speaker: NA
Text: and at the same time have the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions so restricted under the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House that administrators are at

Speaker: NA
Text: their wits' end to keep their particular insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tution functioning?

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: Bhutan and Bangladesh-Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: Member for Port Adelaide- Mr Konrad

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalejs-League of Rights-Women Who

Speaker: NA
Text: Want to be Women-Honourable Member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Adelaide-Radiography

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Cowan)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the

Speaker: NA
Text: question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: Farrer)(10.30)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight I want to salute two countries of

Speaker: NA
Text: quite different extremes, namely Bhutan and

Speaker: NA
Text: Bangladesh. I do so quite deliberately as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of a pro-Asian strategy to build up our po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical, cultural and economic links with Asia,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Federal member for Farrer and shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for veterans' affairs and on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of the coalition for its own part as it recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nises where our future lies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had the privilege of being perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: first member of the Australian Parliament to

Speaker: NA
Text: visit Bhutan, located as it is between India

Speaker: NA
Text: and Tibet, during the recent summer recess.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is one kingdom that values its rich and

Speaker: NA
Text: colourful heritage and it has taken positive

Speaker: NA
Text: steps to retain· that heritage, despite some

Speaker: NA
Text: limited modernisation and some modest in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in tourism. It has a very popular

Speaker: NA
Text: King, who is a determined young man who

Speaker: NA
Text: . lives quite modestly and who has recently,

Speaker: NA
Text: through Bhutan's judicial system, been quite

Speaker: NA
Text: relaxed about seeing one or two Ministers go

Speaker: NA
Text: to gaol who were involved with corruption,

Speaker: NA
Text: so determined is he to see that his kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: is not corrupt and does not go down the

Speaker: NA
Text: path of other kingdoms which have suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: from a great deal of corruption, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: flowing from foreign aid. Indeed, Bhutan

Speaker: NA
Text: hesitates to take on foreign aid. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: conscious that it can absorb only a degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign aid and it quite often rejects sugges-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions from countries wanting to give it for-

Speaker: NA
Text: eign aid, to make sure that it does retain its

Speaker: NA
Text: balance and culture in a sensible way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia enjoys very good relations with

Speaker: NA
Text: Bhutan and has a modest foreign aid pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram, including merino sheep breeding at

Speaker: NA
Text: 10,000 feet-plus on the slopes of the Hima-

Speaker: NA
Text: layas. It was certainly a very rare privilege

Speaker: NA
Text: to have visited Bhutan and to see the state

Speaker: NA
Text: of relations between it and Australia and to

Speaker: NA
Text: see Australian aid workers in many and var-

Speaker: NA
Text: ied situations of some considerable hardship,

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying out their duties. To all of that I

Speaker: NA
Text: would simply add one tip to those who might

Speaker: NA
Text: be seeking to go to Bhutan: beware of arrows

Speaker: NA
Text: overhead, because archery is still very popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar; it abounds. When I walked out of a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular ruined dzong, or castle, I heard a

Speaker: NA
Text: swish in the air and looked up and realised

Speaker: NA
Text: that I had walked straight into the middle of

Speaker: NA
Text: a target range for the local archery practice.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the ides of March next week-on 15

Speaker: NA
Text: March-Bhutan will in one sense move closer

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia when direct flights start from

Speaker: NA
Text: Bangkok to Paro, just near the capital Thim-

Speaker: NA
Text: phu by Druk Air, flying a BAe146, linking

Speaker: NA
Text: up with Thai Airways International and/or

Speaker: NA
Text: Qantas. I think a greater interest in Bhutan

Speaker: NA
Text: will be taken by people in Australia. Bhutan

Speaker: NA
Text: is an independent member of the South East

Speaker: NA
Text: Asian community group of nations and a

Speaker: NA
Text: free voting member of the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: and one which Australia should continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: build up its relations with, notwithstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that it is a small country with only

Speaker: NA
Text: just. over one million people. But I say again

Speaker: NA
Text: it is a colourful country with a rich heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: and one that it was a privilege to visit.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to the second country, Bangladesh.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am delighted to say that there are two

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of great tranquillity in Bangladesh, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer to the war cemeteries at Comilla and

Speaker: NA
Text: Chittagong, out on the eastern side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bangladesh, which I visited in my capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: as shadow Minister for veterans' affairs. Not-

Speaker: NA
Text: withstanding all the turmoil of Bangladesh,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cyclones, the floods of last year, the

Speaker: NA
Text: derailments and the horrific tragedies, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause its population is some 110 million and

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment anything goes wrong, it always

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to go very badly wrong, those two war

Speaker: NA
Text: cemeteries, containing the graves of over

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,400 allied Service personnel, including many

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Air Force and Royal Australian Air

Speaker: NA
Text: Force personnel, are in excellent order. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: delighted to report that much to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: In passing I mention my concern at the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect that the Office of Australian War

Speaker: NA
Text: Graves may be under some review. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: be totally opposed to any abolition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Office of Australian War Graves. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: would cut across the intent of this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to see that proper maintenance is car-

Speaker: NA
Text: ried out on all war graves, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian war graves in Australia or Asia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly there are problems in Bangla-

Speaker: NA
Text: desh and there are problems with the aid

Speaker: NA
Text: programs and the direction and focus of those

Speaker: NA
Text: aid programs. Clearly that needs to be more

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly monitored.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I salute those Australians who

Speaker: NA
Text: serve this country, be they with the aid pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams or with the Department of Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs and Trade, in such countries as Bhu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tan and Bangladesh. They are not easy post-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. They serve their country well and they

Speaker: NA
Text: deserve credit for their work.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal member for Adelaide people often

Speaker: NA
Text: ask me if I enjoy my job. My reply to them

Speaker: NA
Text: is that I love it. I think I understand what

Speaker: NA
Text: politics and Parliament are about and the

Speaker: NA
Text: learning process which this adjournment de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate affords me. Last Thursday, as I con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded my speech on the Aged or Disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: Persons Homes Amendment Bill-a very

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitive and important issue-I stayed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to listen to the adjournment debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Imagine my surprise when the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Port Adelaide ( Mr Sawford)

Speaker: NA
Text: hauled himself to his feet, not to speak on

Speaker: NA
Text: the fall of living standards and high interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates which are crippling his constituents in

Speaker: NA
Text: Westlakes, or perhaps to deliver his view on

Speaker: NA
Text: pornographic videos or the value of the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: marine corporation, but to chop me up for

Speaker: NA
Text: daring to do something about the plight of

Speaker: NA
Text: our elderly. He referred to me attending a

Speaker: NA
