Text: senior citizens rally in Adelaide last week,

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to portray that marvellous group of

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned taxpayers who have been ne-

Speaker: NA
Text: glected and rejected and now feel dejected

Speaker: NA
Text: by this out of touch government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Port Adelaide was

Speaker: NA
Text: very qualified to speak about this rally in

Speaker: NA
Text: light of the fact that he did not even bother

Speaker: NA
Text: to attend it! Along with the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hawker ( Mrs Harvey), I joined

Speaker: NA
Text: the 5,000 who marched from Victoria Square

Speaker: NA
Text: to Elder Park in that century-plus heat, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it is a wonder more did not keel over. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Port Adelaide pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeds to lambaste the Liberals, Greypower,

Speaker: NA
Text: one of my staff, and whoever else gets in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way of his vitriolic tongue. But his source of

Speaker: NA
Text: information came from that great periodical,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Herald, the Australian Labor Party's toe

Speaker: NA
Text: rag produced in Adelaide. On a front page

Speaker: NA
Text: was a big spread by the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Hawker, and on the back page an article

Speaker: NA
Text: by a David Harvey on retirement incomes

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled 'Watch This Greypower Group'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Port Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted directly from this piece of gutter press,

Speaker: NA
Text: where it is fair game to attack not only a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of my staff but also Mrs Jessie Tay-

Speaker: NA
Text: lor, President of the 5,000 strong Senior Cit-

Speaker: NA
Text: izens of Australia. She is not a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party, as quoted by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member. He is also having a go at

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide's Lord Mayor, Steve Condous, who

Speaker: NA
Text: is the group's patron. If we turn the page of

Speaker: NA
Text: this magazine we find four Labor candidates

Speaker: NA
Text: who are currently staffers for State and Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral politicians-a typical arrogant attitude,

Speaker: NA
Text: whereby concerned people in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: are seeking to assist our seniors groups, but

Speaker: NA
Text: if someone is a Labor staffer, well that is

Speaker: NA
Text: different in their socialist eyes.

Speaker: NA
Text: But then the picture gets a bit clearer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's secretariat has put its campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy into gear and called up its Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: heavyweight, the man elected to fill Mick

Speaker: NA
Text: Young's shoes. Remember Mick Young? He

Speaker: NA
Text: did a runner from Parliament when he lost

Speaker: NA
Text: the axe and the cheque in the woodchip

Speaker: NA
Text: affair, so the head kicker from Port Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: is called in to do a number on me, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Adelaide, to try to discredit me

Speaker: NA
Text: so that Labor can get a bit of a run for Bib

Speaker: NA
Text: Catley, its Moscow and Warsaw trained ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ademic, the scuba diving, luxury yacht owner

Speaker: NA
Text: who hopes to represent the working class.

Speaker: NA
Text: As George Apap-a great Labor Party lu-

Speaker: NA
Text: minary-said, Labor has lost touch with its

Speaker: NA
Text: supporters and keeps fielding these out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: touch academics. He even accused the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Port Adelaide of

Speaker: NA
Text: handing out how to vote cards for the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: erals. How ironic. Well, I have got some

Speaker: NA
Text: news for the head kicker, and that is that he

Speaker: NA
Text: has lost the plot on my exposure of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Democrats and their attempts to

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresent their contribution to the Sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate. But then the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Adelaide went on to extol the virtues

Speaker: NA
Text: of what he and his Government were doing

Speaker: NA
Text: for the pensioners and the superannuants. If

Speaker: NA
Text: we talk to the Government, it says those

Speaker: NA
Text: tens of thousands of elderly Australians have

Speaker: NA
Text: got nothing to complain about. But talk to

Speaker: NA
Text: the 38 pensioners who turned up at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prospect Returned Services League meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Bannon, Crattey Duigan, Harvey

Speaker: NA
Text: talkfest. Ask them about raising the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold or income splitting.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Port Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: condemned me for being involved in Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: pamphlets at the pensioners rally. What does

Speaker: NA
Text: he say to the Prospect mailing list cunningly

Speaker: NA
Text: described as an address book-'Please sign if

Speaker: NA
Text: you would like to be on the Premier's task

Speaker: NA
Text: force inquiry'? It is obvious that the on

Speaker: NA
Text: ground intelligence must have escaped the

Speaker: NA
Text: eyes of one Michael Wright, because 180

Speaker: NA
Text: petitions distributed at the rally have come

Speaker: NA
Text: flooding into my electorate office. They in-

Speaker: NA
Text: clude names from Albert Park, Semaphore

Speaker: NA
Text: and Birkenhead, good suburbs that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member would know about.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not mind a healthy debate, but if

Speaker: NA
Text: someone is going to chop me up to help his

Speaker: NA
Text: bloke in Adelaide, then his people are going

Speaker: NA
Text: to have to be a bit smarter. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member concluded with the fact that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: been in this Parliament for 11 months and

Speaker: NA
Text: not seen from our side 'a policy on helping

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners in need'. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: has in fact been here for 12 months and in

Speaker: NA
Text: that time has made one 90-second speech-

Speaker: NA
Text: some 300 words at less than 30 a month. On

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 December he made 90 seconds worth. For

Speaker: NA
Text: my part, I have made 26 speeches to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, including nine concerning specific

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner problems. I have with me in black

Speaker: NA
Text: and white the coalition's retirement incomes

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, which the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Adelaide has never seen. That is one

Speaker: NA
Text: policy which the Government does not have.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Text: Dobell) (1O.40)-The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: has just finished speaking, said--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sawford-He walks out again.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Text: I hope he remains in the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for my comments. He said he partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pates as often as possible in the adjournment

Speaker: NA
Text: debates because he is on a steep learning

Speaker: NA
Text: curve. He is trying to learn about parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I wish him well in seeking to learn as

Speaker: NA
Text: much as he can about the chamber. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the next lesson he learns is that when

Speaker: NA
Text: one is going to drop a bucket on someone a

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman at least tells the person who is

Speaker: NA
Text: the target for· his attack that he is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a speech about something to do with

Speaker: NA
Text: him. I understand that when the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Port Adelaide ( Mr Sawford)

Speaker: NA
Text: said something critical about the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Adelaide he made sure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Adelaide was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber at the time the comments were

Speaker: NA
Text: made. This is not the first time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Adelaide has acted

Speaker: NA
Text: in this way. At least this time he is not

Speaker: NA
Text: picking on a female member of Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: as he has done in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCGauran-Madam Speaker, I take

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of order. I would seek a withdrawal

Speaker: NA
Text: of that comment. It connotes bullying and is

Speaker: NA
Text: an attack on a member.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member will resume his seat. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no point of order.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Text: I make it clear,. Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, that I was referring to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Hawker ( Mrs Harvey),

Speaker: NA
Text: whom the honourable member for Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: previously attacked without any warning. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would simply say to him that if he wishes in

Speaker: NA
Text: future during the adjournment debate to at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tack members on this side of the House or

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps members of the National Party of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia or anyone else--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Smith-Never from Tasmania.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Text: Especially if they are from Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: mania; the gentlemanly and parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to do is at least to tell the person

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that he is going to give a speech

Speaker: NA
Text: which might be of interest. This is, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: part of his learning curve and I hope that in

Speaker: NA
Text: future debates in this House he takes that

Speaker: NA
Text: on board.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason I rose tonight was to make

Speaker: NA
Text: some comments about a question which I

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on notice concerning a Mr Konrad

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalejs, a gentleman who could be deported

Speaker: NA
Text: from the United States of America. I received

Speaker: NA
Text: the following information from the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Arts and Territories ( Mr Holding)

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the Minister for Immigration,

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ator Robert Ray):

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) On I November 1988 a US immigration judge,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of civil proceedings in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States, ordered that Mr Kalejs be deported from

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: This was done because he had provided false

Speaker: NA
Text: information when applying for a visa to visit

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States. The second reason was as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) by his wartime activities he had 'assisted' in

Speaker: NA
Text: the persecution of individuals based on race, religion,

Speaker: NA
Text: national origin or political opinion' and was deport-

Speaker: NA
Text: able under Section 241 (a) (19) of the US Immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Nationality Act 1952 as amended.

Speaker: NA
Text: I point out that Mr Kalejs has appealed

Speaker: NA
Text: against the deportation order and it could be

Speaker: NA
Text: a long time before the appeal process is

Speaker: NA
Text: finalised. I am concerned that in answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: my question on notice the Minister has made

Speaker: NA
Text: it very clear that if a US citizen had been in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia under similar circumstances, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia could not have asked that person to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave our country. We do not have the same

Speaker: NA
Text: protection which the US legislation provides.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know that Australian taxpayers are

Speaker: NA
Text: about to spend a great deal of money in

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to ensure that people who it is al-

Speaker: NA
Text: leged have committed war crimes in Europe

Speaker: NA
Text: during the Second World War and who have

Speaker: NA
Text: a case to answer will be forced to appear in

Speaker: NA
Text: an Australian court of law and have that

Speaker: NA
Text: case heard in a fair trial. I am concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: that Mr Kalejs will be deported to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: if his appeal is unsuccessful and Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers will possibly then have to pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: a trial against that gentleman.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has confirmed that it is pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible that Mr Kalejs gave false information

Speaker: NA
Text: when he applied to visit Australia way back

Speaker: NA
Text: on 27 October 1950 and he possibly also

Speaker: NA
Text: gave false information when he obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian citizenship in 1957. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: that should be sufficient grounds for deport-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Mr Kalejs to his country of birth.

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Text: Gippsland) (10.45)-

Speaker: NA
Text: That insidious organisation, the League of

Speaker: NA
Text: Rights, has attracted a great deal of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment both in and outside the Parliament in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent months. Much of this comment was

Speaker: NA
Text: commenced by the very courageous National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party of Australia senator for Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Ron Boswell, who sought to expose

Speaker: NA
Text: its operations and influences for what they

Speaker: NA
Text: really are-a grave threat to many of our

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions. A number of Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party members hoped to jump on the band-

Speaker: NA
Text: wagon. Let me deal with two of those Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: members who, in the process, damaged

Speaker: NA
Text: wrongly and utterly unfairly the reputation

Speaker: NA
Text: of an individual and worthy organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Robertson

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Cohen), in an article he wrote in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bulletin on 29 November last year, headed

Speaker: NA
Text: 'League of Wrongs', described the organisaabsolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Women Who Want to be Women as a

Speaker: NA
Text: 'front organisation' of the League of Rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is utterly false. WWWW, which is now

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporated into the organisation Endeaso,

Speaker: NA
Text: vour Forum, has never had any contact with

Speaker: NA
Text: the League of Rights. Indeed, as I shall now

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrate, it has been at the forefront of sive remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting the League of Rights. The founding

Speaker: NA
Text: member and currently the national and overpricornia

Speaker: NA
Text: seas coordinator of WWWW, now Endeanotoriety

Speaker: NA
Text: vour Forum, is a person for whom I have

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of respect. Mrs Babette Francis

Speaker: NA
Text: Indian by birth and, if anybody in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community knows about supposed multiculthe

Speaker: NA
Text: turalism or taunts of racism, I would suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that she does. I understand that Mrs Francis

Speaker: NA
Text: once accepted an invitation to speak at the

Speaker: NA
Text: annual conference of the League of Rights

Speaker: NA
Text: because it is the policy of the Endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: Forum to accept all speaking engagements

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of the views of the host organisaForum

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. When she spoke to the League she took

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to condemn strongly its antilife,

Speaker: NA
Text: Zionist philosphy, and she especially conganisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: demned their questioning of the numbers .of

Speaker: NA
Text: Jewish victims of the Holocaust-so much

Speaker: NA
Text: so that Dr Bill Rubinstein, of the editorial

Speaker: NA
Text: board of Australia/Israel Publications, wrote:

Speaker: NA
Text: Thanks for your remarks in our favour at

Speaker: NA
Text: League of Rights do. This turned up in their

Speaker: NA
Text: zine attached . . . Many thanks again for doing

Speaker: NA
Text: this-it showed great courage, I'm sure as

Speaker: NA
Text: activities do . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreover, Women Who Want to be Women vour Forum.

Speaker: NA
Text: was the only Australian women's group in

Speaker: NA
Text: the non-government organisations forums

Speaker: NA
Text: both the United Nations Mid-decade for

Speaker: NA
Text: Women Conference in Copenhagen in 1980

Speaker: NA
Text: and the final Decade for Women Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: in Nairobi in 1985 which openly expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the Israeli delegation and the

Speaker: NA
Text: right of Israel to exist as an independent

Speaker: NA
Text: nation with defensible frontiers. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Robertson needs any

Speaker: NA
Text: proof of that, I refer him to a report of

Speaker: NA
Text: those conferences in Quadrant of December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980 and December 1985. Interestingly,

Speaker: NA
Text: Babette Francis herself made the point that

Speaker: NA
Text: no other kind of support was offered by

Speaker: NA
Text: feminist groups funded by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to attend those conferences.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier this year Endeavour Forum pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished Gizela, the story of a Jewish Holo-

Speaker: NA
Text: caust victim written by her mother. So it is

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong for the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Robertson to make that attack on En-

Speaker: NA
Text: deavour Forum and specifically Mrs Babette

Speaker: NA
Text: Francis. Despite having been requested to do

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member has never apol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ogised to either Mrs Francis or Endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: Forum for his utterly inaccurate and offen-

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, the honourable member for Ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Wright), in a speech of some

Speaker: NA
Text: in this place late last year, also

Speaker: NA
Text: a attacked the four Ws, or Endeavour Forum,

Speaker: NA
Text: is as being an apologist group for the League

Speaker: NA
Text: of Rights. Mrs Babette Francis also wrote to

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Capricornia

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking an apology. Instead, I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honourable member for Capricornia

Speaker: NA
Text: wrote back to her, not offering any sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: apology but listing a whole set of questions

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to financial status and membership

Speaker: NA
Text: and organisational aspects of Endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: for answering. Endeavour Forum is

Speaker: NA
Text: a group of sincere individuals who are pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pro-family and anti-radical feminist or-

Speaker: NA
Text: It is made up of people of intel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ligence, integrity and utter fairness. To my

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge, and certainly to the knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: of the office-holders of that organisation, none

Speaker: NA
Text: of these people would have any contact with

Speaker: NA
Text: the the League of Rights. I call on the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: magaable member for Robertson and the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: all your able member for Capricornia now to

Speaker: NA
Text: apologise to Mrs Francis and to the Endea-

Speaker: Mr SAWFORD
Text: Port Adelaide) (10.50)-

Speaker: NA
Text: at The honourable member for Adelaide ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Pratt) is not here to hear me respond to his

Speaker: NA
Text: comments. Last Thursday night in the ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journment debate I praised him for his essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial idea of caring for the elderly citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and I am sure that view is shared

Speaker: NA
Text: by every honourable member on the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment side. However, he failed to accept my

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion that he should get to the stomach,

Speaker: NA
Text: the means, the substance of what he is trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to do for pensioners. In his speech last

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Thursday he slammed the Australian Dem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ocrats for handing out pamphlets and ignor-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ing the wishes of the senior citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide, but he failed to address the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Liberal Party in South Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: handed out pamphlets. It is interesting that

Speaker: NA
Text: on that day the Labor Party complied with

Speaker: NA
Text: the wishes of the senior citizens and did not

Speaker: NA
Text: hand out pamphlets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The trouble with the ideas of the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Adelaide is that they lack

Speaker: NA
Text: substance. For example, last Thursday night

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Adelaide made

Speaker: NA
Text: some claims about the Bannon Labor Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in South Australia. He referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: increased violence against the elderly. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member is simply not telling the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth. I shall mention some of the achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of the Bannon Labor Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia. They include the enactment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Summary Offences Act with increased

Speaker: NA
Text: penalties for over 50 offences. The maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty for rape is life imprisonment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum penalty for indecent assault is eight

Speaker: NA
Text: years. The maximum penalty for robbery

Speaker: NA
Text: with violence is life imprisonment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member did not mention the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to section 302 of the Criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: Law Consolidation Act which resulted in a

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial increase in the level of sentences

Speaker: NA
Text: for armed robbery and other crimes. He failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to mention the Crimes (Confiscation of Prof-

Speaker: NA
Text: its) Act, introduced in 1986, allowing the

Speaker: NA
Text: courts to order the forfeiture of assets ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained as a result of criminal activity. He

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to mention the penalties for drug

Speaker: NA
Text: fickers in South Australia-a fine up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $250,000 and 25 years in gaol. He failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: mention that the Attorney-General in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has authorised over 100 appeals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to acknowledge that in South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia over 100 Neighbourhood Watch areas

Speaker: NA
Text: have been established. He failed to acknowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge that funding for the Police Department

Speaker: NA
Text: in South Australia has increased by $83m in

Speaker: NA
Text: the past six years. By the way, South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has the highest ratio of -0iil,;e per

Speaker: NA
Text: capita of any State. An examination of the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence and a reading of the facts show

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has not been a downturn in the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of penalties for offences and that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no evidence to support the claim of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Adelaide that there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a dramatic upswing in crime aimed

Speaker: NA
Text: at the elderly of South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The real point in my criticism of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Adelaide is that, al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though it is acknowledged that he has the

Speaker: NA
Text: idea right, it is no use in this House having

Speaker: NA
Text: a good idea and not having the wherewithal

Speaker: NA
Text: to put forward a policy and be able to state

Speaker: NA
Text: what the specifics of that policy are. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: really what I said. What is the outcome of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's making that state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment? Is he feeling good? The outcome is

Speaker: NA
Text: nil, nothing, zero, nix, zilch, nought. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: completely blank nadir. It is an inverted

Speaker: NA
Text: zenith. As I said to the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: of Adelaide on Thursday night, he came into

Speaker: NA
Text: bat for the elderly-that is a great thing

Speaker: NA
Text: which members of the Government side re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect-but he made a duck. He did not

Speaker: NA
Text: make any runs. Tonight he again stated some

Speaker: NA
Text: very valid and good ideas, but he had no

Speaker: NA
Text: wherewithal, no substance, no process, no

Speaker: NA
Text: facility to implement the ideas. Again he

Speaker: NA
Text: made no runs.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr SAWFORD
Text: He nicked his own

Speaker: NA
Text: wicket, as the honourable member for Chi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fley said. I think he did more than that. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think he was bowled middle stump. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Adelaide has a

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine concern for people in his electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I would like to see him come up in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House with a little more than a piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: paper which he says is his Party's policy for

Speaker: NA
Text: traf- the elderly in South Australia.

Speaker: Mr SMITH
Text: Bass) (10.55)-Today

Speaker: NA
Text: marked the opening of the Australian Insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute of Radiography's fortieth annual confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence. I was present at that conference, and

Speaker: NA
Text: radiography has some problems which I

Speaker: NA
Text: should like to bring to the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. Some researchers indicate that ra-

Speaker: NA
Text: diography as a profession is under some strain

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country. It is a service that most of

Speaker: NA
Text: us experience when we go to have X-rays

Speaker: NA
Text: taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: Back in October 1986 the Institute in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales called for a limited operator

Speaker: NA
Text: training program to allow medical staff in

Speaker: NA
Text: outback and remote New South Wales hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pitals to attain basic knowledge of X-ray

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment. Why was this so? It was revealed

Speaker: NA
Text: that patients in remote New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals were being exposed to radiation

Speaker: NA
Text: doses up to 1,000 times higher than neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary because staff were operating the X-ray

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment in an untrained way. One exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple quoted to me involved a nurse who had

Speaker: NA
Text: made 34 attempts at X-raying a patient in a

Speaker: NA
Text: small country town before the patient was

Speaker: NA
Text: sent to Dubbo Hospital. Another example

Speaker: NA
Text: involved a 16-year-old girl who had two

Speaker: NA
Text: punctured lungs which were missed by inves-

Speaker: NA
Text: tigating doctors after a young nurse was asked

Speaker: NA
Text: to operate the X-ray equipment. In my view,

Speaker: NA
Text: the national conference has the ideal oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to raise these issues to national prom-

Speaker: NA
Text: inence at its conference in Launceston this

Speaker: NA
Text: week.

Speaker: NA
Text: For most Australians the profession is the

Speaker: NA
Text: front line in preventive medical procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: for breast cancer. More than 5,000 cases of

Speaker: NA
Text: breast cancer are diagnosed each year in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and one in 15 develops the disease

Speaker: NA
Text: during her lifetime. For this reason alone the

Speaker: NA
Text: profession of radiography must make its voice

Speaker: NA
Text: heard so that every Australian, whether a

Speaker: NA
Text: city or country dweller, is able to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: those expert services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Interestingly, back in 1986 the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Government's response to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal for this urgent training program, was

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was far too expensive. However, one

Speaker: NA
Text: may legitimately ask the question, 'Can pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventive or early warning and correct diag-

Speaker: NA
Text: nostic procedures ever be too expensive?'.

Speaker: NA
Text: All honourable members in this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the cost of health services is ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessive and preventive medicine is by far and

Speaker: NA
Text: away the best and cheapest medicine to the

Speaker: NA
Text: overall community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier this month the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: National Cancer Institute's most recent fig-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures for 1985, released this month, show that

Speaker: NA
Text: the incidence of new breast cancer cases

Speaker: NA
Text: diagnosed per year is the highest in history

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United States. The death rate from

Speaker: NA
Text: breast cancer has increased and this increase

Speaker: NA
Text: may be attributed to diagnosing more cases

Speaker: NA
Text: with new technology or it may be a real

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the spread of cancer. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: the specialists admit they do not know. Only

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 to 20 percent of United States women

Speaker: NA
Text: have regular screenings. In Australia the fig-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure is estimated at below 5 per cent. Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: also has concerns about radiography and the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent of breast cancer and detection. The

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the United Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: working group on breast cancer screening in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1987 interestingly made the following

Speaker: NA
Text: observation:

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a need for a massive program to train

Speaker: NA
Text: radiographers to carry out procedures correctly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the same issue applies in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: but more so. It is estimated that in Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of a national screening program

Speaker: NA
Text: every two years of women over 50, those

Speaker: NA
Text: most susceptible to breast cancer, would save

Speaker: NA
Text: the life of one woman in 100 who otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: would have died from breast cancer. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: view, Australia must reassess its attitude to

Speaker: NA
Text: screening for breast cancer. I do not have all

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts, but I worry whether government,

Speaker: NA
Text: at both State and Federal level, appreciates

Speaker: NA
Text: the extent of the disease. I welcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement of the Minister for Commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity Services and Health (Dr Blewett) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Radiation Laboratory survey to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish the range of radiation doses cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently being used in the latest technology.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, is it enough just to make a rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendation, as Dr Blewett did in a press

Speaker: NA
Text: release, that women over 40 should have an

Speaker: NA
Text: initial mammograph, then regularly after that

Speaker: NA
Text: as advised by a doctor?

Speaker: NA
Text: My concern is that when one examines

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent United Sta - figures, as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: the concern expressed in the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom and at the conference in Launceston

Speaker: NA
Text: today, one sees that Australia needs to dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cuss these issues in far more depth than is

Speaker: NA
Text: the case at present. The participants in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Launceston conference will have the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity during the national conference to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: to national prominence these issues, which

Speaker: NA
Text: for too long have been ignored. The health

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian women is being ignored. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: time that we all took a far closer look at

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue and supported the radiography

Speaker: NA
Text: profession.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 11 p.m.
